movie_review_blurb: Truly tense, entertaining and -- and here's a word that's rarely used to describe American movies -- unpredictable.
It's a dull retelling, noble in purpose but meandering in execution.
The writing is half-baked, from the muddled dialogue between Jamal and William, to the flimsy plot points, such as the answer to why Forrester doesn't publish anymore.
What's most despicable is the dichotomy the film draws between family and success.
The script is too grounded to be considered farce, but the flick is way too silly for grownups.
Moving, entertaining, and sometimes very funny.
The release of Best in Show, which reunites most of the talent from Waiting for Guffman, is a cause for celebration.
Nothing Like the Holidays is vaguely unsatisfying, caught somewhere in the middle between popcorn flick and serious cinema.
The eerie buildup is mostly pro forma... But the backstory of the haunted house, revealed slowly in sepia-toned hallucinations, really is creepy.
It instills an appreciation for the tremendous amount of work and passion that the performers put into their craft.
The enigmatic Andreotti is the perfect subject for a biopic in the European tradition.
The results aren't quite Anchorman, but they're worth a chuckle.

For science-fiction fans looking for a bit more brainpower than Transformers has to offer, District 9 points the way toward redemption for a movie genre that could use an infusion of artistic ambition.

As the subject of a documentary, this grim enterprise distinctly lacks the warm and fuzzy appeal of The March of the Penguins. So director Louie Psihoyos ingeniously reinvents his film as a spy caper.
Starting with the ominous caveat 'Inspired by a true story', there is little indication that All Roads Lead Home is going anywhere interesting.
A ufologist's variant of The Da Vinci Code, except without all the action and faux scholarship.
Every time the story shows some glimmer of originality, it immediately retreats back to formula.
If you're willing to regress to the mental age of 12 for a couple of hours, it's an amusing ride.
It's funny how movies based on real stories can be the most formulaic and predictable.

As a subtle expression of masculine angst, it's the timid flipside of Fight Club. As a gentle critique of the American dream's descent into empty consumerism, it's a less cutesy, less feminist Little Miss Sunshine.
Both halves of the story ring true in their way, but they don't ring out in harmony.
Vile, hateful and undeniably funny.
The film does shed light an another facet of Nazi history, and it does it with an attention to the complexity of human nature that makes it worthy of its Oscar win.
This is stand-up comedy here. Bring the funny and leave the rest on the bus.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Margot at the Wedding is an excellent film that few people will see, and even fewer will like.
When it's funny, it's good. But when it takes a turn for the heartwarming, it feels more like a Disney knockoff than a send-up.

To the shock of cynics in the audience waiting for this film fantasy to be lame, Beowulf turns out to be exciting, fun and occasionally breathtaking. No question it's a popcorn flick, but it's cheesy only when it chooses to be.
To call this feel-good comedy conservative is to cede 'family values' to the realm of politics, which, despite a vague NPR-ishness to the characters, is something Real Life refuses to do.
As a procedural, Gone Baby Gone is by the numbers. As a portrait of human folly and resilience, however, it's great drama, and it has some powerful performances to match.
Dripping with Wes Anderson's patented blend of whimsy and melancholy, The Darjeeling Limited is the story of three brothers traveling across India in search of themselves.
A thoughtful, informative and thoroughly entertaining examination of the role of performance-enhancing drugs in modern life.
I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell is the Armageddon of gross-out sex comedies.
movie_title: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The smart storytelling combines with spectacular visual set pieces and a spicy musical gumbo to deliver one of the finest films of the year, in any genre.
This movie may be filled with razor-sharp shuriken and katanas, but as far as the filmmaking goes, it's a blunt instrument.
It isn't possible to examine the scientific arguments in a movie review, but as advocacy documentaries go, this is a pretty good one.

How many times must we be subjected to another gorgeous, glamorous starlet impersonating a clumsy wallflower? Will anyone really believe in this GQ-perfect big man on campus who lacks the courage to ask her out on a date?
Beauty, along with a sense of mystery, is what audiences expect in a Gothic romance, and Fukunaga delivers with carefully composed shots of austere landscapes and shadowy Victorian opulence.
The acting is restrained, the story stays under the top, and hand-held cameras shake almost imperceptibly, giving a whiff of verite with no danger of going full Greengrass.
Bowden's devastatingly casual assessments give the film much of its punch, but, ultimately, the barrage of simple assertions fails to cohere into an argument.

To its credit, the film does attempt to grapple with the ambivalence that Europe and America feel toward the Roman Empire. We admire its cultural achievements while condemning its brutality, and in that tension we see our own ideals and failures reflected.

Carrey is truly great in one of those rare risky roles that prove he can do more than pull faces, although the frank portrayal of an alpha male who is also "gay, gay, gay, gay, gay" is sure to make some percentage of his fan base squirm.
The best thing about the film is neither the top-notch CGI nor the shallow moral lessons but the performance of Will Poulter as Lucy and Edmund's insufferable cousin Eustace Scrubb.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: With "Tangled," a delightfully fresh spin on "Rapunzel," the entertainment powerhouse delivers its first classic-caliber computer animation outside the Pixar family.
The supporting cast serves up enough small moments of surprise to keep this formula flick from falling flat.

Once Hackford has committed to the characters and to their compelling (if dark) world, he has nowhere to go but to some predecided facts that might not be the most interesting end to the characters' journey.
What can you say: The French sure know how to make pretty pictures.
The characters and their supernatural love triangle are developed with a businesslike efficiency that makes it almost impossible to invest in them emotionally.
South of the Border offers valuable historical, social and political context, particularly if you aren't an international-news junkie.
The already fragile bond between the two leads gains an added layer of intrigue here because it plays out at a distance.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In an American film, you live the story. In a European one, you're an outsider looking in. Ah, but what a beautiful view.
Letters to Juliet is a guilty pleasure for the ladies, perfect Blu-ray fodder when their significant others turn them into World of Warcraft widows for the evening.
As formula films go, The Bounty Hunter is more enjoyable than most, even if it packs in as many cliches as any.
An intriguing portrait of a man and a time that changed everything.
Fuqua tries to create the illusion of meaning by copycatting the style and techniques of better directors, but he can't save the naked emperor of the script.
Even if you're convinced by the many well-spoken interviewees, the film's conclusion is almost as depressing as the historical indictment that precedes it.

In interviews with a few of the key players, the film desensationalizes the story without really demystifying it. It's an intriguing but shallow examination that never really finds a point of view about its subject.

Elizabeth achieved its power by focusing on the central idea of how a callow princess became a great queen. In trying to re-create the formula, the sequel merely grasps about for a reason to be, and that makes for dull watching, indeed.
Whip It, set in the roller-derby subculture of Austin, is a sweet coming-of-age comedy, safe, familiar and comforting.
There's a lot of great stuff here, but it just doesn't come together.
May not shake all the cowbells off the genre, but it kicks up plenty of dust.
Suffice it to say it's a bit of primal brutality that lays bare the animal in each of us, fighting to survive.
Despite an occasional whiff of cheese, it's mostly a fresh, funny, coming-of-age story that feels authentic.
Reygadas' gift for imagery is undeniable, but for most viewers, Battle in Heaven will offer not enlightenment but frustration.
The faux mythology may be cheesy, the grandiose plot stretched thin and full of holes, but underneath the recycled story and style is a hint of something troubling and real.
The intellectual grist is intriguing, but one can't escape the feeling that Bee Season is only skimming the surface of its source material.
If the filmmaking is somewhat less perfect than in Ang Lee's Sense and Sensibility, Austen fans will nonetheless delight to see their favorite characters brought to life.
It's what you thought Fight Club was going to be, before it went in a whole other (and far more interesting) direction.
It sounds weird, and it is. It's also very funny, not to mention mesmerizing and, finally, heartbreaking.
Captures the frustration of those who sense something deeply dysfunctional in the political and economic status quo but feel impotent do anything about it.
As much as it tries to be a smart, postmodern indie film, dot the i is pure Hollywood fluff.
If the plot is thin, at least the characters are interesting, and the performances are consistently strong.
A great piece of entertainment.
Director Lucrecia Martel's storytelling is spare to the point of being stingy.
Everything a nature film should be: breathtaking, heartbreaking, soul-inspiring.
It is at once a beautiful work of artifice and a convincing reflection of life's messy ambiguities. Aesthetically contained, morally uncertain.
With no access to these women's inner selves, we are left wanting at least a fuller portrait of their outer lives, some way to infer the meaning that the film declines to provide.
Affecting performances by the cast place those abstract issues firmly in the human world.

Combining the sinister suspense of Alfred Hitchcock with the unrepentant violence of Quentin Tarantino, South Korean director Park Chan-wook delivers a revenge tale as shocking as it is thought-provoking.
What might have been a static portrait has become a true story, with tragic turns, joyful surprises and provocative glimpses into the meaning of life.
movie_title: The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill (2005)

movie_review_blurb: No, it's not particularly original. But it's pretty darned funny.
Jaa's moves are impressive, but the choreography ranges from bland to ridiculous (as when one dirty fighter resorts to using major appliances as weapons).
It's hard to imagine this movie capturing an audience outside the Mormon community.
Like its cinematically superior inspiration, Celsius 41.11 isn't going to change many minds.

Mormon movies are a burgeoning industry in Utah, and despite the niche audience and low budgets, some of them hold their own with Hollywood in terms of storytelling and entertainment value. The Book of Mormon Movie, however, isn't one of them.
It took me all of 10 minutes to decide I hated it.
Tedious and utterly lacking in dramatic tension.
A reflection of how its main character comes to experience reality, as one small moment between what came before and whatever horror or happiness is yet to come.
Despite quibbles over details, the case [Gore] presents is compelling, and anyone who isn't sure whether global warming is a mounting crisis or a massive hoax should see this film.
With its absurd anti-gun "message," the film certainly could be called a satire, yet it remains firmly within the genre it is satirizing.
A precisely calibrated crowd-pleasing machine, balancing action, comedy and just the bare minimum of pathos.
An old-fashioned English farce with enough gross-out humor to rival the dumb and dumberest of American movies, but also enough smarts to make your pleasure guilt-free.

One of those self-consciously quirky indie films that will strike some as comic genius while leaving the rest of the audience scratching their head.

This movie feels less like a plot-point checklist than the last one did, and there's enough visual razzle-dazzle to entertain those who haven't read the book and might miss a twist here or a turn there.

Um, gambling's bad, mkay?

As sweet as the pies that serve as its central gimmick.
Pretentious and precious.

Just from an entertainment standpoint, wondering what decisions the characters will make, and what the consequences might be, makes for edge-of-your-seat tension despite the movie's quietly thoughtful tone.

Efforts to build suspense, with ominous music and dark figures flashing past the camera, are laughably amateurish, as is the made-for-TV cinematography.

A film that's thoughtful and exuberant, achingly sad and wildly funny.

A chilling portrait of a megalomaniac.

This is certainly a believable story, but it's one we've seen before, and neither screenwriter Douglas Soesbe nor director Dito Montiel has found a way to elevate it into something that challenges or inspires.

It's hard to watch. And even harder to look away.
Genisys is more entertaining than the last two installments, although it's not nearly as good as the first two.

To those film lovers attuned to quiet moments and emotional nuance, this film has a shine all its own. The old-school hand-drawn animation celebrates sweeping landscapes and but also the telling detail, revealing character through spare gestures.

movie_review_blurb: Steadily a portrait emerges of a man who is an inspiration as much for his character as for his talent.

It's Hollywood formula at its most generic.
Yes, there are life lessons aplenty, but that's perfectly appropriate in a celebration of one of the great moral fables of all time.

A straightforward, fly-on-the-wall portrait of real people struggling with real-life problems.

movie_review_blurb: Naharin's dances, amply illustrated from decades' worth of film, are visceral, emotional and sometimes shocking.

A courageously mundane character study that aims to show people as they really are, rather than the gauzy movie version that we all want our lives to be.

For me, while it's not quite "This Is Spinal Tap," it scores at least a 7 out of 11.

A film that sometimes comes off as an intersection of tangents, but it also gives rise to moments of joyous whimsy.

Inspired by a childhood accident that befell director Fernando Eimbcke soon after his father's death, this low-key character study is a beguiling paradox of Mexican suburban splendor masking personal grief.
[Director] Larrain deftly employs a Dardennes-style in-the-moment handheld lensing, managing a high-wire act in which audience disgust is outpaced by breathless anticipation.
This nightmare scenario is to high-school valedictorians what this wreck of a movie is to comedy screenwriters.

Pirates is a film whose insipid, generic plainness is its worse offense.

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps carving enough space for the previously unheard voices of Muslim gays to speak is enough to ask of this socially groundbreaking work.
With Blind Mountain, 6th Generation Chinese maverick Li Yang continues his scorched-earth treatment of 5th Generation heroic peasant stereotypes launched by his debut feature Blind Shaft.

Disappointingly uncharacteristic of Sokurov, the humanist moments that pass between them lean toward token sentiment, and the moments that pass between Alexandra and the grandson she traveled so far to see feel inconsequential.
Brian De Palma's paradoxical take on the occupation of Iraq is as blatant as an open sore yet swathed in layers of formalist irony.
Useless is a shape-shifting work that overturns expectations at every turn and leaves behind an open-ended consideration of value -- of clothing, of human labor, of human life.

Caché is about how the way we look at people -- a spouse, a child, a homeless person, a security guard -- reflects our own humanity, exactly the sort of thing the best works of cinematic art aspire to reveal.
Lee has a rare gift for depicting how the minor dissonance of everyday interactions eventually explodes into public displays of rage and despair.
Tarr seems to be working in a pan-European purgatory through which his elaborate camera movements are more clinical than communitarian.

movie_review_blurb: Never mind the crazy cast; this weary retread of trendy multicharacter melodramas is what's really unhinged.
Following his most even-handed exploration of male-female sexual conflict in Woman on the Beach, Hong Sang-soo hurtles full-bore into the subjectivity of the horny man with Night and Day.

But more than probing the societal norms that undermine his salacious couple's bid at happiness, Cisse is also out to dissect the sordid relationship between storytelling and reality.
The conventions of contemporary youth culture and cinema could both use a change of sheets.
In "Chi-raq," Lee mixes fierce agitprop with lyrical musical numbers and Greek-inspired sex farce in hip hop verse. It's a mad combination that fittingly addresses a world of madness.

Bratt's performance suggests enough subcutaneous rage to give the proceedings an edge, even when the sluggish narrative takes the slow-cruise ethos of its low-rider culture far too literally at times.

Intimate yet larger-than-life, this masterpiece of the everyday shows you don't need James Cameron's toy box to make images pop from the screen, much less to see and embrace the world anew.
Unable to probe the complex relationships engendered by a biracial society, Skin simply becomes an example of colorless, by-the-numbers apartheid cinema.
William Hurt and Chiwetel Ejiofor, impressive at opposite ends of the table as a government mouthpiece and a philosophy professor, provide all the fireworks the story needs.

Certainly a nobler attempt in the animated feature genre than the likes of Robots, Shark Tale and Chicken Little.

Whether it's read as an exclamation of borough pride or as a set of unwritten laws governing its residents, the movie takes a well-trodden path in chronicling the lives of three Italian American friends, circa 1985.
The story and characters are surprisingly engaging, with fight scenes and scares effectively placed between plot turns.
This mostly effective dramatization paints a suitably ugly picture of the dehumanizing depths people are willing to go for money.
Director David L. Cunningham applies a jarring, disorienting style to much of the action that, rather than mirroring Will's inner confusion, distances the audience from his plight.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Goodness, gracious, there's no greatness in Balls of Fury, a lifeless pingpong comedy that ricochets from one flat gag to the next. The only novelty it can boast of is that it's a sports spoof without Will Ferrell.
The distance Kaurismki creates belies his deeply humanistic streak. He engages characters in the direst of situations not to see them suffer but to search for hope.
An expressionistic portrait of a society in violent chaos, the film blends cinÃ (C)ma vÃ (C)ritÃ (C) and newsreel footage to capture a modern-day tragedy with Shakespearean overtones.
A bittersweet story of a family and the surprising effects a crusading eccentric can have on them.

White is a clever writer, and many of his best lines will sneak up on you long after you leave the theater. There's a stealthy sweetness to the movie, a desire to understand those who go their own way, that would seem to be his ultimate aim.

The best way to enjoy it is to suspend your disbelief and soak up the actorly tête-à-tête that pits wily veteran Anthony Hopkins against young gun Ryan Gosling in the kind of courtroom potboiler that can be fun if you let it.
It's a ridiculous plot, but one that's absolutely in the spirit of the films they're satirizing.
Diggers has the conviction to avoid tying things up with a bow and allows us the privilege to imagine where its denizens will go afterward.
Coupland and Fox do a nimble job of incorporating seemingly tangential points that are deceptively relevant to the larger issues.
A completely forgettable comedy starring Zach Braff and Amanda Peet, The Ex takes a mix of tired scenarios and combines them in a way that makes the nearly 90 minutes feel much longer.
Much of the journey becomes redundant, and the film likely would have been more effective as a 20-minute short.
This film feels like Hartley has been handed a Bourne or a Bond movie to direct and maintained his own style and low-budget aesthetic while thoroughly enjoying and deconstructing his new toy.
Strives for contemporary noir in tone but feels closer to an ineffective parody of James M. Cain filtered through faux David Mamet dialogue.

In essence, you get It's a Wonderful Life meets Wings of Desire, swapping out the substance for self-help platitudes. If you can get past that, you can enjoy it as a 90-minute look at a lovely postcard.
The film probably tilts the balance too far in favor of Mr. Brooks at the expense of the uninspired Det. Atwood.
Many of the riffs in the mock documentary might be lost on little tykes, but the film's feel-good message of perseverance, friendship and finding your own wave should be enjoyed by all.
This deeply felt vision of the human condition has more resonance than yet another movie concluding that war is hell.

We've seen the inner lives of hit men and mobsters rendered innumerably in recent years on film and television, but You Kill Me does it in a satisfyingly comedic way, loaded with easily identifiable idiosyncrasies.
The dancing is sexy, but the complete lack of chemistry between Sanchez and Sweeney makes the love story and the film fizzle.
An inspiring tale of a small woman who stands tall in the face of injustice.
Uncovers the same joy and sorrow that characterizes the Romani music in the everyday lives of the musicians who play it.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is a pastiche of tortured slapstick, groan-inducing dialogue and a lethal dose of treacle, apparently awaiting one of Williams' trademark sprees of riffing and vamping to save the day. That moment never comes.
Murer is a skillful director and has crafted a crowd-pleasing story that will have particular appeal to mature 'tweeners.

The film often feels like a ghost story narrated by the ghost himself and works best when it is visually more impressionistic. Images of empty rooms and landscapes are far more evocative than the Cobain stand-ins the filmmakers occasionally deploy.
Gray's skill with meting out suspense pays considerable dividends.
[Director] Karslake balances the more emotional elements of the film together with the scriptural analysis and weaves them into a moving conclusion.
movie_title: For the Bible Tells Me So (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [The filmmakers] make the common error of attempting to cover every seemingly significant moment in the man's life rather than focusing on the greatest conflicts.
An orgy of disco-era excess, it's also an interminable exercise in beating a dead horse.
Our investment in their plight is ultimately enough to withstand the contrivance of the plot thread that tightens and tests the young men's relationship.

Longtime screenwriters Dick Clement and Ian La Frenais have woven a masterful narrative full of odd twists and dark humor from which Australian director Roger Donaldson and a prime cast mine plum characters and a tight plot to satisfying effect.
Its occasionally endearing schmaltz is eclipsed by bizarre shifts in tone and a lackluster story.

Terrific performances and a bleak, riveting look at life on the economic fringes eventually gives way to an overly familiar tale of abuse, denial and catharsis that feels like warmed over Sam Shepard minus the poetry.

Some of the movie's problems stem from the fact that the filmmakers can't seem to decide whose story it is, with a constant narrative tug of war between Wade and Ryan's battle for survival and Drillbit's dreams of escaping to Canada.
When the makers of the blackjack drama 21 stepped up to the table to place their bets, they opted to play it safe.
As much as the film uplifts, it also anguishes as the difficult appeal process plays out.

The otherwise congenial film plays itself to a draw because of flat characters and a script that overdoes the melodrama in the service of checking off a series of genre tropes borrowed from sports movies.

Director Eli Hershko and co-writer Christopher Theokas do a nice job with the relationship between Carla and Grandpa, but the other roles go underdeveloped. The filmmakers are even less successful with plotting, telegraphing every major turn.
By concentrating on the early projects, we get a richer sense of the development of Nichols the artist in his own words and illustrated with photos and extended clips of performances.
Though there is undeniable uplift to the performances and Warren builds to a suitably inspiring crescendo, the film's hybrid format may prove frustrating.
[An] intimate, sometimes painful documentary ... demonstrates what a Sisyphean task seeking the truth can be.
Harvey delivers an in-depth cultural and sociological view of the sport, while making a compelling case for the necessity of fighting.

It's surprisingly affecting, but there's a tendency to telegraph ... pivotal emotional moments that in a way lessens their effect. It's a tribute to the film's overall craft and, especially, its cast, that it's as much a winner as it is.
Within this roiling Petri dish, the filmmakers cultivate a dynamic portrait of Egypt, with its dense social, political and religious layers.
Ty Manns' script ... plays like a first draft, one written from a manual and riddled with two-dimensional characters and on-the-nose dialogue.
[An] exceedingly earnest hybrid documentary/docudrama ...
Jones reportedly conceived of the film years ago. However, as the story evolved and took on more emotional themes he never found the right balance between the sentimental and the hard-boiled.
Jumper seems half-done -- a long prologue building to a classic hero's journey or the launch of an antihero -- but comes to a screeching halt before it can begin either.
... wickedly funny ...

Its full title may be unwieldy and its humor a tad colorful for a family audience, but Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show is surprisingly endearing and chock-full of a genuine appreciation of the moment.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the presence of funny guys such as Zahn, Garlin, Justin Long and Jonah Hill, along with veteran character actors Ernest Borgnine, Joe Don Baker and Robert Patrick, the movie fails to be even passably funny.

A flotilla of L.A. residents gathers in an unlandscaped recreation area in Baldwin Hills to canoodle, attempt suicide, plot revenge and dig into one another's psyches in writer-director Kurt Voelker's high-spirited if slight comedy, Park.
Choking Man mainly falters in its inability to reconcile the darker psychological elements of Jorge's mind and all that they portend.
Irrepressibly moving without being sentimental, Steal a Pencil for Me is a testimony to true love.
While endearingly heartfelt and G-rated to boot, its storytelling suffers from a lack of locomotive force and characters that feel disappointingly two-dimensional.
Part horror movie, part agitprop theater, What Would Jesus Buy? is a documentary on a mission.
Despite an attractive cast and a few nice moments, Sex and Breakfast is just not that exciting.
In a year that has seen wave after wave of films addressing the war in Iraq with varying degrees of anger and frustration, Grace serves as a gently thoughtful coda and reminder of what continues.
A film that's main crime is inducing stupefying boredom with little payoff in the end.

Everything has been significantly amped up -- bigger, louder, further removed from reality -- but it also feels that much more forced. Cage and Kruger seem like they're not having much fun this time around, and Bartha still gets the best throwaway lines.
Freeman and Nicholson make the most of Justin Zackham's script, but there just isn't enough substance behind their characters to prop up the carpe diem platitudes.
What it lacks in originality, it makes up for in execution.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Together with production designer Toby Corbett and costume designer Hope Hanafin, they get their visual cues from the narrative and the music, creating a rich, down-to-earth environment where violence and magic seem equally possible.
A gentle adventure-comedy that sails a heroes' journey so straight and true that Joseph Campbell would smile.
movie_title: The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Perfectly in tone with election season, Dan Cox's documentary plays like a 30-second political attack ad (at 144 times the length), rehashing the accusations that have been bouncing off the Austrian-born movie star for years.
While it [the "camcorder ploy"] injects the film with a run-and-gun urgency, the device grows tiresome and ultimately leaves the film shortchanged.
Perched uncomfortably between thriller and melodrama, it's a film that hints at possibilities that are left unfulfilled.
A diverting police procedural.
Rambo hits his stride in the film's second half, meting out justice in an unjust world and ultimately the movie works best when warbling its out-of-tune greatest hits.
For what is essentially a screwball comedy, Over Her Dead Body is surprisingly uninspired, a frothy concept that offers little satisfaction in the way of execution.
Writer-director Malcolm D. Lee sets out to prove that you can go home again, but the lesson apparently is that it's going to be painful for everyone involved (audiences included).
... the 81-minute film contains a surprising amount of information about the two Italian-born immigrants who were tried, convicted and executed in Boston amid accusations of grave injustice.
The scenario isn't entirely plausible, but the actors are engaging and you can't beat the running time.
The movie is at its funniest and most original when zinging the sometimes pretentious milieu of competitive figure skating.
Maddeningly exploitative, the film takes a provocative subject -- pedophilia -- and wraps it in a sterile, vacuum-sealed package, devoid of meaning.
It's a terrific story of a team of Davids with hoop dreams running a gantlet of patrician Goliaths against a backdrop of momentous social change.
Something about the boldness of the exercise keeps you watching.

The film strives for some type of a girl-empowerment message that equates trading one type of conformity for another with self-determination but muffs the dismount and stumbles on the landing. In other words, it fails to Stick It.

A barely concealed rip-off of National Lampoon's Vacation, this Barry Sonnenfeld-directed, Robin Williams-starring misfire spits out one failed gag after another as it tries to disguise its lack of originality.
The grand ideas are effectively integrated into a drama that relies equally upon the head, the heart and the body for inspiration.

Grant opens up his life, not with embarrassment or explanation but with humanity and gratitude. Emotional, melodramatic and sentimental, the film unabashedly wears its heart on its sleeve, and is the better for it.

Rogerson and producer Jilann Spitzmiller ably convey the humanity of the inmates while also exposing them as deeply flawed individuals. The film also reconfirms the enduring relevance and power of Shakespeare and his adaptability to almost any milieu.
The frenetic, action-oriented (and fairly violent) set-pieces are well crafted, but without interesting characters it's only sporadically involving.
... highly persuasive ...
Smart, compassionate filmmaking that captures both the intricacies and the tragedy of contemporary adolescence.
Fine, understated performances and the self-assured way that Byler lets the film find its own rhythms, rather than setting into some template, result in a mature film of subtle complexity.
Though the film seldom deviates from its thriller format, Gamazon and Dela Llana astutely weave in matters of political, cultural and religious importance, elevating Cavite well above mere genre.
Autumn is as dry and lifeless as the leaves that fall to the ground in its opening images.
A skeeter noir bogged down in the unconvincing pulp of a melodrama without conviction.
It's one of the charms of Air Guitar Nation that much of it plays like a mockumentary in which you're not quite sure who's pulling your leg. But it's real, even if the guitars are not.
The typically moronic plot simply gets in the way of what might have been a super-ambitious sneaker commercial.
An exhilarating story of loyalty and perseverance, The Heart of the Game succeeds as both inspiration and social commentary.
The themes are all familiar and the plot unfolds slowly and in predictable ways, but there's plenty of heat generated by the three leads.
Interviews with metal practitioners such as Tony Iommi, Alice Cooper, Rob Zombie and Dee Snider, journalists and academic types paint a compelling portrait of a vibrant society of outsiders.
What feels like meandering in the moment builds to a genuine emotional attachment to the characters.
It's the type of movie where nothing is as it appears, and even when it's all sorted out it's completely unsatisfying.
Writer-director Kevin Noland effectively utilizes his fine young cast and the natural beauty and rich culture of northern Spain in amiably posing a timeless question of youth.

Though his typically clueless on-screen persona learns very little about comedy or Muslims, Brooks the filmmaker makes the underlying point that true understanding is achieved through observation and empathy.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A first-rate contribution to the Holocaust canon.
A Good Woman won't ruin anyone's day, but it won't make anyone's either, and it won't get the great Irish playwright anything like the admiration his work deserves.
The campier aspects of the film are not enough to make up for its lapses into melodrama and just plain silliness.
The film's lack of depth as it oversimplifies the complexities of racism keep it from being anything other than a lightweight date movie.

The film's biggest accomplishment is that it is entertaining whether or not you know the outcome. Telfair's got the skills to play and market himself, and Through the Fire has enough game to make us care.
Richards mistakes boorishness for drama, and the seemingly tendentious desire to be off-putting succeeds all too well.

This family adventure about a team of sled dogs abandoned in Antarctica naturally invokes the traditional shout of 'Mush!' urging the canines to go faster, but it's also an apt descriptor of both its shameless sentimentality and ineptly structured story.
A movie-of-the-week treatment of race and class, the film credibly portrays the day-to-day workings of an urban ministry.
As good as the leads and the supporting cast are, and as much action as gets packed into the film's relatively brief running time, none of it draws us in dramatically.
The story that first-time feature filmmaker Curry tells is extremely compelling, but where he really scores is in addressing politics and race in a way that allows events to speak for themselves.
The entire film envelops you in an incredible array of fascinating sea life. The effect is continuous and so successful that you'll find yourself holding your breath.
The film's depiction of a defeated man summoning the moral courage to address his past is, satisfyingly, more '70s than '80s.
A film of great beauty with unfulfilled promise -- a disappointment, but with much to recommend and be glad about.

Devoid of cleverness or anything approaching reinvention, the film relies on special effects and its cast, human and animal, for its limited appeal. Hopefully, it will be limited enough to spare us Son of the Shaggy Dog.
A persuasive if not groundbreaking drama.
Despite a fine cast, the film feels as lost as Howard, unsure of its direction or tone.
The would-be psychological thriller devolves into a plodding domestic drama.
The film fails to establish Jones' significance to the band or why his death should be seen as anything other than just another rock 'n' roll casualty.
Slither is a gross, disgusting, but undeniably amusing treat laden with homages and in-jokes.
If seeing a guy get whacked in the privates doesn't make you laugh the first time, maybe it will the fourth, or the 24th time.
Even if you've never done a crossword in your life or been frustrated by the attempt, you will likely be drawn into this intriguing world through the enthusiasm expressed by its adherents.
The tension between his eagerness to please and his resolve to make the film inside his head have resulted, with Lady in the Water, in a major misfire.

Neither a comedy nor a drama but existing in that comfortable space in between, Catch and Release, the feature-directing debut of screenwriter Susannah Grant, is an oddly appealing, if innocuous, movie of considerable charm.
... it moves along with minimalist efficiency before running out of gas during an overlong allegorical final section.
Mr. Smith captures ground-level political machinations in an utterly fascinating way. The question raised by the title makes for an interesting, if possibly disheartening, debate.

Featuring a stalwart cast (many of whom appeared in Walker-Pearlman's 2000 drama, The Visit) and some delicately wrought moments, the film is unable to overcome its soap opera scenario and clunky pacing.
Lively, free-wheeling amusement.
movie_title: Once in a Lifetime: The Extraordinary Story of the New York Cosmos (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmaker's niftiest trick is in making a group of neurotic, self-involved, overly verbal people so engaging.
The film's pace is brisk enough to maintain our full attention. Antibodies is not so much an art house movie as a well-made, commercial thriller that happens to be in German.
Carrey has never looked so uncomfortable on-screen.

It follows the paradigm of inspirational movies so perfectly that even the smallest deviation seems rebellious. The movie's orthodoxy is precisely what allows us to take such pleasure in its irregularities.

The overall soundtrack seamlessly patches together a sonic quilt of eclectic music that evokes a kind of timeless flow. It's not a Glastonbury of any particular vintage, but rather a continuum of experiences that have occurred on this sacred ground.
Overlong and lacking dramatic focus, the film nevertheless captures the dark allure that the unsolved crimes had on the region over a 22-year period.

[Writer-director Craig Brewer] displays a real passion for the music and a knack for using it to create mood. But it's not enough to overcome the thinness of his characters or the greeting card sentiment that pulls the rug out from what came before.
A film that will catch you leaning in one direction and abruptly pull you in another, all the while building to a surprisingly emotional climax.
Scurlock does well to counter the more dire aspects of the film with a razor-sharp sense of humor.

Women don't come off terribly well in I Think I Love My Wife, writer-director Chris Rock's comedic 'update' of the 1972 Eric Rohmer drama, Chloe in the Afternoon. It's not so much misogynistic as it resembles a fossil from another era.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Its biggest failing - and the ultimate one for a lightweight entertainment such as this - is that it's a deadly bore from start to finish. Even more annoying is its blind-alley structure resulting in an unsatisfying mind game for the audience.
Tense and gut-wrenching, Beyond the Gates is a horrifying story told with grace and compassion.
Movies about male friendship are often trivialized with the 'buddy' tag, but this one resonates beyond that.
It is buoyed by some incisive acting and writing and anchored by a standout portrayal from Bauchau, a versatile veteran of international cinema.
The incessant reminders of the outcome, along with the liberal use of split screen, serve only to create a disconnect from what's on-screen.
Swank shows that in the right role her unusually disarming talent can elevate routine material.
The compelling documentary An Unreasonable Man carries the tag line, 'Ralph Nader: How do you define a legacy?' but it might just as easily have asked, 'Who gets to define the legacy?'
If the segments are uneven, Moncrieff -- with the help of her excellent cast -- nevertheless crafts a gripping overall narrative that exposes a shared dissonance among the protagonists.
Kids may grow up too fast today to embrace the film's familiar message of the virtues of an unhurried adolescence, but it's nice to be reminded of the possibility.
Most successful in capturing the emotional elements of its story, the film relies on its excellent cast to balance out sketchily drawn characters and the unfortunate obviousness of its plot.
Renaissance is a dark joy to inhabit once you jettison the idea of a satisfying narrative.
A brisk, superficial treatment of the tragic supernova life of Edie Sedgwick, Factory Girl disappoints as both biography and drama.
Entertaining enough but strictly in a wait-for-cable way.
Nobody Wants Your Film is both the cautionary tale implied by its title and an inspiring note from the indie underground.
It manages to be smart and surprising and provides this season of serious movies with a much-needed shot of whimsy.
It's minimalist cinema that turns on subtle emotion rather than narrative and demands the audience's full attention.
It's an ambitious film drenched in sincerity and oozing with nostalgia that, despite the energy provided by its title icon via archival footage, falls flat dramatically in nearly every other way.
The movie is a genial romp and because it relies on the gentlest of scatological comedy, it can be enjoyed by all ages.
The script, written by Black, Gass and director Liam Lynch, packs in gag after gag (and cameo after cameo), but there's not enough dramatic impetus to keep it from becoming a drag.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An ineffective would-be tear-jerker that proves the adage 'dying is easy, comedy is hard.'
... sublime psychological thriller ...
Chilling.
Off the Black is a modest, bittersweet character study that hits its mark.
The ads promise magic, but apart from the requisite heart-tugging finale, what it delivers is uneventful.
There are worse ways to spend the holidays, and, at the least, it will likely make you appreciate your own circumstances.
McConaughey's performance is oddly comic but actually serves to counter more traditional interpretations of a stoic coach leading his charges.
Cavemen and dinosaurs, cowboys and Roman soldiers, lions and zebras, all running amok, sounds like more fun than it is.
It's a classic family dilemma made fresh by the setting and the realistic circumstances.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Has the patience to glean real emotions from surreal situations and the intelligence not to offer up fake closure.
From exposition to denouement, Corky Romano is paint-by-numbers filmmaking of the highest (or lowest) order.
Percolates with neurotic insecurity, painful deceit, busted opportunity, and pervasive regret, but the movie never capsizes under its own weight.
Lifetime's Whitney Houston biopic was confusingly bland, and we're not happy about it.
Bridget Jones has grown up. We owe it to ourselves to grow up along with her.
[Rihanna] brings gusto, grit, and gravitas to a project that is otherwise a farce. She's wrings spitfire energy, regret, hope, and, ultimately, doom out of basically two scenes.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: What's so ambitious and ultimately so masterful about Dunkirk is that it is almost entirely an action sequence.
It is profound, peculiar, frustrating, frightening, transfixing, maddening, and, mostly, beautiful.
It is a slightly terrifying, slightly maddening shark movie. We will likely need a week or so before swimming in the ocean again, which is all we ever want from a shark movie!
It's certainly pleasant, and anyone who is a fan of his will chuckle their way through it. But it's unclear what we're being sold here.

Despite all the marketing focus on the homicidal circus freak, It was never about the clown. It's about how trauma haunts a childhood and how the latent ennui of small-town America can fan the flames of our greatest fears.
The 'female James Bond' label? [Charlize] Theron earns it, but she doesn't need it.
Is The Unauthorized Saved By the Bell Story the worst movie that has ever been made for television?
movie_title: The Unauthorized Saved by the Bell Story (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Few films know exactly what its audience wants from it as much as this sequel to the raunchy-schmaltzy Moms Go Wild (And Learn About Themselves in the Process) hit comedy from last summer.
Three Billboards says a lot about how we treat women who demand answers.
The film is positively invigorating, partly because of how it winks at the conversations happening in our country -- in newsrooms and beyond -- in its dialogue.

I, Tonya is one-of-a-kind and definitely rough around the edges, dressed up to awkwardly fit in with the more traditional award season contenders. There's all the ambition, progressiveness, and danger of the triple axel.
A Christmas Story is a cute, mildly amusing tale that, it turns out, becomes extremely grating once you add music. At least, once you add this music.

The uneven script and stilted dialogue is in such contrast to the stampede of rousing musical numbers that we wonder if the project would have fared better on the stage, where a weak book linking together standout music is arguably more forgivable.

[Three Identical Strangers] tickles at our obsession with triplets, the nature vs. nurture debate, and the idea of being separated at birth. But it infuses its story with a dark reality, too, sending a frigid chill up the spine.
As a crime-thriller, it's suitably nerve-wracking and ludicrous, while somehow still poignant and thoughtful.

It would be impossible to list the myriad tenets of the conversation surrounding abuse and victimhood that the film explores. We wouldn't purport to answer any of those questions, and maybe the film doesn't intend to either.
Give it up for the astutely ridiculous workplace satire that, when it comes to cinematic cajones, is nothing if not a horse of a different color.

There's something about Love, Simon that feels like a bona fide event...It's a film that we swooned and winced and cringed and grinned through, the journey the best coming-of-age movies take their audiences on.
The Oscars telecast, clocking in at four hours and 50 minutes, was chock-full of carefully-produced moments. Yet it couldn't live up to its own.
A visually dazzling, if tonally meandering odyssey that tempers its sci-fi gravitas with a child's sense of humor. It's the rare live-action family film to feel like a bonafide kids' movie.
Fuggetabout It, 'Analyze That' A Fitting Sequel
The Two Towers stands tall among year's best.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Marvel's 'DareDevil' falters, fails to meet high expectations
Visually stunning, 'Gangs' one of the year's hottest tickets. Scorsese's years of vision will become etched in our hearts and minds for all time.
Without the presence of Tautou, this would be a dry heritage pic; with her, it brews a sense of enigma that just about saves the day.
It carefully exceeds expectation, helped in no small measure by Langella's wily, wistful lead.
It lacks narrative momentum but not warm humour or extreme headstands: you won't need telling twice that certain moves are "definitely not for beginners".
Some metaphors score and some miss, but this is leap-of-faith cinema: the rewards entail some risks.
Intelligent, innovative and intimate sci-fi is always welcome, but Oblivion isn't quite it.
As a slice of rural Americana, Promised Land works. Then it turns into sticky apple pie, leaving only the feeling that you've been had.

MacDowell was never more convincing and Chris Elliott is a dry delight as her lens-man. Murray and movie, meanwhile, are a mutual godsend: Groundhog Day rescued his career from calcifying in self-caricature.
Meadows' loving report on a "live resurrection" is indeed alive and passionate, until too many gaps render it less than godlike.
movie_title: The Stone Roses: Made of Stone (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Saggy but also energised and endearing.
The drip-feed of old tricks and a slow-drifting camera combine to stoke our expectation.
Stories of humans raised in the wild range from Tarzan to Mama, but none compare to the resonance of Werner Herzog's 1974 film.
movie_title: The Enigma of Kaspar Hauser (Jeder für sich und Gott gegen alle)(Every Man for Himself and God Against All) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Al-Mansour carefully dodges easy uplift, but her message of hope to future generations of Saudi women is clear.
Like a more obvious underwater twist on Herzog's Grizzly Man ...
Starts with a bracingly stylised snarl and ends in a muddle.
Goro's expressive artistry is fleet, fluent and tenderly affecting. With a worthy story, he might breathe the old man's rarefied air yet.
City offers star power, dashes of dazzle and plenty of movie nods. But Hughes' thriller fails to locate a life of its own.
You pity the kids of the more Boss-obsessed but there's pomposity-pricking humour and uplift here, too.
The mid stretch drags, but by the time the LA crowd hurtle stage-wards for a bullish 'The Boy With The Thorn In His Side', a(nother) career resurrection seems within his reach.
Another Brit hit, plus Batmanglij is beginning to show dash as director. The duo make a tight fist of hot topicality and high tension from an ideas-packed genre piece.
Park Chan-wook brings operatic finesse to generic material in his tight-wound, wickedly weird US debut. And Mia Wasikowska nails it.
Choppy cuts muddy the narrative, but the faith in grassroots art's motivational value resonates clearly.
The directors' affecting yet non-sentimental verité approach suits the raw material, spurning 'expert' talking head commentary and letting the band speak (and scream) for themselves.

A sense-scrambling work that conjures images of indelible potency: you won't forget the dissection, the lyrical love scene, the pitiable homunculus, the chilling trek to hell or Adasinsky naked in a hurry.
Fleet, funny, impeccably orchestrated: whimsical Wes returns on top of his game.
The cast cut into the tough truths of late-life relations. The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel it ain't.
The leads charm, the action crackles and the grooves are well-laid for part two.
You'll cry a bit come the tense, touching climax - then punch the air with joy.
The value of small things is tenderly endorsed in this miniaturist French cousin of Alice In Wonderland and Moonrise Kingdom.
movie_title: À pas de loup (On the Sly) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Jonathan Cenzual Burley serves promising magic-realist fruit from meagre means in his debut.
movie_title: El alma de las moscas (The Soul of Flies) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Some strained metaphors and character tics aside, this proves both Polley's perceptive eye and Williams' ability to explore life-scuffed emotions. Wry, risqué and real.
JGL's enjoyment in his job adds welcome levels of Levitt-y.
You'll be in bits, but your critical faculties might weep too.
Burton's finest, freshest film in ages is a welcome homecoming. You'd call it patchwork pastiche, if it weren't so zapped with energy, feeling and imagination. It's alive!
Ascher's hugely enjoyable docu-collage of Shining theories embraces ambiguity but proves that Kubrick's deep chiller is worth the revisits.
Its artful ambiguities are immersive. Check in.
Lowery's understated authority lifts his tragic romance above mere Malick mimicry, while Affleck and Mara bring heart to the scrupulous artistry.
A taut, teasing study in sense and susceptibility, given ballast by a suitably shaken and shell-shocked lead turn from Mikkelsen.
If this is raging against the dying of the light, long may he rage.

Marshalling formidable technique and force of feeling, Bayona's tale of courage and empathy in the face of catastrophe fulfils his debut's promise, its harrowing conviction hammered home even harder by the spot-on casting.
Although detractors might wish for something more profound, capturing the poignant pointlessness of life passing by feels like a noble pursuit in itself.
The plot meanders but Koreeda's hand is deceptively sure: the detours all add up in a climactic montage of gentle, effortless poignancy.
Rigorously exposing systemic corruption and collusion, Gibney traces the problem to the top, detailing how the Vatican closed ranks to protect itself.
movie_title: Mea Maxima Culpa: Silence In The House Of God (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Splashes of overstatement aside, the ambition intoxicates.
Sex, drugs, murder, radical verse and Radcliffe make persuasive bedfellows in Krokidas' live-wire lit-pic.
Debut director Nathan Todd's intermittently convincing reflection on the Troubles.
The talking-heads inserts distract but the end result is a fresh nostalgia trip and - thanks to those pioneering dad-dancing moves - a winning arena-show snapshot.

Soloway spikes the clichés with refreshingly rude humour, steadily darkens the mood and gets gold from her lead: her face a rubbery miracle of expressive range, Hahn laces every dramatic/comic beat with the zing and sting of truth.
Fans of indie cinema's mood-movie fringes, check in.
Bandele's keen handling of cast and domestic conflict makes for a nuanced historical epic, but he's less sure on the big stuff ...
Hogg's third film mounts a dead-on study of disconnection.
From the texture of the underground havens to the idea that our leads have to - literally - cling to each other lest gravity tears them apart, it's a wonder of detail and ingenuity.
The regional stereotypes in Dale Launer's broad script aren't so laudable, but the on-screen talent merits a retrial: Tomei talks up a storm and Pesci terrorises thinly spread gags into near-shape.
Laced with poignancy and portent, Miyazaki's epic is an elegy for lost dreams - and a farewell befitting an animation master.
The violence hits you like a shovel to the head, but the political rage stings hardest.
With style, heart and thrills, Singer has nailed the most ambitious X-flick yet. Popcorn pizzazz combines with X2's emotional sweep and something extra: a platform for the X-Men's screen survival.
Hanna's fearless voice still commands attention.
[A] promising but patchy provocation.
An earthy, affecting and droll celebration of the unique alignment of influences that forged a great band - and the thrusting live footage rams Pulp's greatness home.
movie_title: Pulp: a Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets (2014)

movie_review_blurb: What emerges is a demanding but hypnotic, probing portrait of an artist denied her art, by a director in total command of his.
Goodison's ace is his cast: when he just lets us watch them, their natural warmth provides all the conviction needed.
An affecting, hilarious portrait of chalk/cheese sibling love, with a sweet twist: Tom thinks he's a loser, but his film is a winning one-off.
Quemada-Díez doesn't play soft, and the stinging climax really sticks with you.
movie_title: The Golden Dream (La Jaula De Oro) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The gentle lightning of Once doesn't strike twice for Carney, but his latest music movie has charm beneath its slick surface - and Knightley and Ruffalo harmonise just fine.
Between Maguire's winning lead and the lively portraits of workmates on the lash, there's a sitcom in the making here.
Likeable casting can't quite salvage director John Hardwick's threadbare British pop comedy, under-developed from a web series.
Where's Xander Cage when you need him?
The details ring true and the performances smart in Mackenzie's prison movie.
Sun, sex, psychosis, skinny-dipping: it sounds like genre tat, but Guiraudie's dark, droll study of a risky attraction upends expectations. It plays by stealth, but its sly grip is sure.
Kieran Evans' adaptation of Niall Griffiths' rough-hewn novel mixes unsafe S&M with social desolation to choppy effect.
The casual plotting leaves loose ends, but Hong's rhyming rhythms take up some of the slack.
movie_title: Nugu-ui ttal-do anin Haewon (Nobody's Daughter Hae-Won) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: With no real plot to bind them, the pile-up of chaotic chases, repeat-on you leek puns and noisy dust-ups gradually kills the appetite.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The fact that Lebanon had a space programme is just one of the surprises in Khalil Joreige and Joana Hadjithomas' fascinating dispatch from the "who knew?" fringes of docu-making.
The lead character's called Grace, but don't be put off: Cretton's tough-love snapshot of shattered youth is achingly moving rather than manipulative or mawkish.
Every second is earned in Macdonald's long, generous and rigorously detailed Bob doc.
B's mix of talking heads and reportage is a bit bland for the material, but the extravagant showpieces hoist up the slack.
Redemption beckons for Alfa's titular lead but the flat finale can't save the film.
A warm, watchful slant on marital mores in an ultraorthodox Jewish community.

Bigger and broader than before, Ron's return occasionally feels like autocue'd sequel-making. But it spikes old news with enough fresh comic zip to keep you hooked through the self-indulgent stretches.
With no 3D, no friends and no hope, Redford and Chandor show how survivalist instincts can stoke thrilling, thoughtful cinema.
By using the tangible magic of hands through walls, moving statues, steamy paws and the rest, Cocteau makes rapt believers of us all - adults and children alike.
movie_title: Beauty and The Beast (La Belle et la bête) (1946)

movie_review_blurb: First it's a family-tree detective story, then a playful meta-movie, then a maternal melodrama. and along the way, it weaves strong feelings into a dissection of storytelling and truth.
Deploys talking heads, dreamy animations and lyrical music to trace the arc of Boyd's life and mount a poetic, poignant tribute to the seductive mystique of a rarefied craft.
The semi-improvised plot is thinner than Cera's man-boy face-fluff, but Silva's curio works best as a free-wheeling character piece, splicing oddball comedy with discreet depths.
The ending stumbles, but not enough to tarnish this study of life lived under society's radar.
A master docu-maker gets the inside dope on a master dissembler. It requires stamina, but its charismatic subject exerts genuine magnetism.
The direction pummels and the cast impress, yet Berg's war movie promises more than it delivers.
Self-indulgent? To a point. But Jarmusch makes seductive work of it: the deep, dusty images, the hypnotic pacing.

The plotting is elliptical and the sweep intoxicates, but the contrast between De Niro's meditative Vito and Pacino's soul-starved eyes brings piercing focus to Coppola's resonating study of corrupting power.
Herzog's tapestry testifies to life's light from death's darkness.
Generous tides of life and longing flow through this buoyant masterpiece.
What a trip.
Azazel Jacobs' lo-fi indie comedy unfolds slowly but with patient precision.

Gooey tunes and rampant primary colours can't scupper the slick yet guileless crowdpleasing of Jamie J Johnson's debut doc. We might giggle and gag on the garish Euro-pop, but Johnson gets us on-side with winning, grinning empathy.
Sin, sexual abuse, erotic salvation... Director Maeve Murphy's thick stew is worthy but heavy like a sledgehammer.
Ernest Lehman's cheeky script, Bernard Herrmann's score and several sizzling set-pieces deliver a rush of pure joy.
Clumsily plotted and psychologically messy as it is, Moran's pop biopic is a ripe bustle of business, given substance and conviction by well-rooted performances.
There's nothing dry about this study in tradition: Schwietert stresses the freedom and spontaneity in avant yelping, qualities his lead trio embrace with palpable passion.
Fans of speculative and conceptual sci-fi and classic storytelling should take this trip to identity's dark side. The direction is elegant, the acting impeccable. Take the trip.
Cookie-cutter characterisations, homily-heavy script and over-reliance on maudlin musical prompts are all too chocky-box icky in their own right.
As cold as a corpse, as warm as love and thick with shady business in between, Alfredson's chiller is moving and nerve-jangling. A vampire movie to nourish the heart, mind and fear glands.
Your eyeballs will relish Almodóvar's movie-movie cocktail, but it'd be nice to see him serve up some fresh flavours. Despite the tactile direction, there isn't enough to resonate post-film.
Gilliam's plotting is typically ramshackle, but the fantasy visions are wondrous. Top job of rescuing Heath Ledger's cruelly curtailed contribution, too.
Yi is a unique tour guide, her deadpan demeanour, embarrassed giggle and horn-rimmed specs generating non-starry appeal.
Glug a pint of seasonal spirit before watching Debbie Isitt's mish-mash of show-must-goon generics, bittersweet Brit-comedy realism and Hollywood endings.
Part tastefully muted, part plain morose, Keaton's direction styles this as a character study of hearts in winter. But it doesn't wash.
Jarmusch's film captivates stylistically, and at least some credit's due to his less-is-more plotting. But extensive introversion leaves it gasping for air, almost vanishing up itself.
As brazen as you'd expect from a film with a name that recalls an arthouse tentpole, this debut from writer-director-star Yang Ik-Joon is tonally, one-of-a-kind odd-couple movie.
Pandorum director Alvart summons some scares here: Ferland is persuasively weird and hornets are utilised to skin-crawling effect. Most of his ideas are second-hand, though.
Rohm brings subtlety to her role but Edgar's paranoia dominates, giving the hammy Huston too much room to over-cook this thin tragedy.
After two hours in the dark with this loud but hollow hybrid, you'll know "space madness". In a good year for smart sci-fi, Pandorum lumbers and groans.
It's streetwise stuff, shot in a vigorous on-the-hoof style, but also full of joy, both in its blissfully comic moments and in Doinel's telling passion for moviegoing.
Intimacy, nuance and emotional punch are conspicuous only by their absence. Dreary.
Curtis hangs situation and character comedy on a homage to rock'n'roll. That would be fine if it were funny, but auto-pilot Curtis prevails.
Both a homage and utterly distinct, Haynes's comeback film plays havoc with your emotions even as you marvel at its ravishing artistry. There are flashier films around, but few as accomplished.
Too slight to really haunt, but its subtlety is as treasurable as an old friend.
The proof of the pig is in the pounding: it sounds good.
The Falling Down-meets-After Hours pitch and plum cast (William H Macy, Rebecca Pidgeon, Bai Ling, Mena Suvari) look tempting, but it's not a stretch to see why it's sat on the shelf for two years.
Thank heavens for Hoskins, Manville and Channing, whose weathered sparkle is enough to satisfy none-too-demanding rom-com requirements.
Everyone involved takes this tat seriously except William Hurt, who goes gung-ho as the alter-ego goading Brooks' kill frenzies. If only they'd cut out the middle-Kev and cast Hurt instead...
The old gender-tussle tune is played lightly and wittily, with a streak of mischief peppering any risk of schmaltz.

Lee's saucy, sumptuous slow-burner is a complex, elegant seduction, drawing on Hitchcock but putting a singular stamp on a rich spread of spies and sex, repression and sacrifice. Just don't try those moves at home...

As a comedy of male delusion, Night seems to shrink from its flimsy dramatic subtexts; as a probing of dream and reality in love, its pretensions to depth suggest a neutered comedic courage: Woody Allen-lite.
Granted, Philibert's free-roaming approach is as languid as a weekend ramble. But his warm, tender, patient film finds much to move and chew on in the mulch and mire of rustic matters.

Away from home, Wong is on far-from-vintage form. But he still speaks the seductive language of longing with tactile tenderness, and draws out a natural performance from Jones. Worth a look, if not quite one to fall for.

But some are capable of articulacy and Bertoglio provides the odd ghostly image: primarily, middle-aged fashionista Wendy Whitelaw, who sprays her suburban lawn in regulation Factory chic. The happy ending is welcome, too.
His account of Anderson's demise moves, but by then, this arch-raconteur's bluster may have sand-papered your patience.
movie_title: Never Apologize: A Personal Visit With Lindsay Anderson (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Even sword-slashes "sigh like a breeze". Martial arts fans might gag but Wong fans who were disappointed by My Blueberry Nights should see this. It's the look of lush.

Frustratingly, there is potential in Watkins' claustrophobic, back-to-nature setting, but, in trying to play 'edgy' with contemporary anxieties, his cooked-to-formula script merely sinks to the level of the gutter press exploiting those fears.
A stonking lead performance from Kristin Scott Thomas ferries Philippe Claudel's directorial debut over its forced twists.
Fluffed satirical targets, a shortfall of required rom-com charm, cheap gags and a thoroughly unpleasant 'hero' situate How To Lose Friends several floors below the desired Apartment-esque heights.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: DiCaprio and Winslet channel much nuance into their home-based hell. Mendes' level-headed helming is best at pinpointing the brutality of banality, while Roger Deakins' lush cinematography stylises suburbia as a lavish velvet coffin for its residents.
A touching, gripping tale of friendship and forever-young fantasy in failure's frontline.
A promising young writer/director team show signs of strain on their feature debut, juggling too many flavours at once.
Pitched somewhere between Lars Von Trier and The Village, Giorgos Lanthimos' dark, deadpan comedy is a coolly cruel dissection of power gone crackers.

Part painfully funny, part just painful and soul-searching, Solondz's sixth feature is a sequel played as self-interrogation, tackling old terrain with the benefit of hindsight and the sure sting of conviction.
Little narration is needed: sweeping shots of the truly overwhelming natural terrain are as awesome as anything in Avatar.
movie_title: Petropolis: Aerial Perspectives on the Alberta Tar Sands (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Half engrossing, half just gross, Kim's revenge epic is all form over content. The style dazzles, but just think what he could do with a decent script.
Carion delivers a tight, tense and tragic package of the personal and political entwined, with Kusturica's huge presence at its soul.
Exuberantly uses dance to flex 3D's potential and 3D to make dance thrill cinematically.
If The Wire's urban tapestries were real, they might look like this.
The leads gurn gamely, Ben Batt's villain oozes menace and Golden directs energetically, but the climactic twists are as convincing as pills made of washing powder.
A familiar tale lent richness by note-perfect turns and stealthy storytelling.
A bristling breakout turn leavens tired material in Niall MacCormick's coming-of-anger.
Like most mix-tapes, offers crackling content even when its contexts aren't clear.
An ensemble piece wobbling between undercooked drama and low-powered farce...
July's romantic fantasy of stagnation and romantic drift has depths, but they're hidden behind walls of kookiness.
The film doesn't go deep on politics, but Logan's gregarious presence provides plentiful pleasures in this heartfelt homage to a warm, wily art-world one-off.
movie_title: The British Guide To Showing Off (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There's something satisfyingly jolting about the way Arnold makes Brontë her own.
A touching tribute interweaves with tough storytelling in Eric Khoo's poignant portmanteau riff on Japanese graphic artist Yoshihiro Tatsumi's works.
Hard, fast, brutal: Soderbergh's sucker-punch return to action knows what it's about. Not subtle or substantial, but it gets to work with flab-free focus.
While hardly searching, Barker's portrait is infectiously affectionate.
movie_title: Rock and Roll's Greatest Failure: Otway the Movie (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The talky emphasis may alienate, but Cronenberg's psychoanalysis session offers wry writing, elegant direction and fine leads.
It isn't wholly original but it does brim with emotion, imagination and modern implication. Take that, Bats.
Some fantasy interludes prove distracting but the ecstatic experience of the Chems' psychedelic spectacle is brought to thrilling life by Smith's fluid, fizzing direction.
At the heart of this art is the thrill of the then-new: when Pinocchio hits sea-base and gushes "Gee! What a big place!", we share a sense of joy at the filmmakers' creative adventures.
Too thin to pass as provocation or drama.
The script needs more nurturing but Noomi Rapace takes up some of the slack in Pal Sletaune's maternal mystery.
Gallows humour and character twists offer welcome reprieve from the largely hysterical acting and rivers of viscera.
Heartening as small acts are, the bigger issues here demand a more rigorous address.
Taking a cold, cruel plunge into its sociopath's world, Winterbottom's latest genre swerve is an accomplished neo-noir.
Exploring class, generations and misbehaving bodies, Holofcener's dramedy refines its character studies with warmth and wit as she creates warts-and-all individuals whose flawed humanity we warm to.
This is a fan's film, with all the flaws that entails, but doubters might emerge converted.

Emphatic confirmation that Denis is one of the world's finest filmmakers. Equal parts terrifying and tense, punchy and ambiguous, direct and disorientating, White Material marshals its resources with great intelligence and visceral clout.
Imagine a less upbeat Taxi Driver remixed mumblecore style.
At last, a possession movie for lapsed horror acolytes to believe in.
Rooting awkward chuckles in freaky family ties, the Duplasses then spin our sniggers by planting parallels between John and Cyrus. Just who's the biggest man-child?
Alongside The Haunting, Jack Clayton's 1961 adaptation of Henry James' The Turn Of The Screw is the pinnacle of corner-of-the-screen scares.
Easy to eulogise but tough to explain. Funny strange, funny ha-ha and finally affecting, it's a film of poignant, quietly patient power...
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Both warm and chilly on top, Helander's well-mounted black comedy puts a devilish spin on movie Santas.
Amalric doesn't tease out emotional ties between the narrative threads, which scuppers the faux-redemptive finale and results in a film of merely incidental pleasures.
Leave sick bags, bring hankies. Without softening the gruelling content, Boyle draws affecting and affirmative power from Ralston's story.
Bruno Forzani and Hélène Cattet's baroque Belgian beauty pays homage to '70s Italian horror but brims with its own sexualised currents of threat and promise.
Excesses aside, Iñárritu's fresh focus and tactile direction pack a palpable punch here.
With only his silver-fox thatch betraying the years since classic Stop Making Sense, Byrne wriggles and writhes through a groovy set of polyrhythmic pop.
Cinephiles will lap it up.
Fondly indulgent rather than inspired, breezy but broad and indicative of treasured talents coasting.
It plays by the noir book, but Michôd's wallop from the wild side wields a tight grip of sure styling, taut plotting and poised performances.
As conviction slowly croaks, pop star Duffy's cameo drives one last nail into the film's coffin.
Gustavo Hernández's one-take Uruguayan horror is daring and technically well-executed, but its plot clichés creak like old floorboards.
Martin turns a cautionary tale into rollercoaster material: with extraordinary home-video footage capturing the Pappas' rise and fall with an immediacy that leaves you stirred, shaken and moved.

Blending the mythical resonances of The Searchers with lyricism and bristly realism, Wolfe's harrowing, haunting dispatch from Brit-cinema's undergrowth is strong meat: emphatic evidence of a bold talent's arrival.
Welles' dazzling direction more than makes up for any lack of viewer understanding.

Using archival interviews to show how enviro-concerns and oppositional thinking drove them, Crump sometimes moves too briskly, but the awe-inspiring imagery speaks volumes: this big-thinking art demands big-screen respect.
movie_title: Troublemakers: The Story of Land Art (2016)

movie_review_blurb: he tension between oppression and youth is so beautifully played (Günes Sensoy stands out) and poised -- dodgy voiceover aside -- the final glimmer of hope makes you want to punch the air.
Steggall indulges watery metaphors, but draws emotive work from Stevenson and pinpoints the uncertainty of life's tipping points.
The director's early days are thoroughly detailed here; if his later career is rushed over, an impressive trawl of talking heads (Gabriel Byrne, Cillian Murphy) keeps thing lively.
movie_title: Versus: The Life and Films of Ken Loach (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This rare gem is ripe for rediscovery.
Amponsah's lines of inquiry could be sharper, but he successfully humanises the people behind the headlines.
Writer/director Pierre Godeau proves hotter on context than character. The result's non-judgemental but emotionally parched.
You'd call it offensive if the faux-deep dialogue and karaoke-singing gynaecologists were not merely ludicrous.
A film too stiff for comedy, too silly for drama and too slow for fun in between.
Sollima interweaves gangsters, pimps, junkies and scary dogs with pungent echoes of venal Ancient Rome.
Sensitively directed and subtly acted, this modestly radical romance is a soft-spoken beauty.
Horror's maternity ward births a treat. The story's sketchy, but satire's alive and the ending's a scream.
Keaton sells the crap out of Kroc's filet-o-fishy business, but sauce overrides substance: it needed tougher meat.
Taken as a hearty blast of indie-rock nostalgia, Lost in France is a joy. But its industry-wise ruminations speak no less loudly to today, and to a sense of what music may have lost.
Aiming straight for mounting dread, Parker gets the job done aggressively. Chances of him resurfacing with bigger projects look solid.
A Silent Voice makes beautiful, affecting work of teenage emotional turmoil.
A genre-blender imbued with style and substance. Magnetic and elusive, Stewart matches her director.
That lost village isn't the only thing that goes astray in the ungainly return of Belgian artist Peyo's little blue critters.
A godsend as Gibson's peaceable pilgrim, Garfield imbues Doss' gangly mannerisms and corn-fed dialogue with a winning mix of Gump-speak sweetness and self-certainty.
Travelling from gated communities to Glasgow, Round earns the trust of KFC employees, Wall Street wonders and more to show how we have been "submerged" in our financial lives.
Even when he lapses into whimsy, Cousins' approach summons a portrait of great colour, complexity and originality.
The twists are guessable, but Bryn makes seductive work of the route there, every candle-lit corridor and harrowed tree holding our gaze.
Numan emerges as an unlikely star from his guide to a rock life, and more likeable for it.
movie_title: Gary Numan: Android in La La Land (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Messier than a raging kegger, but game leads and a high gag-count keep the comedy-sequel comedown at bay. Just.
Cox doesn't just plot an obvious decline: things do get grim, but he makes you care as you also despair for punk's cracked casualties.
The expressive authority of Kubrick's direction is breathtaking.
There's plenty to commend it, not least the magnetic Alfredo Castro as Armando.
Between the thrilling concert footage, what emerges is a pungent time capsule of a forgotten fringe of America, ripe for rediscovery.
movie_title: A Poem Is A Naked Person (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Dagg keeps things simple, but his jogging camera whips up the urgency and he's well-served by Sutherland's rangy physicality.
Too daft for drama and too solemn for satire. Merely lost.
The Morrises clear-sighted thrust upholds the power, punch and potential of an honourable, determined press.
movie_title: Attacking The Devil: Harold Evans And The Last Nazi War Crime (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The result veers closer to arty film noir than reportage: a stylised love letter to the city, memory and objects, charged with fading but potent feeling.
A feelgood film buzzing with the positive vibrations its subject aims to share.
Despite some loose ends, Guadagninos melodrama drips with mood and boasts a runaway lead in Fiennes: his bum-bared makeover is a bells-on blast. Swinton shimmers, too.
Will Smith shows measured charisma, but Peter Landesmans awards-season drama is too formula-baked to generate the required head of steam.
The ravenous locals don't speak volumes for Roth's cultural sensitivity, but little here speaks much for his abilities.
Over a series of little intimacies Haleys steady hand balances the weight of lifes sorrows with generosity, wit and warmth: especially when the titles meaning becomes tenderly clear.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Von Horn plots cause and consequence with patient precision: his tale of crime, culpability and rough justice leaves a more lingering impression for it.
The ending turns soggy. But until then it passes the time divertingly enough.
Immaculately composed in loving widescreen, the portrait of the gypsy camps brims with life.
Lie Laas' furrowed lead and Nørgaard's taut orchestration of flashback-pumped plotting help flesh out old clichés - at least until the climax takes a glum turn for the overwrought.
With the scares stealthy, Gavin's parable draws power from the heart's shadows: the climax may alienate some, but its audacity is earned.
Alluring and unnerving, Lynch's horror-show reminds us how much cinema misses him. Watts is electric, too.
Iggy Pop's droll cameo and the Mods' affable humour make a thrillingly unlikely success story more appealing still.
