movie_title: In the Realm of the Senses (1976)

movie_review_blurb: For, in short, in its gutsy, bare-bones beauty, The Hurt Locker is not simply a war movie. It is war poetry.

Despite the saccharine trailer and the icky tear-jerking pedigree, The Time Traveler's Wife is actually a movie of some substance. it is the film about disconnected love that The Curious Case of Benjamin Button should have been.
For all its formal élan and gritty location shooting, Sin Nombre is a wearily hollow, morally specious movie.
A whodunnit set on a scientific research base in Antarctica that slowly becomes a "Who cares?"
A comprehensive documentary portrait of the controversial photographer Robert Mapplethorpe that is hugely compelling throughout.
A vapid and misogynistic Japanese sex-dramedy. Idiotic.
movie_title: Lala Pipo: A Lot of People (Lalapipo) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Mustang is incendiary and intimate, enraging and sweet.
It features lots of walking and talking and drinking, and occasional screechy rock interludes. Like a Richard Linklater movie, in other words. Only less fun.
movie_title: The Night Is Short, Walk On Girl (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Audacious, intriguing and also strangely sweet.

A flinty central turn from Brie Larson and a gregarious yet nonetheless repellent Woody Harrelson are the cornerstones of a family drama about alcoholism and parental abuse that refuses to rest on easy platitudes and psychological certainties.

It features impeccable performances from a cast led by Carey Mulligan, Garrett Hedlund and Mary J Blige, and attempts, unashamedly, to ask enormous, difficult and quintessential questions about the nature of -- yes, believe it -- the American soul.

A foolish, creatively fatal miscalculation sits at the heart of this south London relationship drama. It's a movie that expects you to love the central character for no obvious reason other than he's the central character.
It's a whopper of a performance from Garfield, and one that moves deftly through gradations of acceptance and hidden agonies.
This film is stop-and-point stunning. It is not without problems, however.
A bafflingly poor French comedy, Le Correspondant is aiming for Hollywood studio gloss, but misfires spectacularly on every level.
[A] robust film of serious ideas and unexpected ambition.
Crikey! We've barely forgotten the recent Australian serial-killer drama Wolf Creek and now here we are again.
Finally, after the abysmal The Dark Tower and the overhyped It, we have a Stephen King adaptation that's worthy of the brand.
Hard not to like, but difficult to love.
An exploitation western that veers from self-importance to high camp,
It's a haunting film, with the blood, the dreams and the deer, but never wilfully obscure. Just slightly off kilter. Like life.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Tennis in movies doesn't work. We know that.
[Almost Heaven] feels as if it should be much more profound than it is.
It's great fun, with a powerful sense of narrative.
For the most part, the results are pleasing and unexpectedly thoughtful.

Finally, a tennis movie that works. After the disappointing Borg vs McEnroe, we get another high-profile tennis film about a clash of personalities, only this one is defined by thrills, heartache, politics and passion.
It's confused. It's clichéd. It's dated, dubious and unintentionally silly.
There are some lovely observations from the directors Neasa Ni Chianáin and David Rane, especially the scenes of music lessons.
... cringeworthy fluff piece...
Leaving aside the dubious notion of boosting your self-worth by taking your clothes off in front of strangers, the film just isn't very funny -- or romantic.
It's deeply derivative, but relatively inoffensive. Young kids will love it.
The film... lurches wildly between respectful adaptation and clueless remake.

The infamous shower scene in Alfred Hitchcock's Psycho gets taken apart, fabulously dissected, then reassembled for this expansive and essential Hollywood documentary named after the scene's 78 camera set-ups and 52 edits.
For the uninitiated, the viewing experience will be incredibly vague, devoid of backstory, context, history or canonical importance.

The film is directed with profligate pizzazz by iconoclastic New Zealander Taika Waititi who seems to hold two fingers up to the entire Marvel Cinematic Universe, even as he caresses it with delicate affection.
Strikingly original.
The performances are careworn and convincing, and the film is never less than compelling.
This gorgeous nature documentary megamix, with sequences liberally culled from last year's BBC Planet Earth II series, rightfully earns its place on the big screen.
The whole thing is basically Gossip Girl as seen through the lens of Nietzsche's theory of eternal recurrence, only not as fun as that sounds.
Powerful film-making, executed with subtle style.
... punchy, raucous, savagely smart screen comedy...
Difficult, provocative, and consistently amusing. Almost perfect.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are scenes where Scott Thomas plays several competing emotions simultaneously, often through grimaces alone, but with masterful aplomb. What do we want? More Scott Thomas comedies! Now!

Gasp as The Starry Night swirls and moves. Swoon as the Café Terrace at Night bubbles into life. And be only mildly interested as the Polish animator Dorota Kobiela tries to concoct a narrative to justify all the bravura stylism.
By turns gorgeously toxic and deliciously feral, the sheer intensity of emotional aggression in this, Noah Baumbach's best feature to date, can be almost overwhelming.
It manages to hit the appropriate beats of this snowbound survival tale (digs ice shelters, scares off wolves, drinks meltwater) while also being incredibly dull.
This is either one brilliant satirical commentary on traditional racial stereotypes in Hollywood movies or it's not.
It might just be the quirkiest, most quintessentially British film phenomenon of the decade.
Your enjoyment will be in direct proportion to how much you appreciate seemingly endless amounts of quality tango. Me, not so much.
Vaughn's new movie, Kingsman: The Golden Circle, is, in short, the end of the road. The dream is over. The film is appalling.
A movie that replicates, step by formulaic step, the familiar and now oddly dated template of the inter-racial buddy movies of the Eighties (think 48 Hours or Lethal Weapon).

The debut feature from the Venezuelan director Jorge Thielen Armand, La Soledad is remarkably assured, even as it blurs the lines between fiction and reality by casting real people in not-so-real situations.

A ten-year labour of love, culled from more than 300 hours of intimate observational footage, Quest is a documentary with a seemingly banal remit but it bristles with cinematic urgency and dramatic power.
Profoundly silly teenage romance gets a begrudging nod of respect for a final-reel twist that nobody will see coming.
Eight volumes, more than 4,000 pages, and a multitude of exotic settings and alternative realities entered by two near-mythic antagonists, are here transformed into turgid cinematic slop.
Much of the film is stunning.
A genuinely gorgeous and quietly upsetting fantasy drama.
Step is a superlative entrant into the particular modern genre of film-making known as: "Tear-jerking and life-affirming documentary..."
This should be arresting. It should be gripping, complicated, provocative and difficult.
The fourth, and strongest, film in the Conjuring franchise, Annabelle: Creation is an exercise in pitch-perfect, nerve-jangling, modern horror film-making.
Bonkers in all the wrong ways.
Derivative, head-wrecking, synapse-splitting tedium.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: What Theron sells superbly, as she did in Mad Max: Fury Road in 2015, is, simply, ferocity.
Denmark's so-called biggest war crime forms the historical backdrop of this nerve-jangling bomb-disposal drama
A trivial Super Size Me-style premise (take performance-enhancing drugs on camera and see if they work!) becomes something far deeper in this thrilling anti-doping documentary from Bryan Fogel.
You don't have to possess an obsessive knowledge of the early life, musical influences and chart hits of the Mancunian pop icon Morrissey to appreciate England is Mine. But it helps.
A perfect storm of talent collides to create one of cinema's great doomed love dramas.
This is an alarmingly trivial film that is also, allegedly, a commentary on the July 2012 mass shooting at a Colorado multiplex showing The Dark Knight Rises.
A chilling idea and an interesting central performance are undercut by pretty much everything else in this apocalyptic action film about a second American Civil War.
He's back! Let the bells ring out, let the choirs of angels sing! Tom Cruise has once again, to the surprise of many, given a great performance.

A dextrous Indian drama set in a hostel for the dying on the banks of the Ganges, replete with wry humour, cheeky visual gags and an obsession with the paradox of celebrating life on the edge of death.

Guilty-pleasure holiday porn at its best, 7 Days is a romance that takes place entirely on the tiny, sun-bleached Mediterranean island of Levanzo. What? Is that not enough? Obviously, there's a plot too.
Angelina Jolie comes of age as a director with this relentlessly tense, often harrowing and hugely accomplished account of life under the Khmer Rouge during the Cambodian genocide of the 1970s.
Initially intriguing, but eventually wearisome.
This is profoundly silly Christian recruitment propaganda masquerading as newsroom drama.
A propulsive, wildly entertaining and hyperkinetic action flick.
This is essential viewing for cinephiles and Francophiles alike, but others may find the three-hour-plus running time a little excessive.
movie_title: My Journey Through French Cinema (Voyage À Travers Le Cinéma Français) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating premise, some quirky characters and ravishing landscape cinematography eventually dwindle into nothing in this only fitfully interesting documentary.
This sweet and upbeat French drama might as well have been called Teachers Are Awesome.

Flirting with pretension and needless structural chicanery, this vibrant portrait of Cairo on the cusp of the Arab Spring is saved by the director's obvious affection for the city, and by the eerie sense of visiting a now-vanished place.
movie_title: In the Last Days of the City (Akher ayam el madina) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Tedious and ultra-violent.
First-world problems and phony psychodrama form the basis of Darren Aronofsky's Mother!, a self-important bum-numbing film masquerading as high-class horror.
It, unfortunately, is loaded with superfluous screams. The effect is akin to having someone poking you in the ribs, relentlessly, and shouting: "Scary, isn't it? Scary! Right!?"

George Clooney directs Matt Damon from a Coen Brothers script. Brilliant, right? How could they go wrong? Well, if nobody involved in the creation of Suburbicon went terribly, egregiously, wrong, they didn't quite go right either.
The pinnacle of McDonagh's directorial career so far.
The results are understated, often amusing and occasionally profound.
God save Dame Judi Dench. The one-woman powerhouse has, at 82 years of age, given a career-high turn in Victoria and Abdul.

Yes, it features a stand-out, possibly even award-worthy, central turn from the newcomer Danielle Macdonald, but the film's most notable feature is its descent from gritty set-up into cringeworthy cliché.
A sci-fi comedy satire that purports to be about environmentalism and the end of the American consumer dream, but is actually about something much more intimate, and simultaneously more expansive.
[A] riveting prison documentary.
Sliding Doors and Groundhog Day are shoehorned into a dubious teen comedy...
movie_title: Fireworks, Should We See It from the Side or the Bottom? (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A heroic, award-winning central performance from the Congolese actress Véro Tshanda Beya Mputu is reason alone to see this often gripping, occasionally infuriating French-language melodrama.
A must-see for anyone craving a refresher course in Troubles history.
Zvyagintsev has said that the movie is a criticism of Putin's Russia, and of a materialistic society that has cut itself free from caring, but it works as straight drama too.
Kumar is such an amiable lead, and the feminist credentials of his real-life counterpart so rock-solid, that the movie rises above its limitations.
How they got the Donald Crowhurst story wrong is its own minor tragedy.
It is, in the light of the 87-year-old's monumental career, simply the worst thing he has done (and that includes those godawful orangutan movies).

The director Ryan Coogler and a charismatic cast... turn racial clichés on their head and drag in some heavy Shakespearean conflict to create a vivid yarn that's entirely new, frequently startling and, at every step along the way, all Marvel.
It's just awful.
The film is a mess.

Lethal Weapon meets Heat meets an unintentional Tropic Thunder-style parody in a straight-faced cop movie that begins with fabulous verve and energy before descending into giggle-inducing macho clichés.
The results are entertaining and watchable, but always slightly, oddly out of sync with the eponymous turn.
... I challenge you not to be grimly compelled by every minute of Phantom Thread.

Yes, it's intense jingoistic nonsense and full of hilarious caricatures - watch out for US enemy No 1, the evil Arab Mullah Razzan, played by Numan Acar in deadpan homage to Aladdin's cartoon nemesis Jafar.
Sadly, tragically, Early Man is just not very good.
An initially gripping parable about workers' rights in a Portuguese lift factory gradually becomes a harrowing endurance test
movie_title: The Nothing Factory (A Fábrica de Nada) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: At worst it suggests that the brains trust at Pixar, after 22 years of peerless output (Toy Story was 1995), is finally eating itself. At best, well, it's a superbly polished, technically flawless family film that makes you cry. And this is bad how?
The movie is half-baked, incoherent and frequently dull (a key plot point hinges on the difference between a daily or a weekly travel pass), yet, astoundingly, it is set up for a sequel.
... bar a few set-piece action scenes, this is mostly illogical, second-rate muck.
The co-director Julien Temple (The Great Rock 'n' Roll Swindle) provides the archive footage and animated inserts, but for better and for worse the film is all Suggs.
It's all very TV. And probably not worth the trip.
movie_title: Tad the Lost Explorer and the Secret of King Midas (Tadeo Jones 2: El secreto del Rey Midas) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: All plot holes can be subsumed within the magical-realist tone for which Del Toro is famed. Yet there's an uncomfortable tension between the film's whimsical, Amélie-light (or, lighter) style and its clumsy political point-scoring.

Don't let the fluffy faces fool you. Wes Anderson's latest animation delivers talking dogs and snicker-inducing scenarios. But it's also bleak and frequently unsettling, a dazzling family movie with the darkest of hearts.
It doesn't help that the film is pulverised by wall-to-wall narration.
A film that plunges you, shoulder height, into the horrors of Auschwitz-Birkenau during the final days of the war.
The "joke" soon wears thin, however, and the film, with few actual ideas to express, resorts to slapdash plotting and dead-end gore.
David Oyelowo does sterling work... in a film that might easily have been labelled sub-Tarantino trash were it not for the winning efforts of the Selma star.

If her story, however, is even vaguely familiar (made nude flick, was brainy, did inventions, made glamour flicks, stayed brainy, had lots of plastic surgery, died) then this will be a very ho-hum trawl.
Kate Winslet delivers an incendiary performance (easily her best since 2008 in The Reader)...
As a production project it was, apparently, stuck in "development hell" for more than a decade. Sometimes projects are stuck in development hell for a reason.
If you're still with the movie after the first ten minutes you're probably with it for the long haul (and possibly for life -- it lingers).
... one of those extremely tense and increasingly violent yarns where the guilt runs all the way to the top.
Lover for a Day could not be any more French (in the pejorative sense) if it tried.
movie_title: Lover For A Day (L'amant d'un jour) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Derivative, barrel-scraping "family animation" at its worst.
Zimmerman has effectively drowned any brainpower in a kaleidoscope of sloppy edits and relentless rolling footage of a man who appears to be profoundly boring.
The film, obviously, is a joke, yet tragically unaware of it.
[An] affable tale of dancing, cancer and eleventh-hour romance.

A furiously engaging movie that features Margot Robbie in an ice rink, Margot Robbie at the action end of brutalising domestic abuse and, most significantly, Margot Robbie transforming fourth-wall breaking into a nearly sublime art form.

Made on a budget of only $1.2 million, it is technologically startling, classically composed, with rich still frames, wide shots and close-ups, more formally precise than many big-budget studio efforts.
It's strong stuff. And then it all goes down the drain.
The performances are unremarkable, the direction minimal, while the clumsy appropriation of a real world Isis threat for cheap cinematic thrills seems, at best, questionable.
It's a fearless, committed, and award-worthy turn, and emblematic of a first-time film-maker at his most expressive and most affecting.
An exquisite melodrama about the extremes of love and grief and familial conflict that also, when you're least expecting it, packs a hefty political wallop.
This gripping, full-access account of life inside the White House during the last 12 months of Barack Obama's administration is sobering and heartbreaking.
... turns some sobering and timely questions about press power and presidential abuses into eminently satisfying screen entertainment.

The director Stéphane Brizé does some lovely work with non-chronological flashbacks and flash-forwards, but the deadening sense that we know exactly where this is going (hint: not up) is never quite undone.
The nervy bookkeeping rats in Scrooge's office are a joy, but Statler and Waldorf (Jerry Nelson and Goelz) as the chain-swinging ghosts Jacob and Robert Marley are, as ever, peerless.
Too many scenes are excruciatingly ill-conceived and the couple's chemistry is shaky, yet the outcome is never in doubt.
The performances are impeccable (Kassovitz's and Huppert's especially).
Cecil Beaton is the name and hagiography's the game in this documentary portrait that collapses at the feet of its subject.
Modern US history gets a bracing rewrite with Dolores...
This profoundly silly exploitation thriller posits the existence of a sinister New York gambling den where gorgeous but penniless immigrants go to die.
[Julia Roberts] lifts every one of her scenes in Wonder to near-sublime places.
In every aspect, Oldman proves a charismatic draw.

... stealing the best bits from My Left Foot, Born on the Fourth of July and The Theory of Everything by playing a character who's not quite paralysed, but mostly in a wheelchair and delivering enormous shouty set-piece speeches ...

By turns utterly charming and inherently shambolic, this no-budget feature-directing debut from the actress Mercedes Grower is an ambitious trawl through London love lives, with a bonus structural gimmick.

... the story of a Canadian naif (Gordon) who is stranded in Paris and falls for a local Chaplinesque tramp (Abel) is told with such broad strokes (lots of double-takes and achingly obvious pratfalls) that it eventually becomes wearisome.
... a deeply unironic and mildly gross Blanchett showreel.
... after an opening montage that ridicules the worst excesses of social-media myth-making ("This is me and my wonderful life!"), the movie has little left to say.
Smart, appalling and illuminating.
movie_title: Jim & Andy: The Great Beyond - Featuring a Very Special, Contractually Obligated Mention of Tony Clifton (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The urgent docu-style filming is impressive, but it's Pattinson's fearless turn that lingers.
The result is a horror show. A Frankenstein's monster of input and influence that knows not what to do, where to go or how to be.
... a corny soup of macho clichés and empty theatrics...
... is ultimately undone by its corny conventionality.
The # doesn't stop this excruciatingly tedious and formally inept "selfie movie" from being pure visual torture.
A difficult and highly mannered performance from Sally Hawkins coupled with a repugnant and profoundly unappealing character played by Ethan Hawke sink this curious, and curiously saccharine, biopic.
It's lots of fun and ridiculously violent, but the running time means it eventually becomes wearisome.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Wiseau, The Room and the making of a celluloid catastrophe are the subjects of The Disaster Artist, a fabulous, strange and frequently hilarious comedy-drama from the self-styled polymath James Franco.
... disappointingly toothless, soft-focus documentary.
It's vivid and uncompromising at best. And at worst? You might admire it just slightly more than you enjoy it.
Some virtuoso visual imagery and poignant contemporary themes go searching for a plot and proper characters in this hit-and-miss Hungarian drama.

What makes Molly's Game more than an entertaining, if enjoyably familiar big-screen Sorkin-fest (whip-smart characters spouting rapid-fire dialogue while slyly revealing personality traits) is that it's a profoundly emotional film.
A typically winning central turn from Kendrick and some Pitch Perfect staples just about save the day.
Yet another needless reboot searching for a reason to exist.

The film creates an audacious alternative reality where orcs, elves and fairies live among us and form part of a vibrant criminal underworld. The first 30 minutes, at least, is wildly accomplished film-making from the director David Ayer.
ll along you wonder how a story with so much potential could become a movie with so much wall-to-wall nothing.
Difficult, but hugely important film-making.
It's one of Scott's best films yet.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Part of you wants to shout at the screen...but the other part of you will be utterly wowed by the imagery. So that's probably good enough.
Pulp is an underrated comedic masterpiece.
The film is aiming for tough edges, but it's essentially very vanilla.
[Mountains May Depart] is another ambitious and elegiac portrait of societal change and fading Chinese values.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A committed central performance from Jasmine Hyde can't quite save this half-baked thriller that matches jarring tonal leaps and narrative ineptitude with unfortunate echoes of superior films.

The film has little to offer in terms of ideas or insight other than to say: "All this, while being a clown! For kids! Isn't that just mad?" It's Brazil's official entry for this year's Oscars. I won't be betting on it.
movie_title: Bingo: The King of the Mornings (Bingo - O rei das manhãs) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It took them 40 years, but they've finally done it. The best Star Wars film of the series. There. That's it. It's that simple.
It's basically an intellectual battle, held in an amphitheatre as large as a galaxy, about the right to life and the inherent tensions in US-UK political relations. In other words, essential viewing.
movie_title: Stairway to Heaven (A Matter of Life and Death) (1947)

movie_review_blurb: It's darkly amusing, sometimes uplifting... but deliberately dodges feel-good clichés.

[It has] a lethargic, lurching narrative that bounces between trailer-ready effects set pieces, and then scrambles, in a truly desperate final act, for something resembling meaning, depth and emotional connection.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The text is rich with stylistic flourishes and social observations, and boasts a genuinely wrenching closing sequence. The film, alas, is not.
The high watermark of Merchant Ivory film-making.
Packs a shockingly honest punch.
A rare thing in cinema history -- the third part in a movie franchise that's actually better than the preceding instalments.
Hysterically pretentious.
Underneath the street locations and locally cast actors, however, this is as slickly vapid and Hollywood (in the bad sense) as it gets.
There are some beautiful moments in Noel Clarke's Brotherhood.
The Neighbour is a serviceable B-movie thriller that's in the bizarre position of having nothing whatsoever to offer in terms of originality, performance, visual pleasure or storytelling verve.

The film promises a fabulous twist that never comes, and delivers instead some cutesy magical realist touches (lots of interior boy brain stuff) and a palpable lack of chemistry between Dornan and Gadon.
An initially intriguing but ultimately flimsy sci-fi action thriller.
A deeply personal film that's often moving, Jim: The James Foley Story is a documentary that nonetheless falls short of greatness by virtue of the blind loyalty it demonstrates towards its subject.
A movie so bizarre, so profane and so quietly virtuous that it works.
Two Women is an earnest, straight-faced adaptation of Ivan Turgenev's A Month in the Country that has a sexy and compelling performance stunt at its heart.
Holy Columbian marching powder, you'll be hard-pressed to find a more adrenaline-soaked, palpitation-inducing, stress-ride at the cinema.
Equity is a bizarre movie that manages the near-impossible feat of making a financial drama from an entirely female point of view without being in the slightest bit feminist.
An overlong, often plodding documentary about the 1970s evolution of punk (yep, again) that balances a clear enthusiasm for its subject with some genuinely awful creative decisions.
The lead actors, Geoffrey Couët (as Theo) and François Nambot (Hugo), deliver performances of subtlety and range.
movie_title: Paris 05:59: Théo & Hugo (Théo et Hugo dans le même bateau) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I never feel totally comfortable watching a movie in which the heroine is punched repeatedly in the face, in wide shot, by a muscle-bound psychopath until she blacks out.
What's wrong with the new Ben-Hur? How long have you got? This is a textbook case, step by agonising step, of how not to make a big-budget blockbuster.
It has an interesting premise and seems to be about the dark subject of death and childhood, but then backs out nervously towards cops'n'robbers banality.
Ouija: Origin of Evil is so brilliant for so long then sadly implodes.
Even by mainstream studio comedy standards, Keeping Up with the Joneses is poor. It plays like it was conceived in a Hollywood pitch meeting and has zero connection to human reality.

The Accountant boasts an appealing central performance from the redoubtable Ben Affleck, but is elsewhere lumbered with sluggish pacing, a surfeit of narrative detail, implausible coincidences, [and] tension-deflating flashbacks.
The Dreamed Ones should come with a warning: for seasoned arthouse enthusiasts only.
Workmanlike film-making meets familiar Yank-bashing propaganda in John Pilger's new documentary The Coming War on China.
Jet Trash is affable, mildly distracting, gap-year porn masquerading as a proper grown-up thriller.
The worst thing about boxing films is the boxing... Bleed for This, thankfully, knows these pitfalls.
It's a thrilling rumination on the mimetic aspects of poetry, the inexplicable drive towards creativity and the search for meaning in the most simple acts of human expression.
Creepy does as creepy says. This is an eerie and discomfiting thriller from the Japanese horror maestro Kiyoshi Kurosawa.
Magnus is a sweet and mostly restrained documentary about the world chess champion and occasional clothing model Magnus Carlsen.
I Am Bolt teaches you nothing at all other than that he's a nice guy, and possibly the greatest track athlete of all time.
[The film is] immersed in stultifying cliché and ear-poundingly awful dialogue.
It takes everything that was fresh and assertive about the original and transforms it into vile, hateful overkill.
Finally, a Philip Roth adaptation that works.
Gimme Danger is a gross act of fandom masquerading as a musical documentary.
Earnest and occasionally engrossing.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: By turns baffling, disturbing, moving and provocative, Alexander Sokurov's dreamy documentary stimulates the heart and head, just as it tests the limits of descriptive analysis.
Ewan McGregor's directorial debut doesn't do justice to Philip Roth's great book.
A grimly saccharine and interminably trite sea-sodden weepie.
A slim and derivative exploitation horror.
A disappointing and mostly flimsy sequel to Anthony Baxter's powerful 2011 documentary

A crassly nihilistic crime movie that is brought to you by the veteran director Paul Schrader and the often dazzling lead actors Nicolas Cage and Willem Dafoe, Dog Eat Dog is a waste of their talents.
Made over seven years, The Land of the Enlightened is an earnest, if woolly headed, docudrama from the Belgian photographer Pieter-Jan De Pue.
ChickLit will possibly be remembered as the moment when the low-budget Britcom genre hit bottom.
Utterly specious.
Under the Shadow is an eerie, often unsettling, Iranian feminist horror film set in Tehran in 1988, at the height of the Iran-Iraq War.

Some movies are great. Some movies become great over time. And some movies contain moments of such greatness that you forget the rubbish bits. Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children is one such movie.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A truly horrible TV movie premise -- let's re-create the first romantic date between Barack and Michelle Obama -- is given serious intellectual and emotional heft in the writer-director Richard Tanne's feature debut

Working in a genre that has recently hit bottom with dreary parody and vacant spectacle, the director Colm McCarthy and his team have managed to wrangle if not quite a complete reinvention, then something vivid and startling in its own right.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Captain Fantastic is a powerful weepie with a career-high turn from Viggo Mortensen as a hippy father driving his six children to the funeral of their mother.
Brent is back! And not a minute too soon.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If you're looking for a short, sharp hit of sun-soaked adrenaline (and who isn't?), you won't do any better than The Shallows.
Deeply dubious -- possibly specious -- this documentary is nonetheless car-crash compelling.
It's supposed to be ironic and self-aware, full of deliberately poor line readings and stiff, stylised performances, but it's mostly tedious.

This family-friendly blockbuster is not a Pixar pick-me-up, or a wacky Ice Age odyssey designed to send the little ones screaming excitedly through the foyer, hopped up on irony and wisecracks and heading directly for the nearest toy store.
The Legend of Tarzan is a Marmite blockbuster that will repel and attract in equal measure.
The Secret Life of Pets is a brazen retread of Toy Story - an identical animated blockbuster in almost every aspect, except for the charm, warmth and narrative wit.

The shooting style will drive many people to distraction (a four-minute opening shot of a bush, for instance, is a killer). But as an essay on motherhood, memory and the looming shadow of loss, it's close to exquisite.
Like an anti-Frost/Nixon, there's a ton of build up and no pay-off.

A raspy voiceover man (Lindsay Farris) announces authoratively that we are about to witness the story of the Egyptian gods... "From what I recall it goes something like this." What? Did he just say that?
The Trust is a heist movie that gives Nicolas Cage his juiciest performance since Kick-Ass and indulges some very kooky Cageian line readings.

Alice Through the Looking Glass was always going to be something of a stretch. The best material from the Lewis Carroll novel on which it is based was greedily excavated, in 2010, by Tim Burton for his smash hit 3D Alice in Wonderland.
A thriller without the thrills.
An intimate, often unflinching portrait.
Office Christmas Party is yet another wacky entry into the increasingly tedious modern genre known as "big stupid party where crazy stuff happens movie".
Urban Hymn is a movie of noble intention and clod-footed execution.

Expertly made, and a must for horror film aficionados, Hounds of Love is a chance for everyone else to enjoy an utterly punishing night at the cinema, with acute stomach tension and mild stress-induced nausea.
A sweetly compelling music documentary.
movie_title: Gary Numan: Android in La La Land (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A deeply silly horror movie.
An efficient if unsurprising Dutch drama.
Tickled is an unexpectedly engrossing documentary that's built around the hitherto unexplored (on film anyway) world of "competitive endurance tickling".
Blinky Bill the koala (which first featured in a children's book in 1933) is given a thunderously bland computer-animated makeover.
Directed by the twice Oscar-nominated Hany Abu-Assad, it is remarkable for dancing deftly between politics and melodrama without coming down heavily on either side.
Chevalier is Richard Linklater's Everybody Wants Some!! squished through a European arthouse grinder with deeply pleasing results.
Profoundly pretentious, woolly-headed and sophomoric.
movie_title: Ming Of Harlem: Twenty One Storeys In The Air (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It was probably inevitable that the Tarantino revolution would lead to this.

Romantic comedies that feature pregnancy as a dramatic motor are unanimously, and without exception, awful... Yet, here comes the writer-director Rebecca Miller, with her big brain and literary pedigree, and she completely nails it.
Suburra is a sprawling Italian crime drama with genuinely epic ambitions.
A loose and occasionally amiable documentary about Scottish folk music, Where You're Meant to Be isn't half as charming as it thinks it is.
Miracles from Heaven is manipulative, blunt, super-Christian propaganda that's dignified and deeply moving in its own way.

This one, thankfully, boasts some welcome new cast members (including the rapper Common and Nicki Minaj), a new director in Malcolm D Lee (the cousin of Spike), and a fearless approach to difficult subjects.

Schmaltzy when it should be moving, phoney when it should be sincere, and borderline offensive when it should be thought-provoking, the high-profile rom-com Me Before You is almost a perfect cinematic calamity.
Embrace of the Serpent is a breathtakingly gorgeous Oscar-nominated drama that caresses your eyes with its visuals as it bangs you over the head with its message.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Little Men is a deceptively intimate drama that presents itself as a quirky coming-of-age story.
Treading that perilous line between wilfully artful and needlessly arty, Esther May Campbell's Light Years is a feature debut that's arresting and infuriating in equal measure
This is a tongue-in-cheek buddy movie that's above average, but not too far above average.
A tough-love drama with shades of Bicycle Thieves.
Finally, 27 years after unleashing Jean-Claude Van Damme on the world, Kickboxer, the martial arts franchise that refuses to die, is boldly rebooted with the supremely silly Kickboxer: Vengeance.
It's oddly devoid of any political context (it could be set on Pluto) and demonstrates the stultifying effects, yet again, of the traditional rom-com formula.

It features Juliette Binoche and Fabrice Luchini giving deliberately hysterical and bonkers performances as posh people in a small coastal town in early 20th-century France who are being tormented by local fishermen-turned-cannibals. Wacky, eh?

An occasionally compelling portrait of Whitney Houston that asks, or teases, myriad questions about the singer's precipitous rise and tragic fall, but clearly doesn't have the footage or the interview subjects to answer them.
I've had enough of Gere's breathtaking golden years tour de force performances. Because they're starting to look like screen-chewing.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Touchy-feely New Age therapy runs headlong into evangelical Christianity in The Shack.
It's a grim dirge masquerading as a moralistic fable.
The hunky Australian actor Josh Helman is woefully miscast in a paper-thin and blood-spattered biopic of the bare-knuckle fighter and East End demigod Lenny McLean.
A casting masterstroke at the heart of My Cousin Rachel has transformed a wearisome idea into a gothic thriller with dreamy Hitchcockian undertones and regular emotional wallops.
A towering, at times monumentally good central performance from the character actor Roger Allam stands at the heart of The Hippopotamus, but it is entirely alone.
The miracle of Abe's performance, and indeed of Koreeda's direction, is that, despite everything, you don't actually loathe Ryota as a character. You pity him.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Somewhere in the mysterious space between the script and the animation, My Life as a Courgette boasts moments of (yes, whisper it) essential human truth that will leave you floored.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A movie about the important subject of Syrian refugees that subsumes every idea, theme and argument under Kaurismäki's penchant for expressionless actors who smoke a lot and stare into camera while not saying much at all.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A film that luxuriates, through that beguiling round frame, in breathtaking, never-seen-before screen imagery.
A watchable young cast, led by Brooklyn's Emory Cohen, and some time-shifting narrative shenanigans can't quite rescue Detour from the annals of also-ran western noir.
The fourth in the Wimpy Kid film franchise skews towards a conspicuously young target demographic (say, five and under) with precious little left for the accompanying adults.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Does the world really need a fifth Pirates of the Caribbean movie? Is there a limit to the amount of times a Hollywood studio can yell, "Captain Jack is back!" before the collective audience replies: "Who cares?!"
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's eerily similar to the TV show, but not strictly in content or execution... No, what the film-makers have captured and emulated is the TV show's trademark combination of conspicuous sleaze and formal naivety.
Upbeat, downbeat, whip-smart and spectacular.

Here it is. The future of mainstream Hollywood cinema. A place where not only do comic book blockbusters and superhero movies dominate the children's film category, but they inevitably bleed into, and infect, "grown-up" cinema too.
The British war photographer Jason P Howe is the tricky central subject of this grimly compelling documentary.
movie_title: A Good Day to Die, Hoka Hey (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This film just doesn't stop moving. The camera swirls around every shoot-out, every fight, every conversation. Nothing is still. Everyone shouts. The tone is hysterical and everyone is angry.
A wildly simplistic "autumnal romance."
Life, Animated is a feel-good documentary about autism, Disney movies and the stranglehold childhood has on adults.

Sometimes you're watching a movie and you know that it's not working, but you're clinging to it. You're pleading with it. You're willing it to get better. And then it does something so stupid and downright inept that you just give up.
The film is a hoot. It's a hit. It's a smash.
It ranks as one of the most bleak, most harrowing, and harrowingly significant, movies about US racial dynamics to have emerged from the studio system.
What it is, essentially, is 106 clamorous minutes of big-screen bombast that's so concerned with its own spectacle and scale that it neglects to deliver the most crucial element -- drama.
A weary Madame Bovary rehash set in rural Ireland.

One of the most lugubrious movie premises of recent years -- watch King Louis XIV, the Sun King, die slowly, in one dark room, over nearly two hours of screen time -- is here transformed into startling and fresh entertainment.
movie_title: The Death of Louis XIV (La mort de Louis XIV) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Typically dreamlike, and occasionally unnerving, this biographical documentary is a must for David Lynch completists, and a fascinating curio for everyone else.

Not quite a film so much as a cinematic experiment, Snatched gamely asks the question: "Is Amy Schumer funny enough... to transform a leaden Tinseltown turkey into pure comedy gold?" The answer, alas, is firmly in the negative.
A slightly sleazy Clint Eastwood vehicle from 1971, also called The Beguiled, gets an arthouse remake from Sofia Coppola for no discernible reason.
At best, the Malick method is a cinematic sacrament. At worst, it's a moronic, cringeworthy perfume commercial. Malick's new film, Song to Song, is his worst yet. An absolute shocker.
A sweet and sometimes moving, if ultimately minor, film about a hopelessly inadequate fraud case from 2012.
In probably her best screen role since the 2010 comedy Potiche, Catherine Deneuve delivers a masterclass in characterisation in The Midwife.
Deviously original ...
90 minutes of mostly uninspired vapidity that appears to be ticking the correct Despicable boxes.

How they managed to make a movie about a guy who went from poverty to fame to prison to fame again, before being shot five times and surviving, and then being shot four times and dying, into something as compelling as a tax return is anyone's guess.

The mellowing of a grumpy widower isn't exactly a new idea in filmed drama, but thanks to a bleak yet morbidly funny tone and some clever narrative shenanigans, the Swedish box-office hit A Man Called Ove wholly reinvigorates the concept.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A cutesy paper-thin premise is given genuine gravitas by the French screen heavyweight Isabelle Huppert.
A movie that aims to reach the hearts and minds of its pre-teen target demographic with a tale about the perils of retirement.
A paper-thin portrait of the racing car driver and designer Bruce McLaren, it is constructed with all the verve and passionate inquiry of a press release.
There are two bravura shots in The Human Surge... Otherwise, well, it's tough going.
movie_title: The Human Surge (El auge del humano) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Rocky meets I, Daniel Blake may sound like a horrendous pitch, but the bones of just that are in this muscular feature debut from the character actor, and now writer and producer, Johnny Harris.

Most of it is mesmerising to look at and Har'el clearly has the eye of an artist and owes a debt to the dreamy narrative style of Terrence Malick. It's just unfortunate that the film has so little to say.

It manages, nonetheless, to shrink all narrative possibilities down into a bitty best-of compilation that's notable only for some horrendously bad science and a career-low performance from Gary Oldman.
It is, ironically, easily the best Batman movie since Tim Burton's masterful 1992 sequel Batman Returns.
A film with serious acting, a true-story premise and nothing by way of charm, intrigue, dramatic tension, sympathetic characters or basic narrative momentum.
This one, Resident Evil: The Final Chapter, ties up all the narrative loose ends, although we were never in Maltese Falcon territory
It's good fun.
It's a shame, then, that the film's thematic relevance should outstrip its dramatic urgency.

A rousing tale of Pacific War heroism that has more in common with jingoistic Wayne staples such as Sands of Iwo Jima or The Green Berets than anything in the 21st century, this is wearily formulaic film-making.
It is such a hoot, watching him shoot everyone in the nightclub. He shoots them in the face, under the chin, through the temple. Blam! Blam! Blam! Screams! Gore! Death!
A deeply empathetic performance from Dev Patel and an unflinching view of child poverty on the streets of Calcutta provide a winning edge to Lion.
Underworld: Blood Wars is the fifth instalment in the long-running B-movie vampire franchise that bizarrely, and appropriately enough, refuses to die.
This is a mega-budget blockbuster that boasts one of the worst MacGuffins in the history of cinema.
Why Him? is a guffaw-inducing comedy from the Meet the Parents franchise writer John Hamburg, who brazenly cannibalises his own material with mostly pleasing results.
Marauders suffers from an affliction that's increasingly rare, if not unique, in the annals of modern gritty cop thrillers -- it is all plot and no drama.
To say that Passengers is a disappointment does not quite capture the lazy surface-gloss inanity that defines so much of it.
A horror movie in everything but name, Morgan Spurlock's Rats is a giddy, difficult, occasionally satirical, often stomach-churning thrill ride masquerading as a serious documentary.
Sebastian Barry's Costa prizewinning novel is gutted and reconstituted to the point of absurdity in this cockeyed adaptation.
An earnest documentary portrait of the film-maker Howard Brookner.
Flat when it should fizzle, formulaic when it should be diverting and plodding when it should flow, it is at best -- and it pains me to say it -- a masterclass in mediocrity.
This is a baffling, breathtakingly inept rom-com that plays like a horrifying cross-fertilisation of Richard Curtis comedies with Robin Askwith sex films.
Monster Trucks is a fist-pumping love-letter to oil-guzzling, engine-revving four-wheel drives.
The threat of a biological attack on London by Islamic terrorists has been transformed into a supremely duff movie by the combined talents of Noomi Rapace, Orlando Bloom and director Michael Apted.
A delicious central premise and a thoughtfully crafted protagonist are ultimately betrayed in this scattershot comedy from the Mighty Boosh stable that's all promise and dwindling rewards.
A smart and speedy cop movie that occasionally reaches for greatness.

The performance artist, sculptor and Seventies counter-cultural figure Chris Burden is the subject of this fascinating documentary that manages, somehow, to create a sympathetic portrait of an often (on this evidence anyway) unsympathetic artist.

This is a superlative French entry into the organ transplant movie sub-genre (Seven Pounds, 21 Grams, John Q, Dirty Pretty Things). In this case, however, the beauty resides in what the film doesn't do, rather than what it should.
[A] slickly accomplished thriller about the lobbying industry in Washington.
This impassioned docudrama makes the unfortunate mistake of confusing artistic ambition with intellectual incoherence.
From the start Moonlight announces itself as something different entirely.
Traditional high school antics take a Russian existentialist pummelling in The Student, a compelling and unnerving satire from writer-director Kirill Serebrennikov.
A catastrophically earnest drama.

This hit-and-miss crime drama never quite finds its feet, despite an intriguing West Country setting, some attempts at social commentary and two meaty roles for Ireland's finest thesps, Brendan Gleeson and Michael Fassbender.
Finally, 17 years since it all began, we get the payoff.

One can only imagine that, given that there's little gore or sex, the restricted entry level is designed to protect younger viewers from the deeply upsetting feelings of frustration and irritation that emerge once it becomes clear that nothing is working.
Nicolas Cage delivers one of his all too frequent cringe-making, extra-screamy, dial-a-psycho performances in this ultra-violent Southern noir.
This could have been so good.
Ambitious if ultimately misfiring.
A sweet and inspiring soft-focus documentary about the 1990s indie music scene in Glasgow.
It's notable only for the deeply shabby way it treats Mad Men's Christina Hendricks and for its extremely odd penchant for child-abuse jokes.
There's a whiff of mild homophobia about it, and it reminded me of the work of another Austrian film-maker, Michael Haneke, in that it basically hates its characters.
Horror fans everywhere should stay far away from this risibly bad entry.
A killer comedy!
Can we please declare a moratorium on Scream rip-offs?
Excruciatingly long and overdirected!
M:I-2 more than meets the challenge of summer sequeldom.
Has there ever been a more insipid sci-fi action film than Soldier? Probably, although it's hard to imagine.
Worth navigating for its refusal to play to the crowd. There's certainly nothing safe or sweet about Weaver's performance.
A half-baked affair that's a pastiche of better, more inventive comedies.
Standout performances include those given by Waters, Reilly, and especially Tom Cruise, ferociously alive after sleepwalking through that Kubrick movie.
Desperately unfunny.
A flawed but powerful Shine-esque tale of love, music, and madness!
Marvelous, provocative entertainment.
A lame-ass horror comedy!
More emotionally engaging than most live-action films.
The producer- director- star- screenwriter is an unexpectedly charming musical lead, pleasantly reminiscent of Jimmy Cagney in Yankee Doodle Dandy.
What it really lacks is dramatic juice.
A talented acting ensemble and some show-stopping musical numbers make the film an intermittently irresistible entertainment.
It's got little in the way of plausible plotting.
Sleek and sexy.
Don't be surprised if Scary Movie spawns itself.
If the film ultimately feels overindulgent and hardly among [Altman's] best work ... it's still a jauntily entertaining ride.
A strange trip but a far from satisfying one.
David Koepp's second outing as director elevates the horror genre with a refreshing intelligence and humor.
The action plods, the characterizations are thin and inconsistent, and worst of all the comedy's not very funny.
What Lies Beneath is startlingly shallow even for a summer movie.
A perfectly sweet-natured, passable family entertainment.
The film is an industrial design marvel full of impressionistic, painterly backdrops and cool CGI effects.
Clunky and contrived!
The film gets a lot of emotional power and tension out of everyday occurrences.
The Matrix is too much of an outer-limits head-trip to resist!
Yes, Meryl Streep is phenomenal again!
This is a second-rate Woody Allen midlife crisis comedy without the laughs.
An overlong misfire that has only flashes of staggering power.
Movies that are labeled 'feel-good' often sound as inviting as a Sally Field Oscar acceptance speech, but Billy Elliot, a U.K. import, comes by its sentiment honestly.
Lush, seductive!
Mission to Mars hasn't a single moment of real suspense.
Filled with surprising bursts of wit and charm!
Mostly works thanks to lead performances.
Wicked sense of humor!
Election is a bracingly intelligent adult comedy that shrewdly captures adolescence.
The father-daughter subplot packs all the emotional heft of Madonna's Papa Don't Preach video.
Crawford's such a good-hearted guy, you can't help but want a cut from his clippers.
Gun Shy is worth at least a shot at a matinee.
After an uproarious first half, Saving Grace arrives at its conclusion somewhat hastily and conveniently. But to its credit, it still maintains a sunny comic mellow.
An intelligent film for an excess of visual imagination.
Disappointingly, the furor over Requiem for a Dream's rating is considerably more compelling than the film itself.
Black and White plays more like a half-finished film essay than a provocative entertainment.
A disappointingly small effort.
Director Darren Stein is so busy throwing in pop icons and arch, self-conscious references to the high-school-is-hell subgenre that he forgets to craft an original black comedy.
Despite being full of Oscar-winning talent, this is still just a better-dressed, drawn-out episode of Touched by an Angel.
Tumbleweeds is a breath of fresh air that busts the cliches of dysfunctional mother-daughter sagas.
Up at the Villa is just lots of silly intrigue.
Lynch and legendary cinematographer Freddie Francis have crafted a hauntingly lovely mise-en-scène.
Spade's wise-ass persona grows tiresome fast.
Love & Sex is nothing but pain and suffering.
This pumped-up contrived, misogynistic military murder mystery is just about the tackiest excuse for summer entertainment I've ever seen!
Some of the wittiest dialogue to trip an adolescent tongue since Clueless.
Despite a good cast and the requisite selection of classic rock, this is a dead-end teen stoner flick.
The potency of [Jackson's] performance is almost enough to save this Y2K update of the black private dick from erectile dysfunction, but not quite.
Actually more fitfully silly fun than the original!
movie_title: Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me (1999)

movie_review_blurb: [Big Momma] is about as old as her pantyhose.
It could do for the plight of poultry what Babe did for bacon.
It's a real space bomb.
A zippy, irreverent time-filler.
An adrenaline-fueled joyride!
Almereyda never plays up the gimmickry at the expense of the performances.
A vivid, emotional story.
Shockingly lethargic!
Music is a calculated but effective film.
Already a prime candidate for 1999's worst!
A must-see for avid fans and a welcome primer for nascent hip-shakers everywhere.
What's most important to Lonergan is that we care what happens to his characters -- and we do, very much.
Refreshing!
Captures the embarrassment of foreplay, but it could use a few lessons in the art of seduction.
It may make you cry, but not because you've seen something worthy of your tears.
A frequently hilarious, exuberant ensemble comedy!
Pure Disney formula.
‐ Mr. Showbiz
It might be the scariest movie ever made!
Love and Basketball offers a rare gimpse into the life of female athletes, and Lathan's got all the right moves.
It's a relief to see Portman giving a realistic, moving performance.
So distressingly dark, grim, and cynical it's likely to make kids cry!
Quaint and refreshing!
While this cautionary tale of brotherhood gone wrong doesn't exactly break new ground, it certainly shows off its writer-director-star's triple-threat filmmaking potency.
Next Friday's a chronic snore.
After winning a well-deserved Oscar for his role as a high-strung football player in Jerry Maguire, this talented actor has become an intolerable screen presence.
Coppola has created a detective story without a solution and a coming-of-ager without discernable characters.
Arteta mines a lot of subtle laughs out of [Beverly and Buck's] unlikely pairing.
The biggest piece of supernatural hooey since estranged wife Demi Moore's The Seventh Sign.
Ambitious, enjoyable.
Jokey homage? Hong Kong action blowout? What's going on here?
Big Daddy is all about Sonny's maturation, but there's nothing new or unexpected about Sandler's latest.
A literate, dialogue-driven treat delivered by a cast that truly savors the script's wicked wit.
Dull, jokey, and insubstantial!
An endless barrage of action-packed fights sure to please all of Van Damme's diehard fans!
Overheated, tedious!
Subpar Dawson's Creek in Danskins.
Decent, suspenseful entertainment.
A pretty consistent bungle in the jungle.
So generic that it sometimes approaches the self-parody of a Naked Gun movie!
The film's bite is as toothsome as its bark.
Wholly predictable and implausible plotting, thin characterizations, and stilted dialogue!
A compelling, if somewhat choppy, tragic drama!
Nothing's helped by a hasty ending.
A refreshing, oddball summer entertainment with a sharp sense of humor.
Arnold Schwarzenegger's latest vehicle, End of Days, is such a witless, bombastic, by-the-numbers hunk of millennial hooey it made me nostalgic for Commando.
A refreshing, funny character-driven treat.

Practical Magic doesn't cast much of a spell!
This is certainly the best studio movie of the new year to date, and Douglas might even be remembered at next year's Oscars.
It's so plot heavy it never finds its nimble comic rhythm.

movie_review_blurb: Irresistibly raunchy!
Can't match its visual poetry with compelling drama.
Breezily funny and entertaining!
A crisp, suspenseful thriller!
A gritty, well-acted urban drama with lots of humanity.
Norton's first film is crisp, confident, and considerably more entertaining than it has any right to be.

I'd rather go on an all-Crisco diet than sit through Poor White Trash again.

You've got a stinker that deserves to be locked away in the yuletide bomb shelter along with Scrooged and Santa Claus: The Movie.

movie_review_blurb: All these men ... have their mirthful moments.

Another hackneyed, high-concept action flick!
Guided by famed visual-effects supervisor John Dykstra, the folks at Sony Imageworks have created some furry fun.
It's a swoony gem of an idea; too bad this Dick is so limp.

Irresistibly entertaining!
In spirit, 101 Reykjavík is so Almodóvar that it could melt the polar icecap.
More about good intentions than great drama.
The film's satiric skewering of '70s liberalism works because it feels emotionally authentic.
Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back is less a satire of the crass product Hollywood hurls at us than a reflection of it.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: This one's all labor pains, and, in the end, nothing gets delivered.
Good old-fashioned romantic entertainment, just restrained enough to skirt schmaltz.
It takes a special kind of stinker to turn an up-and-comer with the wily presence of a young Steve McQueen into a tousle-haired action figure.
The visceral force of Lumumba is a sober reminder that there's nothing more incendiary than the reopening of a forgotten chapter of history.

Loaded with smart, sarcastic one-liners and clever potshots at sexless studio movies like In & Out.

Optimistically explores how vastly different people can come together, and how any journey is more about what happens along the way than simply getting from one place to another.
It captures the youthful excitement of a burgeoning creative movement.

Dazzlingly, Mitchell has opened up what was essentially a performance concert piece and reinvented the movie musical. You go, girl.

Monotonous and mangy.
The film is broad, cute, and calculated at every turn.

By-the-numbers, ailment-of-the-week fodder dressed up with a classy cast.
A mostly smart attempt to resurrect Ealing Studios-style hijinks.
A funny, frenetic, and often quite touching microcosm of the Big Apple life itself.
[A] frank father-daughter drama.
A funny, poignant adaptation of Beverly D'Onofrio's autobiography, and a chick flick that's refreshingly sap-free.

Disturbing and disjointed.

A pretty minor affair, an outdated Aussie About Last Night.

The movie's too mellow cool for its own good.

While this romantic confection is about as substantial as the frozen hot cocoa they serve at the titular Upper East Side restaurant, it's appealing cast and snowbound, fairy-tale NYC locations make it go down easy.
Nothing more than one more run-of- the-mill, surprise-free, suspense programmer.
More than goofy enough to finish with style.
The actors are good enough to make it all work.

A stinky wedge of domestic thriller cheese.
This is satire on the giddy level of The Simpsons.
