Livingston and Cohen opt for mawkish formula in their third act.
The reason to watch is the firsthand testimonies themselves.
Spliced in are some really cheap animation segments and monotonous techno analog music, along with, alas, only the merest flashes of Dick's self-deprecating wit.
movie_title: The Gospel According to Philip K. Dick (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Pretentious neo-Gothic hokum with yawning gaps in logic and credibility.
The Price of Milk is one of the oddest offerings of the season - albeit in a welcome way - but its creamy serendipity is a bit too thick to swallow.
Gay deftly explores the casual experimentation between the two boys.
What keeps it (barely) from being completely intolerable is Keanu Reeves' hilariously awful lead performance.
An exercise in whimsy.
Hannibal is Godfather III-level slumming.
Not even a giddy wrap-up featuring Diamond himself can atone for the dreck that's come before it.
Transparently misogynist at its core.
Ends up having all the heft of a Nancy Drew mystery decked out in a tie-dyed T-shirt and peasant skirt.
Lena Endre, with her throaty laugh and natural warmth, gives a heartbreaking performance as a woman slowly sapped of her joie de vivre.
As with its sleazy, real-life predecessors, you actually come to care about its characters.
The film's greatest flaw is its miscast leads, who conjure up zero dewy-eyed, wish-fulfillment magic.

In fondly revisiting (carbon copying, it often seems) his first film, he's proved merely what we already knew: that he can unleash comic mayhem par excellence. Enough of the little boys with big guns. It's time for Guy to grow up.
Slick, self-assured, and thoroughly awful, Double Take is a primo contender for worst movie of 2001.
Not likely to please anyone.
A riveting, semi-documentary drama, and yet calling it that is a disservice to just how suspenseful and stylish an entertainment it is.
For all its wit and sharp casting, State and Main is way too pleased with itself to be funny or endearing.
The miscast leads make this stately, BBC-ish adaptation ponderous instead of pointed.
A barrage of dangling plot strands, inconsistent characterizations, and suspense-free shootouts.
Such a sensory experience; in its best moments, the film washes over you like a fever dream.
A reasonably engrossing thriller.
Whenever Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon resorts to flying fists or soaring sword battles, the Force is definitely with it.
A preachy, monotonous failure.
Here on Earth hungers for the nostalgia of an Elia Kazan-style farmbelt romantic tragedy à la East of Eden, but the end result is more akin to a soggy Troy Donahue-Sandra Dee weeper.

Deserves to be applauded for not casting Freddie Prinze Jr., but this sloppy, somnolent, strung-together flick pales when compared to such other teenage riffs on classic literature as Clueless and 10 Things I Hate About You.
It is therefore something of a shame when the film's second half succumbs to dewy, baby-boomer nostalgia ... And yet, chances are that you'll be moved all the same.
Meyers' women have precious little on their minds.
There's nothing else about Someone Like You to separate it from the herd.
With its capable cast, twisty plot, and gritty style, Memento is a real keepsake.
Yet, for all the film's slow spots, it's impossible not to be moved by Henry and Pike's blossoming romance, thanks especially to Gross and Schweig's charming lead performances.
The movie's loaded with funny scenes that mix and match its players to good effect.
Evolution doesn't deserve to spawn sequels.
McKay captures their environment without condescension.
Slow as a funeral dirge, the movie's all talk about art and passion and obsession without anything to show for it.
A pallid character drama that glosses over any interesting political or moral questions.
The film is lovely, life-affirming, and guaranteed to make you cry.
movie_title: The Road Home (Wo de fu qin mu qin) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Worth checking out -- especially for the naturalistic performances by the feisty Touly and the rest of the young cast.
If you're 14 and love Limp Bizkit, or 50 and yearn to lay down some rubber, chances are you'll think this honey corners like it's on rails.
The backdrop of exotic pagodas and wartime woe isn't nearly potent enough to buoy the feeble drama that plays out in the foreground.
A postmodern fantasia guaranteed to polarize its audience into believers and non-believers -- though it's impossible to come away feeling like you've ever seen anything quite like it.
There's no real sense of tragedy when these lost souls begin to drop dead in their eleventh hour -- just more pain and suffering for an already strongly unsympathetic group.
Don't pack up your PC -- Tomb Raider the movie has nothing over its electronic counterpart.
About Adam is simply a pleasant diversion rather the paean to crazy-in-love classics it would so like to be.
Those expecting a Bond-like thriller may be disappointed, but this deviously witty diversion deserves to be appreciated for what it is.
What's so touching about Startup.com is that it's really about the collapse of a dream.
Though unflinching in its savagery, Amores Perros is always compulsive viewing.
One more attempt to pass off chopped liver as foie gras.
Plays like a Chinese Cinema Paradiso, full of feeling without succumbing to sentimentality.
Dippy, funny, and fast-paced enough to be a guilty pleasure.
It's refreshing to see some straight musical numbers, uninterrupted and unadorned.
Nossiter's claustrophobic digital video camerawork and an intelligent script he co-wrote with James Lasdun elevate the proceedings above standard psychodrama.
There's so much that's fresh and surprising about the film that it deserves to be seen.
The script ... loses sight of the book's breezy wit and stacks up implausibilities as high as Bridget's half-eaten boxes of Cadbury's Milk Tray.
You're not likely to get much of a rise out of The Center of the World.
Uma Thurman bares her claws in a welcome return to form.
Every scene is designed to cram in a motley combination of stars and send them flailing about screaming in lieu of any plot or character development.
Entertainment that's good and good for you.
With mediocre expectations going in, the flick's cleverness, great score and wicked fight scenes lead me to recommend this to anyone looking for a good time.
This movie is so bad that I feel awful taking up Rotten Tomatoes' space with this quote. I will stop now. What a waste of great talent!
New in Town is a fun little flick that delivers a decent message and makes me want to visit Minnesota. It is the perfect rental.
Shockingly, the movie was a half-way decent horror flick with a great ending you will not see coming. I wouldn't waste your money in the theatres but it's a great rental.
Even though Brendan Fraser might be one of the worst actors out there, his co-stars and a clever script keep this movie alive and entertaining.
The first two in the series were visually pleasing action films but this prequel suffers from bad special effects and awkwardness.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Right now with ticket prices sky rocketing, why not see a flick that will keep you cringing and practically feels like an amusement park ride.
Even though I couldn't separate Dustin Hoffman from the Harvey character, it is still a perfect little flick that makes you smile when you leave.
You can predict the end of the film in the first five minutes but I will say that the dogs and the gadgets were pretty fun to watch.
Paul Blart: Mall Cop is a perfect display of clichés and predictability but I couldn't help but laugh at Kevin James riding the scooter and his addiction to pixie sticks.
If they had an Oscar for kicking butt, Liam Neeson would win it. I feel like I just left the gym. See this flick in theatres!
Anyone who has been in a relationship can appreciate a film like this because it just exposes the guts and glory of it all.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The flick might deliver some good laughs and decent performances, but the script had some of the more forced and unrealistic dialogue I have seen in a long time.
Maybe I am just desensitized, but this movie should have been a lot scarier, a lot more brutal and not the same old slasher movie we have seen a billion times.
The International is one of the better films of 2009 so far and contains an action scene that is worth the price of admission.
As annoying and predictable as this flick was, I found myself slapping my knee more than a couple of times. Don't waste your money to see it in theaters. Rent it!
As a fan of the video game series, I can honestly say that this is hands down one of the worst films I have ever seen. Chris Klein is so bad that he made the movie a comedy.
movie_title: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The flick is brutal, beautiful, thought provoking, phenomenal, genius, violent, sexual, brilliant and just overall completely mind blowing. Alan Moore would even like it!
This flick is one of the most disturbing, brutal and hard-to-watch movies I have seen. It is definitely on par with the original!
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As much I disliked Disney's excuse to make more money, I now know that Nationwide is on my side. The product placement is atrocious.
Every once in a while a movie comes around that most critics hate and I love. Well here is a movie that I thought was completely hilarious.
Knowing has a very gripping beginning and then just slowly lets the audience go until the film becomes a laughable cliché. One of the worst of the year so far!
I can honestly see people hating this film but for fans of Biggie's music like myself, the film is a great memorial to one of the best rappers ever.
Duplicity is another one of those flicks where everything is confusing until the very end but Gilroy does a great job building the chemistry between Roberts and Owen.
I Love You, Man has a great premise, enough laugh-out-loud jokes and plenty of awkwardness to warrant a viewing.
Coraline succeeds more so visually than it does in terms of plot and dialogue.
If the hype is true and this is really Phoenix's last role, he chose a relatively heavy and awkward film to go out on. The acting was superb and the flick felt very realistic.
This is the same old holiday film with a dysfunctional family that you have seen a million times.
Not knowing what to expect, the battle between Hudson and Hatheway was fun to watch but I would not waste money to see it in theatres. Wait for the rental!
Ritchie has brought back that amazingly gritty, yet extremely funny British crime flick that everyone deserves and loves.
The Boy in the Striped Pajamas may contain the most horrific and unsettling ending in film history but that is what makes the movie so darn good.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: 12 Rounds has some great action scenes and intensity but is killed by a horribly written script and ending. I would still recommend a rental.
Role Models seemed like a movie that was so easy to make. Scott and Rudd play the same characters they always play and it is perfectly formulaic. Did I mention that it is pretty hilarious?
The flick is nothing special but it is a great light for Bernie Mac to go out on. He was able to be as filthy as possible.
While all of these animated kids flicks are starting to run together, Madagascar 2 actually is a worthy sequel and is saved by the hilarious use of the penguin characters.
Kaufman has created, what could be his masterpiece, by messing with time and editing in such a way that you are just blown away mentally.
Slumdog Millionaire is definitely Boyle's best film to date taking the use of cinematography, music and story telling to a new level. One of the best films of the year!
While the flick is a disappointment and a pointless continuation of Casino Royale, the hard to watch action scenes still warrant the film one viewing.
Having never read the novel and not necessarily being in the demographic for this film, I must say that I was BLOWN AWAY by how intense and powerful it really was.
This is the perfect movie for a dog lover and just proves once again that the animated kids flicks still have steam. Plus, I loved that HAMSTER!
Australia is sloppy, way too long, has awful dialogue, some bad special effects and very annoying characters.
The first one was mediocre, the second was so bad I demanded my money back but the third one added in a few surprise elements and is one fun ride; no pun intended.
Van Sant could have trimmed the movie up a little bit but that is all forgotten when you see Sean Penn's awkward and genius performance.
Even with the cliché and rushed ending, the flick survives on its clever dialogue that made me laugh out loud a dozen times.
The flick is a very plain Jane version of a disaster film with mediocre special effects, no character depth whatsoever and is just a complete waste of money.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While the movie overall leaves you with a bland feeling, Streep definitely deserves the Oscar for Best Actress with her chilling and scary performance.
Frost/Nixon had the same intensity of an action flick but uses the number one weapon; great dialogue and great acting.
Yes, you should see this film because it was great to see Carrey back in his physical humor form and it brings some great laughs to the table.
Please stay away from the plot line of this film and go into it with an open mind. You will be pleasantly and emotionally surprised.
This is a kid's flick that is extremely dark, contains very little humor and actually plays off as a well written drama that just happens to be animated.

I am not exaggerating when I say this is one of the best flicks to come out in years. It is perfect in every aspect of filmmaking, i.e. acting, directing, pacing, editing, make-up, set design, special effects.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: With a movie that had so much potential, Singer delivers high intensity and action but lacks emotional connection to the characters!
While the movie was fun and entertaining, don't believe the advertisements because the film may have one of the most emotional endings I have ever seen.
Anytime Clint Eastwood is drinking a beer, growling and killing people, I am in. Eastwood directs a subtle film which will make you laugh awkwardly and keeps perfect intensity.
The Wrestler is Aronofsky taking a step back and giving you a full on actor driven flick that will make you cringe and weep and contains the year's best acting performance.
I had nightmares about the trailers, which is unfortunate, because of a lot of films' best scenes are contained there.
The flick is over four hours long and almost feels like you are watching trees grow. What makes it tolerable is Del Toro's dead on performance of an international icon.
Monsters Vs. Aliens is visually pleasing but a sad attempt at entertaining kids. The film is riddled with tired jokes and wasted talent. Wait for the cable viewing.
Year One contains a few jokes that work but what is really bothersome is that Cera and Black play the exact same roles they always play.
If you are a fan of the first film in the series and can forget about the two predecessors, then this is the sequel you have been waiting for. Vin Diesel is back!
Are we 100% positive that this film is not real footage from the Iraq war? Bigelow has directed one of the most intense and realistic films to come out in years.
While the film may not be as consistently funny as Borat, Bruno takes the win for one of the most shocking and hilarious films in years.
The sixth installment of the series is entertaining and passes the time but it suffers from the same anti-climactic feeling as the last film.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: At this moment, 500 Days of Summer is my favorite film of the year and is love at first sight.
Orphan contains one of the most terrifying and intense horror endings I have seen in years but the rest of the film was just laughably bad.
G-Force is painfully bad and completely unfunny.
What appeared to be another cliché romantic comedy, The Ugly Truth adds the raunchy angle and delivers some very decent laughs with your expected ending.
While the film drags a little bit, Apatow and the cast still deliver that perfect formula of hardcore raunchy laughs along with sweet emotions.
The G.I. Joe script may be the worst of all time, but the action scenes are so exhilarating that it is worth seeing.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A Perfect Getaway is not an Oscar worthy film, but it sure passes the time and packs a great punch at the end.
Aesthetically, the film is phenomenal. Streep and Adams deliver fantastic performances and the parallels between the characters were fascinating.
I know this word gets thrown around a lot and it should be used sparingly, but this film is very close to being a masterpiece in science fiction cinema.
This is by far the worst film in the series and the 3D is a complete waste of money.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: What appeared to be another High School Musical, Bandslam delivers a well written script and an in depth story with sprinkles of cliches throughout.
Tarantino perfectly balances brilliantly written dialogue with completely insane violence. I was pumping my fist in the air the entire time.
Rodriguez's latest flick is fun, immature and very imaginative. Sometimes, it feels good to just sit back and not have to think.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: While the film is not as good as Zombie's first, the violence is relentlessly brutal and you will definitely be jumping out of your seat.
While the film starts off slow, Lee's story develops into an amazing trip; no pun intended.
The film is worth every penny of your money to see in theaters but please be aware that the acting and script are both horrendous.
All About Steve is painful, unfunny and easily one of the worst films of 2009.
To keep it simple, the film is very dull and dry.
It embarrasses me to say that Sorority Row entertained me considering its lack of scares and originality.
Go home, turn your computer on and go to the 9 official website. Watch the trailer and then you will have seen the best parts of the film.
Cody's script is delightfully disturbing with well-written dialogue and pretty decent scares.
Zack and Miri Make a Porno is definitely Smith's filthiest, funniest and most sentimental film to date. There is a scene where you will laugh for 5 minutes straight.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This is easily Soderbergh's best film in years with a fantastically convoluted plot and a great performance from Damon. For the first time in a film, I enjoyed being confused.
Fascinating would be the best word to describe The Time Traveler's Wife.
What could have been Michael Mann's masterpiece ends up being a bland, slow, emotionless film with a couple of brilliant scenes sprinkled in the mix.
Visually, the film is beautiful, but as a huge fan of the first one, I was thoroughly disappointed with the structure, pacing, script and overall experience.
Even though I was able to figure out the ending just based on my knowledge of romantic comedies, the film still delivered decent laughs and good chemistry.
Adventureland is the perfect coming-of-age story with great performances and a beautifully written script.
Observe and Report is one of those films that leaves you feeling confused about what you just watched. Luckily the last five minutes make up for the rest of the film.
I may be putting my career on the line for this but this movie was enjoyable, well directed and well acted.
It was refreshing to see a well-done thriller with great performances and intriguing twists that keep you guessing throughout.
17 Again is yet another teenage flick that is completely out of my demo and completely unoriginal but delivers great laughs and an overall fun experience.
Crank: High Voltage is all over the place and not as good as the first flick but still finds a way to deliver the entertainment, shock value and action. Check it out!
I am trying to pinpoint just when I realized how terrible this film really was. It could have been the fact that it hit a dead end around twenty minutes in.
The Soloist is great in the visual, sound and acting department but fails to tell a story that grabs your attention.
Earth is a film of epic proportions which carries a lot of intensity and stunning visuals but drags a little in the beginning before picking up some steam.
Obsessed is your typical stalker thriller but is horrifically written and terribly overacted. I am bitter I had to pay to see it since it did not screen to critics.
Besides the amazing first twenty minutes, the biggest problem is that the film could have been so much better and completely over does the green screen effects.
The best part about Ghosts of Girlfriends Past is that the film knows it is unoriginal and uses that to its advantage. Michael Douglas was priceless.
The effects, direction and film score were so beautiful and mind blowing that it made a grown man cry. That grown man would be me.
Director James Toback gives the audience a raw and realistic view into one of the biggest names in sports of all time.
Next Day Air is unecessarily violent and completely pointless. One of the worst films of the year.
Though the film is a little long and extremely predictable, it is slightly better than The Da Vinci Code and packs some great intensity.
Terminator Salvation is all special effects and zero depth.
As usual with most comedies, the best parts of the film are in the trailers.
The sequel is missing what made the first film so special; magic and mystery. The first flick is far superior.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: When I walked out of the theater, the publicist asked me if I was the little girl screaming in the front row and I answered honestly with; 'Yes.'
Pixar really set the bar high with Wall*E and even though this film falls a little short, it is still sweet, visually stunning and filled with a ton of heart.
If I had enough money, I would be willing to pay anyone back if they saw this movie and did not like it.
Surprisingly, the film actually delivers some great visuals, laughs and gives hope that Will Ferrell can be funny again. Rent it.
For a movie filled with cliches, the laughs happen so frequently that you are able to forget about the fact that you have seen this movie a billion times before.
At best, Tony Scott has directed a mediocre thriller that delivers some decent action sequences.
Eddie Murphy's latest is exactly what everyone expects it to be; painful, cliché and predictable.
Director Sam Mendes perfectly balances comedy and real life drama with a film that will have your attention from the first frame until the last.
Haunting in Connecticut made me feel like I was in a padded room. The main core was AWFUL but the two ends were actually pretty entertaining. Wait for the cable viewing.
Right when I thought Eastwood was becoming an "Oscar Mamma's Boy," he brings out this amazingly brutal true story that is filmmaking at its finest.
If you are expecting this movie to be Iron Man, you will be disappointed, but it is 1000 times better than the abomination that Ang Lee created back in 2003. No pun intended.
I am a 24 year old guy who loves action movies and raunchy comedies but even I can admit the songs in this film were catchy. The film is cliched but clearly for kids to stare at Zac Efron.
The first major release of the year is a complete dud. Shocker!
Besides the few chuckles I had, the movie was just dreadfully bad.
For a movie I knew nothing about going into, it really surprised me and I had a great time watching it.
I just sat there in awe the entire two hours and thirty minutes of the film, just completely stunned as to what I was seeing.
(Juno) is perfectly clever and perfectly paced.
Why, Joel and Ethan, why did you have to ruin an almost flawless film with a terrible last scene?

To this day, six months after seeing the film for the first time, I still do not know the answer to one of the biggest moral dilemmas I have ever seen. Casey Affleck's character has to make a decision at the end of this film that just blew my mind.
The film felt very anti-climatic to me for some reason.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Sex and The City: The Movie is riddled with clichés but the film works on a level that is smart, funny and just downright crude. Kim Cattrall, as Samantha, is the perfect balance to the series and the film.
The Strangers is full of cheap scares and unoriginality but does contain an ending that is worthy of a stomach ache beyond belief.
Could they have made more of a slow, dull and boring film?
The movie is extremely hilarious, yet very serious and emotional at the same time.
(Run, Fat Boy, Run) is your nice, fun, romantic film that is not necessarily worth spending your money to see in theatres.
All I kept writing down in my notes during the movie was "gruesome" "I can't breathe" "My stomach is in knots."

I am totally guilty. You can throw me in a court room and convict me because I am totally and completely guilty of thinking this movie was going to be the same old romantic comedy that we have been seeing for years.
If you can set aside the movie's countless flaws and just go to watch a stupid mindless movie, then you are good to go with this film.
You can pretty much tell which parts were written by Seth Rogen. That was probably why 50% of the movie was actually funny.
The movie has a million flaws, but if you can look past them and enjoy a fun, gritty, violent, racist and entertaining dirty cop film, then you will have fun with it.
Untraceable will have steam for a little while and then it is just going to die down and become the $5.99 movie at Walmart.
27 Dresses can be worked out just like a long division problem. The story offers up the problem and then it just works its way out to the perfect mathematical solution in the end.
I was having mediocre day and I walked out of the movie totally pumped up and ready for the rest of the day, even though it was 10pm at night.
This movie is just down right annoying.
I just kept thinking about Daniel Day-Lewis and Marlon Brando when I watched Paris Hilton's acting performance in this film (can you sense the sarcasm?).

I have never wanted to eat a digital/animated steamed dumpling more in my life than I did when I saw Kung Fu Panda. Jack Black really poured himself completely into this role and the movie turns out to be extremely funny and action packed.
I really wanted to hate this movie so much based on the trailers and Sandler's past couple of films but his outrageous performance won me over and made me chuckle throughout the entire film.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Bigger, Stronger, Faster* should be a documentary that Michael Moore watches so that he can learn how to tell both sides of an argument.
The film is just very sloppy and seemed like it was just pieced together really quickly to be released as fast as possible.
If you have seen the trailers online or on T.V., you can just save your money and wait for the rental on this one. All of the best moments are in the promos.
Just when you thought that a horror/thriller movie couldn't get more violent and gruesome; think again!
(The Bank job) is just a fresh flick with tons of entertainment and it goes by very quickly.
Any movie that has gummi bears fighting to the death will immediately win anyone over. The best animated movie since since Wall-E and easily the best of 2009.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The kids will love this movie...
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This is hands down the best super hero/comic book movie I have ever seen!
This movie has everything. Violence, racism, incest, sex, drugs, gross-out humor, insane amounts of nudity and Neil Patrick Harris!
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmakers should be ashamed of themselves for even allowing this movie to enter a movie theatre. It was like a bad made for TV special that you would see on ABC or NBC.
There was trailer before the film for Harold and Kumar: Escape from Guantonamo Bay, which actually made me laugh more than the entire film of Semi-Pro.
This is the sleeper comedy of the year.

When they were counting down the 88 minutes, I just kept saying to myself, "oh man, this movie still has 72 minutes left?" "Oh man, this movie has 17 minutes left?" I just couldn't wait to get out of the theatre.
(Speed Racer) is one of the most colorful, visual, fun and exhilarating movies I have seen in a while.
(Son of Rambow) is definitely a movie out of left field, but it does have some pretty funny laughs and does make you feel really tingly inside.
(Deception) is a perfect example of an interesting plotline mixed in with some really cheesy and sappy moments.
(The Life Before Her Eyes) is one of those films that you will walk out of just feeling very shaken up and disturbed.
Though it is very message oriented and a little sloppy at times, I found the subject to be really interesting and the opening war scene will blow you away.
I suggest buying a ticket to Prince Caspian, going to grab a bite to eat for the first hour of the film and then heading back to the theatre for the amazing ending battle.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Just remember the "5 minutes of uninterrupted eye contact" scene (with Steve Martin). I was almost in tears.
When I say the movie is cheesy, I am talking provolone, American cheese, Swiss cheese; cheesy.
(Rambo) really only has 3-4 minutes of redeeming entertainment.
Not only did I want to go to sleep the entire time, but I wouldn't watch this movie again if you told me my life depended on it.
movie_title: The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If it was not for Morgan's goofy character or Katt Williams, I would be giving this movie a zero.
This film should NEVER leave the theatres.
Crystal Skull is the worst in the series with some really bad twists and dull moments, but the action scenes alone save the film and warrants at least one viewing.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Wait until you see the end of this film! It was one of the most horrific endings I have ever seen.
Transformers is the best action movie I have seen since The Matrix.
As of October 1st 2007, this is officially the best film I have seen all year.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: (We Own the Night) was terribly written and just such a waste of great actors.
(Vegas) isn't a horrible film but it is not worth spending your money on to see in theatres.
I felt like I was watching a fairy tale or something. It just didn't seem realistic at all.
I might have lost my entire college education watching this and it might be the dumbest film I have ever seen but I can't hide the fact that I was laughing hysterically.
If you can look past the formulaic plot, predictable jokes and sometimes awkward chemistry, you will find yourself slapping your knee a couple of times during the film.
Mongol is a little slow at times, but you do a get a good history lesson while you get to see blood spraying and bodies flying all over the place.
College is exactly like every other film you have seen in the genre. You definitely shouldn't waste your money to see it theatres but it is worth a cable viewing.
Instead of killing people, Nicolas Cage's character should have been more worried about getting a haircut.
The flick is nowhere near the level of Heat because of the predictability but it does deliver great performances and hilariously awkward dialogue.
Another Coen Brother's classic. The point of Burn After Reading is that there is no point and that is the entire point.
Ghost Town had the exact feel as every other flick where a dead person talks to the living but what sets it apart is Ricky Gervais' hilarious performance.
Samuel L. Jackson pulls off an extremely terrifying performance in this formulaic thriller which looses all of its sizzle with an AWFUL ending.
Towelhead is one of the more disturbing films to come out in years and to this day, a month after seeing it, there is one particular scene that still shakes me up.
Imagine picking up a book, reading a couple of pages and then skipping ahead a couple of chapters. The connection between these two characters came out of nowhere.
What could have been Spike Lee's best film since Do the Right Thing, Miracle turns out to be a confusing mess that is topped off with an annoying child.
I was waiting for Will Smith to pop up in this sequel to Enemy of The State, which was extremely far-fetched but still deliver pretty decent entertainment.
With a cast and director like this, you would expect greatness. What you really should expect is a cup of coffee so you can stay awake.
The film made me want to be a better person and shows you that life is sometimes about honor and not money.
The trailers for the film are WAY cooler than the actual movie itself. The acting was so bad that I honestly felt like I was watching a FIRST reading of the script.
Even the simplest films can be the most effective and make you laugh non-stop.
This is the type of film that you dislike one minute and then think it is totally genius the next. The latter was what I felt more often but only by a little.
Religulous will offend you, make you laugh extremely hard and then scare the living hell out of you. No pun intended.
It's a film directed by one of the best directors in Hollywood, written by one of the best writers and has two of the best actors around. How could you go wrong?
I always ask myself why they keep making these inspirational movies, but for some reason, The Express worked perfectly.
City Of Ember is a fun adventure flick that drags a little in the beginning but picks up and turns into a fun ride.
Quarantine is the type of movie that is made to see in a theatre. The film is brutally realistic and shot in such a way that you feel like you are watching real footage.
What is more confusing, the spelling of the word Chihuahua or how a movie this dull has been number one at the box office two weekends in a row?
Though the PG-13 rating of Max Payne limited the amount of violence, the film still succeeds mainly due to the dark, gritty and beautiful cinematography.
W. is definitely a sloppy film with a ton of problems but you can't deny how interesting it is to learn about his life and the acting was superb.
The Secret Life of Bees is an unbelievable story that will definitely get you teary eyed and is proof again that Dakota Fanning is one of the best young actresses around.
Sex Drive is absurdly funny and a perfect example of nice guys always finishing last.
Surprisingly, the FIFTH installment of the series has a nice flow to it and is still able to dish out newly designed horrific torture scenes.
The flick is filled with a ton of laughs, a ton of heart and Simon Pegg is funnier than ever. HILARIOUS!
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Traitor is an amazing flick that perfectly balances out the reality of terrorism and keeps the audience guessing and entertained throughout.
Director Fred Durst, yes you are reading that correctly, made a very noticeable debut with this true story that is full of cliches but a ton of heart.
With all of the unoriginal garbage in Hollywood recently, Hamlet 2 gives us hope that there is still talent left in the world.
Wanted has action scenes and special effects that are so amazing that I broke the "Silence is Golden" rule 4 or 5 times because I couldn't stop yelling "Wow!"
Wall·E is truly an animated masterpiece, and that word shouldn't be thrown around easily, but for some reason I cannot think of a single problem with this film.
This is an open letter to director Peter Berg. I just wanted to say, "Good Job!"
Kit Kittredge is a film you walk out of and say, "Well, that was ok." Then you move on with your life.
Hellboy 2 is visually perfect and is a sentimental look into the world of Hellboy but keeping with the love story of the film it should have been called Heavenboy.
If you can get past the first 20 minutes of the film and turn off all criticisms of bad acting and awful clichés, then you will enjoy this special effects filled adventure.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Meet Dave is one of those films that will get a bad reputation based on the trailers but it actually generated a few chuckles from my end and was not a complete waste of time.
Ledger's performance reigns over Nicholson's by taking evil to a new level. If you don't see this in theatres, then you are missing out on one of the biggest and best films in history.

What happened to James Bond?? I honestly wanted to be a "Dancing Queen" and dance right out of the theatre. Mamma Mia! is one of the most awkward, poorly acted and just laughably bad musicals to date.
I never thought that a movie with a terrible song playing like the "Monkeyrena" would actually keep me entertained and make me laugh, but it did. It still has nothing on Wall-E.
Step Brothers is a very up and down comedy but when the film is riding the upside, it is high-class laugh out loud hilarity that pushes that R-rated envelope in a good way.
The X-Files: I Want to Believe is a film that comes out of nowhere, serves absolutely no purpose to the series and maybe has fifteen minutes of interesting entertainment.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Your suspension of disbelief will totally diminish when the abominable snowmen/yetis show up and start cheering each other on and practically giving each other high fives after beating up the bad guys!
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Swing Vote, to sound as cliche as possible, is a heartwarming film that is smart and laugh-out loud funny. Believe it or not, the flick sends an important message about politics.
Director Nanette Burstein created real movie magic by making a documentary that actually flowed and felt like an actual film with character development and a great story line.

Apatow finally changed up his bathroom humor act and resorted to a violent stoner movie, which works quite well! McBride steals the film with his hilarious performance that even outshines Franco's out of whack character.
What looked to be another Sideways, Bottle Shock turned out to be a very smart and well written take on a true story that even non-wine drinkers like myself could appreciate.
I wasn't a film critic when the first one came out, which was a great excuse not to see it. However, I liked the sequel so much that I am running to the video store right now to rent it.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Larry Bishop seemed like he watched one too many Tarantino films and tried to rip off every cool shot and musical number he ever did, without adding in any of his own style.
Man on Wire is another refreshing film from 2008 that proves that even if Hollywood is running out of ideas, we can still count on documentaries.
Tropic Thunder hits the nail on the head with politically incorrect humor in a good way. It just hammers it right in until it's poking out of the other side.

Again, we have to experience the George Lucas formula post Jedi; great visuals with an AWFUL SCRIPT that felt like it was written by a 3 year old. This time around, Lucas delves into the BABY TALK world.
Henry Poole Is Here is the subject of a great concept which is executed well in the acting and writing department but suffers from its awful music choices.
The genius behind Woody Allen is clearly seen in this film, which contains a very simple story line but it is riddled with clever dialogue and a unique narration.
While The Rocker may be completely unoriginal and campy at times, the film still exceeds well with great laughs and a couple of one-liners I will be adding to my collection.
This is one of those flicks that you almost feel bad liking as a critic but I could not help laughing throughout this entire film.
The flick is mindless fun. Any guy who wears Chuck Taylors, kills people in amazing ways and just spouts off amazing dialogue is totally cool in my book.
Pride and Glory is your standard dirty cop movie with Edward Norton pulling off a great performance while Colin Farrell completely over acts.
The film was a winner right up until the last ten minutes, when it preceded to punch me in the face with every cliché possible.
I cannot wait to go see this film again and I really want to buy the soundtrack.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: While the film will make you contemplate the effects of technology on human interaction, the script is dull and one dimensional. The worst part is that it could have been great.
You will laugh. You will cry. You will fall in love. Zwick perfectly blended together raunchy humor with a hard-hitting emotional story.
Tron Legacy is one of the most visually stunning pieces of entertainment ever made. Dear the Academy Awards, please nominate Daft Punk for best original score!
Give Christian Bale and Melissa Leo the Oscar right now! The Fighter contains the best boxing matches since Raging Bull.
Simultaneously one of the most emotionally devastating experiences I have had in a theatre yet I could not look away. Aronofsky's best since Requie For a Dream.
How Do You Know is a well-written romantic comedy that stays away from formulas and cliches. I loved James L. Brooks' use of the close-up shot to show raw emotion.
Just awful.
The King's Speech contains brilliant cinematography, acting and direction. The flick was as exciting as 3D action-adventure! Give Firth the Oscar!
Beautifully executed on all levels including Deakins' stunning cinematography, Burwell's emotional score, the Coen's perfect direction and Bridges/Steinfeld's epic performances.
Easily one of the worst films of the year. What a waste of time and talent!
There is a line of dialogue said by Tony Goldwyn's character that is worth the entire price of admission! Other than that, the rest of the film is mediocre at best.
The Rite is just another exorcism film that will be forgotten in a long line of films that have followed The Exorcist. Look out for Colin O'Donoghue though!
Never Say Never is a legit documentary made for the fans and the haters. I dare anyone to watch this movie and tell me they weren't inspired. The 3D was fantastic!
Easily the best Potter film since 'Azkaban.' The cinematography is beautiful, the magic is fun and the characters are deep. Did Peter Jackson direct the middle section?
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There is a car chase sequence in Unknown that is so awesome, even Steve McQueen would be impressed. Liam Neeson needs to play these types of roles from now on!
While the film's source material dates back to 1954, it is still one of the more original, though-provoking and down-right entertaining films to hit the big screen in years.
Anytime you have a rattlesnake attached to a machine gun and voiced by Bill Nighy, you can sign me up. Cleverly written, not for kids and not in 3D. Go see it. Now.
Whoever cut together the epic first trailer for Battle:LA deserves an Academy Award. There is a reason why we hear no dialogue in that trailer...
Red Riding Hood is basically a beautifully photographed episode of 'Days of Our Lives.' The script is laughably bad.
You know a movie is amazing when you don't want to get up to use the restroom in fear that you'll miss a single frame. I just wish it ended five minutes earlier.
The film delivers haunted house-type scares throughout but I just wish the second half was as good as the first. Wait for the flick to come out on DVD.
Bad-A**!
Did Arthur need to be remade? The short answer is no but Brand does bring an entertaining charisma to a rather dull and average script. Catch a matinee!
Your Highness is painfully bad!
Scream 4 has the perfect opening and then slowly declines to a slightly above average slasher flick. It could have used more scares and less self-aware satire shtick.
Water for Elephants is a beautiful and captivating film that you will never forget! Robert Pattinson delivers a magnificent performance alongside Witherspoon and Waltz!
Easily the best film in the series! If you can turn your brain off and not be too persnickety about dialogue and acting, you will be blown-away by the action!
The flick should be called I Am Number Six because Teresa Palmer steals the show with minimum screen time. I wish the movie was as good as the last twenty minutes.
Masterfully directed by Branagh, Thor delivers a Shakespearian-esque superhero flick with epic action, performances & emotions making it the strongest Marvel film to date.
Fair Game is a powerful thriller that rides that fine line between telling the truth and keeping things entertaining
The film suffers because every funny joke is in the trailer and director Todd Phillips overuses Zack Galafianakis.
Rodriguez should petition the Oscars to create an award for the greatest death scene. I was practically in tears trying to comprehend the awesome nature of this flick.
Long and Barrymore create very realistic chemistry in a film that pretty much nails what's it like to be in a long distance relationship. Though, Charlie Day steals the movie.
I found myself more interested in the beautiful cinematography than the story line. The American is extremely slow for the first two acts but does deliver in the finale.
I do not understand the hatred for Shyamalan. Yes, he has trouble directing actors but Devil is a very intriguing idea executed in a relatively mediocre fashion.
While the film never reaches that true level of greatness, Affleck has crafted a well-made heist film with amazing performances from Lively, Postlethwaite and Renner.
Dear The Academy Awards, please give Joaquin Phoenix and Casey Affleck their Oscars now please. One of the most riveting pieces of entertainment this year!
The misleading trailer will intrigue people to watch it but the actual product is so much more rewarding. Catfish is unintentionally genius.
The flick is a worthy sequel that contains phenomenal performances but falls short of the first one. Some of the editing felt like a Powerpoint presentation.
Never Let Me Go is easily one of the most hard-hitting, sick, twisted, demented, disturbing, beautiful and emotional films I have seen in a while.
The visuals are absolutely stunning and there's something inherently awesome about owls fighting in Snyder's slow-motion. The issue lies within the story and character names.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Every aspect of the film, from Fincher's beautiful direction to Reznor's emotionally devastating score to each and every performance is absolutely stunning.
I absolutely adored the original Swedish film and was more than worried about a remake. Reeves proved me wrong and delivers one of the best remakes I have ever seen.
I am usually against 3D films but Dreamworks has found the right formula with Megamind and How To Train Your Dragon. Will Ferrell is back!
Buried is a brutal, relentless, mind-numbing thriller whose last five minutes will leave you absolutely breathless.
The film's formulaic nature was ultimately saved by Randall Wallace's stunning horse racing sequences. Even though we know the ending, I still found myself cheering.
Zack Galafianakis delivers a surprisingly emotional yet awkwardly funny performance in a film that rides that fine line of drama and comedy. I left with a smile on my face.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The third installment of Jackass contains 3D that is as good as, if not better than, Avatar. The only issue is the pranks are tamer and get old after a while.
I literally shed a nerd tear because I could not handle the awesome nature of the action sequences in this film. Imagine the Ocean's films with machine guns.
Norton, De Niro, Jovovich, Conroy all give performances that are better than the film itself. Save your money in the theaters and rent it when it comes out on DVD.
Hereafter is a disappointing flick containing great potential that leads to absolutely nothing.
Where is Steven Spielberg when you need him for a clever ending? I had trouble sleeping for three weeks after the original film but I slept perfectly fine after the sequel.
Betty-Anne Waters' story is better than the film itself. Though, the performances are very strong especially from Juliette Lewis who deserves an Oscar nomination.
The 3D is bad. The acting is bad. The kills and torture sequences are mediocre. The ending is underwhelming. Do you really want to spend $15 dollars to see this movie?
In a world where CGI has become the standard in most films, director Tony Scott resorts to using real trains, real action sequences and real stunts. It pays off!
Morning Glory is a sweet, fun and hilarious romantic comedy that survives mainly because of the charming and lovable performance from Rachel McAdams.
Franco's performance was brilliant but the real star here is director Danny Boyle who figured out a way to keep this film moving at a fast pace.
Not only is the film an eye-opening, perfectly put together documentary, it also engages the audiences with spectacular animations and a gripping narrative.
You already paid for and saw this film two years ago. Though, the version you saw then was a thousand times better. Beyond disappointing!
Nerd tears came streaming down my face everytime Michael Fassbender took the screen for his epic performance. Entertaining, fun, action-packed and thankfully not in 3D!
A mind-blowing masterpiece. The films works perfectly on both an emotional and suspenseful level. Every aesthetic from Giacchino's score to Abrams' use of lens flares was epic!
Martin Scorsese's love letter to filmmaking finally proves that 3D is a necessary aesthetic to storytelling if used correctly. I definitely shed a few nerd tears!
While I admired and enjoyed the film, it reminded me of drinking a Pepsi Throwback; tastes great but brings nothing new to the table.
A solid film with a masterful score and beautiful cinematography. While the film never reaches that level of Spielberg greatness, it contains my favorite scene of 2011.
The Devil Inside is a terrible, uninspired, hack "found footage" flick whose trailer gives away every "scary" sequence!"
Joe Carnahan delivers a rather brilliant, deeply emotional, philosophical flick that still finds time to show Liam Neeson's bad-a** side!
Chronicle is an absolutely incredible, brutally intense, emotionally engaging, original film that will blow your freaking mind. Stop what you're doing and see it now!
Through the use of active duty Navy SEALS, live ammo and helmet cameras, Act of Valor produces insanely realistic action. Just don't go in expecting good acting from the SEALS.
The Hunger Games completely transcends the teenage genre by presenting a film with a strong emotional core mixed with an epically bad-a** central character! I loved this movie!
The product placement for Harvey's book is a blatant disregard for the audience's intelligence. I felt like I was watching a 3am "ShamWow" infomercial!
Mark Ruffalo was born to the play The Hulk. There is a ten second epic action sequence that is worth the entire price of admission and every one of your nerd tears! Hulk Smash!
"Prometheus" is a cinematic masterpiece with beautifully haunting visuals and an epic score. Instead of spoon-feeding the audience, Scott allows you to think for yourself!
The Amazing Spider-Man succeeds as a great love story but ultimately fails as a super hero flick. Should you see the film in 2D? 3D? or 3D IMAX? Click for full review!
Someone please show this film to Morgan Spurlock! It should be renamed Dunkin Donuts Presents: Jack and Jill.
Savages is a solid flick for the first two hours and four minutes. I'm still flabbergasted and scratching my head at the choice Oliver Stone made to end the film!
The Bourne Legacy needs Matt Damon, better action and an ending. The best part about this flick is James Newton Howards incredible score!
The Expendables 2 has roundhouse kicks, cheesy one-liners, Chuck Norris jokes and Schwarzenegger/Stallone/Willis action scenes! It's the perfect flick to help you let off some steam!
Lawless uses it's extreme bloody violence as a character to propel this riveting and emotional story forward. Hardy and Pearce deliver incredibly engaging performances!
Cloud Atlas is masterful in concept but mediocre in execution. Three of the stories worked while the other three lacked the emotional depth required for a 3-hour flick!
The epic action brought nerd tears to my eyes! Shane Black delivers a witty, action-packed flick with great twists. See it in 2D as the 3D conversion lacks great depth!
Through Abrams' beautiful use of Giacchino's epic film score, 35mm anamorphic lens flares, and his incredible detail in character, I found myself weeping nerd tears! See it in IMAX!
Zack Snyder marries Hans Zimmer's brilliant film score with the non-stop action resulting in an insane amount of Nerd Tears! Emotional and action-packed! Skip the 3D.
Gravity is the game-changing film of our generation. Cuaron has created a technical and emotional masterpiece that elevates the art form! See the film in IMAX 3D!

The combination of NO green screen, incredible practical effects, Zimmer's score and a solid emotional core makes this Nolan's most complete flick to date. I had major nerd tears! See in 70mm IMAX film!
Tell me. Do you want to see the Justice League assemble and kick some major a**? You will.
Gorgeous cinematography, solid performances & one of the best scenes in Star Wars history. Though, it has issues incl. unnecessary comedy that affects tone. Liked but didn't love.
If you are a fan of the book, you are bound to be pleased; no pun intended. The film takes bathroom humor to the next level and will bring you to tears from laughter.
movie_title: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Dark Knight Rises is underwhelming compared to it's two predecessor's yet Nolan still delivers a satisfying conclusion to his epic trilogy! See it in true 70mm IMAX!
Please give the film editor, Zachary Stuart-Pontier, an Oscar right now. With brilliant editing, great performances and great direction, this film will stick with you.
Is there anything Justin Timberlake can't do? Now, he's actually a decent action star!
The flick, whose advertisements were obviously channeling Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas, is a slow, sometimes intriguing, mess that lacks direction and rich characters.
Green Lantern is lifeless, lacks emotional connection, charisma, good special effects, a flowing story-line and everything else that makes a movie entertaining.
Bay has mastered and improved upon Cameron's technology to create a mind-blowing, nerd-tear shedding, action experience that is finally worth seeing in 3D!
As a standalone film, it delivers intense and engaging action. Though, I couldn't help but feel a bit underwhelmed by the final battle sequence we have waited ten years to see.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The flick's action sequences and cinematography save the film from the awful pacing and cheesy romance. The real star is the shield! Stay away from the post-converted 3D.
The film has a great emotional core amongst the raunchy sequences. The problem is that the film becomes the cheesy romantic comedy that it makes fun of for the first hour.
Underwhelming and disappointing. With five screenwriters, the film lacked substance and connection to the characters which made the decent action scenes appear worthless.
The Smurfs is uncomfortably cheesy and predictable. Kids truly deserve better films than this! The only redeeming quality was the performance from Hank Azaria.
Crazy, Stupid, Love is one of the more refreshingly original romantic comedies containing a beautiful script that is unpredictable, funny and dramatic. I love this film!
A terrifyingly shocking ground-breaking piece of cinema with great heart and action. Somebody please give Andy Serkis an Academy Award!
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's sad that the film could not live up to Dominic Cooper's epic performance(s). The flick had such a made-for-TV feel containing massive plot holes and a cheesy romance.
A rare and important film where every single performance stands out. The film finds a perfect balance between telling a tough story and keeping it very entertaining!
Stay away from all reviews/spoilers of this film, including mine, until you have seen it for yourself. If you're a fan of the series, you will not be disappointed.
Apollo 18 is a surprisingly intense, innovative and well-directed flick that made me jump out of my seat more than a few times!
Thanks to Contagion, I used a paper towel to open a bathroom door the other day and now I'm washing my hands more often. One of the scariest movies in years!
I cried three times! While a bit manipulative, I found myself emotionally invested in every character to the point where I could almost feel the punches!
A modern day masterpiece. I wish I could go back and watch it for the first time all over again.
It's hard not to be romantic about this film!
One of the worst films of 2011. The script and editing are so horrific that it made Sigourney Weaver and Alfred Molina, two great actors, look bad. Stay far away!
The overall story is better than the actual film. You can tell where Hollywood stepped in and fictionalized aspects of the story. It's still very inspirational and fun!
While the film has decent action sequences, the film is overly convoluted and very hard to follow at times. Wait for the rental!
The Ides of March is a masterfully written film with rapid-fire dialogue that has the intensity of a one-hundred minute action sequence.
Oddly enough, I was more emotionally connected to Atom the robot than I was to any human characters. The film is a perfect example of mediocre mindless fun!
Imagine the most vile, disturbing, disgusting, atrocious, violent, appalling, sick, twisted, sadistic, horrifying, lifeless, vomit-inducing thing you can think of.
Barely fresh considering director Craig Brewer essentially made a carbon copy of the original film just with less chemistry and a leading actor who sounded like Mark Whalberg!
How can a movie with these great actors/comedians be so unfunny?
It's sad that in 2011, CGI transformation effects pale in comparison to the brilliant creature make-up effects of John Carpenter's 1982 masterpiece.
The flick improves upon the second films' problems, but doesn't live up to the fresh vibe of the original. I still jumped out of my seat and screamed like a little girl!
The film is like enjoying a beautifully tender filet mignon where every bite is delicious. But, at the end you find a disgusting fungus-filled toe nail on the plate.
The Switch is a wonderfully cute flick that builds realistic chemistry between a father and son. Jason Bateman and Thomas Robinson have amazing emotional arcs.
Takers is unoriginal, overlong, extremely predictable and poorly written but does contain an on-foot Parkour chase sequence that almost saves the film.
80,000 gallons of fake blood, extreme violence, gore, terribly cheesy dialogue, legit scares, high tension, porn stars and a wet T-shirt contest all in 3D. Are you sold yet?
The Princess and the Frog is a beautifully vibrant film where every single character shines; not just the leads. Keith David voices a perfect villain.
Where is Richard Curtis when you need him?
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This is hands down my favorite animated film of 2009.
After a second viewing at a better theater, I feel this movie is more fresh than rotten. The stunning visuals are slightly better than the unoriginal plot and horrendous dialogue.
Downey Jr. puts a perfect spin on the character in Guy Ritchie's comeback film which contains the greatest slow-motion explosion scene I have ever seen.
There is a line of dialogue spoken by Meryl Streep that is worth the entire price of admission.
An unsatisfying sequel to a very mediocre first film. It is so unfunny and painful that I actually saw people walking out of the free screening I attended.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Barely fresh, Youth in Revolt stars Michael Cera pretty much playing the same character he always plays. The first act was hilarious but then goes downhill.
I feel like I have already reviewed this film 100 times. This time around, they plug in the wonderful Amy Adams and the typical romantic comedy still does not work.
Like The Wrestler but with more heart, Crazy Heart delivers brilliant performances from both Bridges and Gyllenhaal.
One of the best and most inventive vampire movies I have seen in a long time. Willem Dafoe rocks this ultra-violent film with great one-liners.
The more I think about this film, the more I love it. Book of Eli packs such a punch at the end that you will want to see it again to see if you catch certain details.
The inspirational story is better than the overall product, which contains mediocre performances and an annoyingly long ending. Invictus is a great rental.
It seemed as if all of the actors were reading their dialogue from a cue card. The Spy Next Door is already one of the worst films of 2010. Horrible.
It pains me to say that I actually enjoyed watching this film. Yes, it is sappy, cliche and unbelievably predictable but The Rock's character is so likable and funny.
The film deserves and Emmy award and yes, I am aware that the Emmy's are for television.
Legion makes absolutely no sense and while the action scenes are cool, the dialogue bits in between are way too drawn out and boring. The ending is so unsatisfactory.
We need more thought-provoking films like Creation in Hollywood.
If Payback and Ransom dated and had a child it would be called Edge of Darkness. Gibson and Winstone shine in this revenge film with a purpose.
Dear John is nothing to write home about.
The film bored me to tears on top of the crying I was already doing when Travolta spouted off a line from Pulp Fiction. I never thought action could be so boring.
Garry Marshall delivers a well-balanced romantic comedy that delivers the laughs and a classic Shirley MacLaine scene. Though, the film needed to lose about twenty minutes.
Baker's fantastic make-up effects together with great performances from Del Toro and Hopkins make this a fun experience. Don't expect an even plot and character development.
From every note of music to every frame of film and each performance, this picture brings a terrifying tale to screen that will stick in your mind for days.
Olyphant and Anderson deliver strong performances in this sometimes predictable yet sometimes surprising horror flick with an amazing last forty minutes.
Haven't I seen this movie before? I think it came out in 1995 and was co-written by Ice Cube.
While the film contains storytelling issues and an inconsistent tone, the intensity of Stanley Tucci's character blew me away. The film is visually stunning and worth seeing.
This is the type of original film that should be pulling in the box office numbers. Harrelson and Foster deliver completely natural and raw performances. See this movie now!
Armored has a decent second half but the use of obvious metaphors, cliches and amateur film making knocks the film down to a satisfactory rental.
A simple story told in a very unique way. I will never think of telephone wires the same ever again.
It was so refreshing to see a story told about true love that contained honest chemistry. Ben Wishaw should be nominated for Oscar right now.
The film ended and I went downstairs to see seven bags of trash in my kitchen. It was at that point, I felt I needed to change my living habits.
If slow-motion bloody zombie deaths set to Metallica's "For Whom The Bell Tolls" does not get you excited, I don't know what will. Zombieland is a great time.
Marcia Gay Harden and Ellen Page shine in Drew Barrymore's directorial debut. Shauna Cross' script is refreshingly original and you will feel great when you leave the theater.
The film has such a promising and hilarious start but there is nothing worse than feeling the comedy get sucked right out of a film.
Even Michael Moore's weakest and most convoluted film is an excellent documentary which will enlighten and scare you.
This is one of the the few films that actually lives up to all of the hype. Paranormal Activity is one of the scariest films I have seen since The Exorcist.
In one of the best directed films of 2009, the Coen Brothers use techniques that actually fit the frustrating mood of the film as opposed to using them just for a cool shot.
Vaughn and Favreau sprinkle in a couple of hilarious jokes throughout but that does not save this formulaic, cliché and horribly paced comedy
Jonze's 'Wild Things' is a masterpiece in direction and cinematography but needs work in the pacing department.
The overall moral focus is lost early on when the film turns into a highly entertaining and far-fetched action adventure. Butler hasn't been this good since 300.
Michael Moore would have a field day with this latest installment, where the writers tackle the health care system with Jigsaw as an answer.
An outstanding documentary that gives you an inside look into one of the greatest performers of all time. The only thing missing was a performance of "Dirty Diana."
Zemeckis brightens up the screen with beautiful visual effects but had trouble bringing anything new to this already amazing story that we have heard a million times before.
Men Who Stare at Goats is one massively long Star Wars joke that gets annoying quick.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Box is a fantastically made thriller that brilliantly captures the tone of the 70's and makes you ponder in a negative way about humanity.
There are three scenes in the film where I slowly brought my hand up to my mouth and became teary eyed because I was so frightened.
A love story that simultaneously left me speechless and with a mouth full of words. Mulligan's performance is the best I have seen from an actress in 2009.
How is it possible that a $250 million film can be less effective on it's audience than the $11,000 Paranormal Activity. The film is laughably bad.
Mo'Nique's Oscar worthy performance had the same scene stealing effect and relentless evil aura as Heath Ledger's Joker.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: New Moon lacks the chemistry and passion that made Twilight so special. The sequel focuses more on the gratuitous sex appeal of the two lead male stars.
Judging by the awful trailers, I did not think in a million years I would see a wonderful true story that perfectly balanced comedy and drama. Bullock was fantastic.
Painful.
The film has pacing issues but it should win an award for casting a brilliant young actor (Smit-McPhee) to carry this heavy drama. He steals the film.
Turn your brain off and turn up the blood splatter.
Hands down, one of the best films of 2009. Anna Kendrick steals the show in Jason Reitman's best film to date.
The trailers give away 99.9% of the film but I still recommend a viewing to see Tobey Maguire's breathtaking performance.
The Ghost Writer leaves you with a positive and intriguing feeling but suffered from odd character development which lessened the impact of the film's powerful ending
The film is like eating an amazing peanut butter and jelly sandwich except that Tim Burton forgot to cut off the crust. The beginning and the end could have been cut out.
As a massive fan of Mallrats and Clerks, it pains me to say that this film is too long, unfunny and painful. Luckily, Kevin Smith did not write it.
A film that delivers amazingly raunchy humor and a fun love story. Actor Nate Torrence steals the film with a scene that will literally make you laugh so hard you will cry.
Brooklyn's Finest is a realistic, disheartening and brutal look into the lives of three different cops at three different stages in their careers.
Vincenzo Natali has created a film that does not follow the normal Hollywood formula and takes insane risks. Chaneac delivers a phenomenal performance without using dialogue.
Have you seen True Lies? Well, then you have already seen Killers minus the great action scenes, great performances and a clever script.
Shockingly, The Karate Kid actually delivers a great story with great fight sequences and great heart. I found myself clapping and cheering at the end of the flick.
The A-Team does not have a single dull moment in between the unbelievably awesome action sequences and the perfect chemistry. Sharlto Copley steals the entire flick.
Solitary Man is the type of thought-provoking film that should be released in over 3,000 theaters. Michael Douglas and the supporting cast deliver great performances.
Dare I say that Toy Story 3 is a perfect film? Pixar, yet again, delivers a brilliant film that will make you laugh, cheer and even shed a few tears. Bravo!
The issues that happened behind the camera, including the original directors leaving the project, are extremely obvious in the final product. The film is a complete disaster.
Knight and Day is a fun and over-the-top action flick that delivers a great performance from Tom Cruise but needed work in the blue screen effects department.
There are really bad films and then there are painful films. Grown Ups falls into the latter category. The movie lost steam after ten minutes!
I am just as shocked as you are that there is a fresh tomato next to my review right now. Slade delivers a fun film that is completely self-aware and full of intensity.
Can we please just stop with the 3D conversions? Shymalan delivers visually amazing action sequences but the film suffers from terrible dialogue and horrible acting.
I don't understand how a film with a budget exceeding $150 million could only have mediocre special effects.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Mark and Jay Duplass have created an oddly original yet weird and natural film that interestingly balances out comedy and drama.
Despicable Me is hilarious and heart warming. The film makers found a perfect balance between using the 3D as a gimmick and using it for depth of field.
Inception is one of the most original, thought-provoking, intense, mind-blowing pieces of entertainment I have ever seen. I would pay money to watch people's reactions.
The Sorcerer's Apprentice is the product of a bad script, lifeless acting and predictable action. Jay Baruchel has already played this character two times this year.
Jolie completely rocks this fun, smart and unbelievably relentless action flick. Hopefully, this means we will see more actresses in leading action roles.
The overall film is a mess but the performances from Jemaine Clement, Lucy Punch and Zack Galafianakis make the flick worth watching. Catch the matinee price.
Zac Efron can act and has a very large emotional arc. The film is both devastating and very uplifting though it does fall on the cheesy side at times.
The 3D conversion is awful. The special effects are awful. The acting is awful. The movie is awful. Stay away from this movie.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Step Up 3-D is worth seeing for the amazing Fred Astaire homage sequence. Jon Chu nailed the longest 3D single-take shot in cinema history. The 3D was even great!
If you liked Anchorman as much I did, you will love The Other Guys. Ferrell is back! You will want to go out and the classic TLC album after the movie ends.
Add a tablespoon of 500 Days of Summer, a dash of Super Nintendo and a pinch of Street Fighter, and Scott Pilgrim Vs. The World is served. This movie is epic!
The Expendables should have been the greatest action movie ever made. Unfortunately, the film is a bit underwhelming. Luckily, Crews and Statham save the day.

Nimrod Antal has crafted an insanely action-packed science fiction flick while simultaneously paying homage to the original material and creating his own.

Get Him to the Greek is filled with consistent laughs and classic comedic moments. I never thought I would see the day where I would say that Diddy is a comedic genius.

Robert Pattinson can really act when he is supported by a great cast. As the film reached it's climax I slowly moved my hand over my mouth in shock.
While the film may be a bit too political, Greengrass delivers his signature style of film making which really sends you into the war zone with Matt Damon.
The Bounty Hunter is a good concept gone horrifically wrong. There are maybe three laughs in this unnecessarily complicated comedy that almost runs two hours.
Repo Men is a mess of a film but it's third act has an action scene that is so strong it is worth seeing. Two words for you; Hacksaw camera.
Corddry, Duke, Robinson and Glover steal the show in this absolutely hilarious comedy that has a great joke every five minutes. You will have to see it twice to catch it all.
Not only one of the best animated films in years but one of the best I've seen. James Cameron should take story-telling pointers from this flick.
Chloe is a bit of a mess when it comes to the story-telling but Moore and Seyfried deliver enough hot chemistry to keep an audience's interest until the final moments.
Seeing this film in 3D is like throwing your money in the trash. The flick is anti-climactic and the leading perfomance from Worthington was not heroic in the least.

I know this would never happen but Chloe Moretz deserves an Oscar for her performance as Hit-Girl. The film perfectly balances graphic stylized violence with major laughs.

In a world of two hour and thirty-minute films comes a funny, action-packed 87 minute flick that packs a great entertaining punch. Fey, Carell and Wahlberg are hilarious."

Both one of the most influential films ever made and one of the most rarely shown.
