To consider Harry and Max as being about incestuous feelings would be shortchanging it, because the film is really about the evolving nature of love and the need to define it.
The bleak absurdity of its predicaments cries out for a tone of pitch-dark comedy to stave off the unintended laughter that it is virtually certain to elicit.
For all the vivid, amusing characters that surround Gina, Beauty Shop rightly belongs to Latifah, who comes into her own as a star and an actress in this film.
What a delightful group they are -- sharp, witty, chic survivors who forged new lives and successful careers in new countries.
An example of popular folk art at its most endearing, and while the film is filled with considerable grace, as a mass entertainment it has not an ounce of subtlety.
Smile is like a dose of cod liver oil: It may be good for you, but it's no fun.
A graceful ensemble piece with effective performances from the entire cast.
A slight sex comedy that would work far better on stage than screen, where it seems far too talky and too slow.
The film is a terrific scare show, fast and furious, made with a lot of style and energy, packing plenty of jolts yet never lingering morbidly over horrific images.

The Take plays out like a Frank Capra movie with the 'little people' taking on corrupt and indifferent officials. In the process the film strikes a strong blow for the dignity of labor and introduces an array of brave individuals.
A film that takes a steadfastly gentle look at some of life's harshest moments while not overlooking its joys.
Kontroll is that singular success, a thoroughly satisfying, rambunctious entertainment that also subtly works on philosophical and spiritual levels.

Opens explosively and never lets up, with Lee Tamahori (Die Another Day) in full command of the action and Simon Kinberg an equally astute writer with a flair for linking socko action set pieces with terse characterization.

Alternately witty, caustic, tender and endlessly imaginative and unpredictable, this latest film from one of Korea's most idiosyncratic and prolific directors is as confident as its resourceful hero, Tae-suk.
A pleasure from start to finish.
A film so enchanting one hates to see it come to an end.

There are some inspired off-the-wall moments, but they are more than offset by a pervasive aura of tedium and the lack of any sense of the forward momentum necessary to sustain an adventure of this kind.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: An elegantly told tale of obsession.
Oliveira establishes a sense of timelessness only to catch his audience up short with a film that ultimately could scarcely be a more timely comment on the world in which we live.
Astutely directed by Alain Corneau.
It has a droll sensibility but is marred by dirge-like pacing.
They are an appealing, vulnerable group, and the film is a showcase for its gifted young actors.
Evokes time and place without being showy about it and offers an altogether invigorating experience.
Wildly uneven, constantly veering between honest emotions and insights and bald manipulation and contrivance.
A full-bodied, all-stops-out love story with a wrenching impact that makes most of today's screen romances seem undernourished by comparison.
Suggests that Russia is such a progressive society these days that homophobia can be treated in jaunty fashion as a joke, something that's harmless and transitory. This strains credibility.
Uncle Nino is strictly straightforward and utterly conventional yet has been made with the kind of caring and commitment that will connect with many viewers.
To reappraise it after nearly 40 years only brings a richer appreciation of Godard's subtlety, sly humor and depth of perception, and his gift for melding nonchalance and profundity.
At heart a reverie, a meditation on the past and its treacheries, the ways in which people become flawed, and the eternal though often elusive possibility of forgiveness and redemption.
Simply too tedious and stretched out to be amusing.
In the depth of its insight Beautiful Boxer in its unique way is as accomplished as any classic boxing movie, such as Body and Soul, Champion, The Set-Up, Rocky or even Raging Bull.

Painfully well-intentioned, the film is undone by a lead character who undermines any goodwill earned by the performances of John Corbett, Amy Smart, Clare Higgins, Allan Corduner, Patty Duke and Sean Astin.
The trouble is that with its lengthy running time Nobody Knows becomes grueling and drawn-out.
Although this is the kind of entertainment designed to send its audience home happy, Ice Princess has its share of stinging moments and has a good deal more edge than one might have expected.
A film of polished ensemble performances, burnished period interiors and fine landscapes, but it's a little bloodless.
The picture is a bust, a grimly unfunny comedy with no connection to reality, and worst of all, running on and on for two dismal hours.
Has sufficient mayhem to please Diesel's action fans while allowing the star to reach out to family audiences.

Even the viewer who finds the premise too far-fetched to accept may nonetheless come away impressed with the ambitiousness of the attempt and even be moved by the emotional effect of the film's well-staged concluding sequence.

Comic relief is often welcome in drama, but these broad caricatures, which draw easy laughter as the minstrel turns they are, destroy the sense of reality that a large and hardworking cast is otherwise striving to create.
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Made with energetic flair and no small dose of violence, mercifully handled with discretion, Hostage exemplifies taut, confident filmmaking.
Unfortunately more didactic than dramatic, and although surprises emerge right up to the end, there's precious little suspense, mystery or uncertainty.
Well crafted and flat-out cool.

An icky love triangle develops between mother, daughter, and spirit, but this still has some laughs, thanks mainly to a neighboring gay couple and a ghost-hunting crew calling themselves SPIT (Super Paranormal Investigation Team).
Booker sparkles in the archival performance clips, and director Lily Keber wisely homes in on his live solo performances, bringing out his character and talent.
Clooney can't quite decide what he wants to make. A retro screwball comedy? A romance? A rough-and-tumble underdogs farce? A parable about how we invent our heroes?

None of this is anything we haven't seen countless times before in rom-com land, of course, and it would be giving the filmmakers way too much credit to say they have entertainingly tweaked a winning but cob-webbed formula.
Throughout, Green's command of time and place proves unfaltering, carefully unspooling revelations that surprise, enlighten and haunt to the bitter end.
What happened in Vegas should have stayed in Vegas.
It's more disjointed than stirring, more listless than wounding and mostly a misfire -- despite some memorable performances and the fittingly desolate backdrop of Saskatchewan.
Awards season may still be many months away, but it's not too early to declare both the filmmaker and Jenkins Oscar-worthy.
What's the difference between a vasectomy and Baby Mama? Baby Mama only lasts 93 minutes.
Like so many thrillers with crooked moral backbones, Street Kings glamourizes the very behaviour it's condemning, lest audiences get bored by too much talk and not enough killing.
What a waste. It's easy to see how Kingdom would have benefited from focusing on the interplay between its superstars. At times they're like kung-fu Ernie and Bert (minus the sexual tension).
Funny Games may be too skillfully executed and acted to dismiss, but it is also easily despised and certain to be loathed.
Like the Holocaust survivor who occupies its wounded centre, Jeremy Podeswa's elegant, stern adaptation of Anne Michaels' novel Fugitive Pieces keeps us quietly, intractably, at a distance.

As eye-rolling as the premise sounds, and as awful as the trailers make it look, The Ruins is a cut -- or slash, hack and chop, as it were -- above other lowest-common-denominator shockers about victimized vacationers (yes, I mean you, Hostel).

Thanks to director Mark Palansky's understated direction -- the fantastical trappings never overwhelm the characters -- and especially with the performances of Ricci and McAvoy, it emerges a charming diversion.
I Am Legend may be the umpteenth variation on the post-apocalyptic zombie genre, but, for the first two-thirds, it's nervy and haunting and creepily adroit.
The first 15 minutes of Vantage Point are the worst. Then you only have to sit through them seven more times.
One of this year's most accomplished entertainments.
Lurches between sappiness and self-consciousness -- resulting in a movie which, for all its charms, fails to convince on either dramatic or whimsical terms.
It knows what it is and never purports to be anything but efficient and engrossing.
As entertaining as a sugar-addled 5-year-old, Speed Racer left me feeling like I'd been in a hit and run with a box of Crayolas.
Beowulf is a spellbinder for the senses -- immersive, electrifying, a landmark for techno-fetishist Robert Zemeckis and his throngs of giga-nerd worker drones.

It's novel, it's amusing and it can't help but peter out in the third act as the screenplay trucks toward a Big Apple showdown between good and evil. By this time, Enchanted is merely coasting on Adams' considerable charm. It's enough.
After four jock-themed comedies in three years, Semi-Pro -- his latest reiteration of growth-stunted masculinity -- can't help but make you feel it's time he benched the routine.
Awkward, a tad loopy but unmistakably engaging.
Book of Secrets isn't just outlandish or ludicrous -- these are embraceable qualities -- but stupefying lazy.
For a satire to bite, someone has to draw blood.
There may be little here we haven't seen before, but rarely has it been executed this expertly.

Like any diagnosis, things here can go one of two ways and -- considering the presence of its acting titans -- it's not a stretch to hope the film would traffic in truth, profundity or the slightest ounce of soulfulness.
U2 3D is no less than an electrifying, immersive marvel of music, showmanship and spectacle.

While [director McDonagh] proves less skilled at managing a plot-driven narrative, sensational performances from all involved -- Farrell, dangerous and dim, hasn't been this natural in ages -- more than shoulder the burden.
A low point in the tear-stained history of sappy, shallow chick drivel.
Ultimately, though, the story is defined by searing turns from the enjoyably crotchety Burstyn and Horne, who shepherds Hagar from prideful wild child to soul-sapped middle-aged mother.
Writer-director Kevin Smith has his mind in the gutter and his heart on his sleeve. The result is hilarious and heart-warming, a raucous farce that's disarming, date-safe and, yes, sweet.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As with any class reunion, the pleasure of this Indiana Jones entry isn't so much what happens, as who you're with.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Warm, wise CG animated fable.
Fortunately, amid all the slavishly photographed grotesquery, there's comic relief. It's called the script.
Pound for pound, it's a hefty disappointment.
The movie itself is a comedic anachronism, out of step with this post-Judd Apatow world.
Is it supposed to be an intense, character-driven tale set against an alien invasion, a la Signs? Or an effects-blowout such as Independence Day? The filmmakers never reconcile between the two.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: In addition to Brolin, others in the superb supporting cast include Emile Hirsch as activist Cleve Jones, Canadian Alison Pill as campaign manager Anne Kronenberg and Franco as a man increasingly uncomfortable at being in the eye of the Milk-spun storm.
Of the movie's misaligned stars, it's Vaughn who emerges the least damaged.
OMG -- I'm so totally not a teenage girl.
What this mutt lacks in uniqueness it makes up for in puppyish charm, high-class velocity and enough pop culture crackle to keep most demographics suitably amused.

That Soul Men proves an entertaining-enough diversion has less to do with the pedestrian screenplay and direction than the high-wattage, crowd-pleasing showmanship of Mac and co-star Samuel L. Jackson.
Saw V or High School Musical 3? Make your choice. All of a sudden, picking between self-mutilation and disembowelment doesn't sound so frightening, does it?
What Just Happened is like a middle-aged Entourage in desperate need of Viagra.
[Jolie] is never less than convincing slipping into the cloche and shapeless garments of Christine Collins, a single mother living in 1928 Los Angeles whose nine-year-old son Walter goes missing.
To use a 1980s sex-comedy metaphor, Sex Drive is to Superbad what Hot Dog: The Movie was to Fast Times at Ridgemont High.

Given the giga-talent involved -- virtuoso visualist Scott, The Departed's William Monahan adapting Washington Post columnist David Ignatius's novel -- I was hoping for something more substantive than Syriana-meets-Spy Game.
Director Jonathan Demme's latest isn't so much enjoyed or savoured as appreciated, even admired, for its skill and daring.
In the words of another famous talking dog, Beverly Hills Chihuahua looks like something for me to poop on.

This collision of sensibilities may be funnier than much of Sandler's recent repertoire, but it's also a clumsy, scattershot fiasco that's more likely to offend those with astute comedic taste than anyone on either side of the Israeli-Palestine equation.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sure helps scrub away memories of Tenacious D and the Pick of Destiny.
If Lee's talky flop was the action, this is simply the opposite -- and pretty close to incredible -- reaction.
[Director] Peter Segal smoothly transitions between slapstick, banter and stunt-work.
This is the summer's most dangerous, delirious jolt to the system.
Hellboy II: The Golden Army may not be a masterpiece -- del Toro is capable of much more -- but it is whip-smart, pain-stakingly crafted and exuberant.
Spurlock approaches the state of the Middle East -- and therefore our world -- with an asinine every-dude-ness that isn't just simple-minded but wincingly self-absorbed.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Locked in a struggle for Gotham's soul, this Batman and Joker are mesmerizing, unforgettable and, yes, complete.
Non-discriminating audience members would be just as well served by re-visiting Rocky, Hoosiers, Rudy or even Remember the Titans.
Traitor is a thriller as fascinating and frustrating as its cagey, conflicted protagonist.
While he's seeing dead people, we're witnessing nothing less than the breakthrough role of Hollywood's next comic mega-star.
Throughout, the repartee between Harris and Mortensen never feels less than broken-in and believable.
The dialogue alone in Nights in Rodanthe made me choke back tears. It's like being pepper-sprayed that way.
This is a meaty, thematically ambitious political potboiler.
The discombobulated violence that ensues is nihilistic, gratuitous and numb-skulled -- perfect for an action fossil that, despite its near-future setting, is all pre-CGI, pre-eco-friendly horsepower.
Want to know what a gifted actress Cate Blanchett is? Watch her keep a straight face throughout Elizabeth: The Golden Age.
Fincher has made what may very well be his masterpiece.
A second-rate Trainspotting.

LeBeouf makes for a likeable, ankle-bracelet-saddled sleuth, while Caruso confidently ratchets the suspense. Even the romantic subplot -- never advised in a taut thriller such as this -- is winning enough to make it a welcome distraction.
It acknowledges the lure of urban sprawl is as every bit as phony yet intoxicating as the tug of cinema itself.
The comedy might stumble as nearly as much as it glides, but there is more than enough sheer, side-splitting absurdity to justify your attention and admission.
As much a moving, mesmerizing exploration of loss and unrequited yearning as it is a nerve-rattling crime yarn.
The movie emerges in the end as a stirring and -- cover your ears, kids -- educational ode to the political power an individual with a cause can inflict on the morally bankrupt status quo.
Director Antoine Fuqua chooses to numb, rather than engage.
Could it have been worse? Yes, it could have been 120 minutes.
A dry, depressing film that, frankly, isn't entertaining enough to make anyone but the truly masochistic fork over $14 to hear how the world as we know it is going to end.
movie_title: A Crude Awakening: The Oil Crash (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [An] evocative, heartbreaking documentary told from three disparate but equally compelling perspectives: the Sunnis, Shiites and Kurds.
I'll give the filmmakers this: They had me calculating the instances 23 appears in my own life. Trust me, it helps pass the time until the closing credits.
Too bad what should have been an epic clash of comic misdeeds feels, in the end, defanged.
It's hardly a profound insight, but the film is well-executed and well-acted and therefore recommended, thumbs and all.
Catherine Hardwicke's Lords of Dogtown works as both an energetic thrill ride and a keenly-felt drama about boys gone wild.
In treating its blaze-battling subjects with such reverence, the filmmakers douse the storytelling sparks that are so desperately required.

For all the suspense it generates, Fracture succeeds because it recognizes that, like a courtroom itself, the legal-thriller genre is an arena for actors to breathe and snort and poke and prod at each other's weak points.
Admiration? Yes. Exhilaration? Sadly, no.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: [Kentis and Lau] play on a litany of basic human fears -- abandonment, among them -- with shattering, savage results.
The film simply isn't funny enough to please the adolescent fans who want pratfalls and will instead have to squirm through agonizingly-penned scenes of '80s nostalgia and male-bonding murk.
A royal pain.
A white-knuckler so well-realized that it nearly defies the limitations of its action-thriller genre.
A sloppy, schlocky piece of work.
If the Terminator went back in time to win a game of Dungeons and Dragons, it'd be a lot like The Chronicles of Riddick.
It tries to be many things, fails at most of them, but emerges as surprisingly serviceable entertainment, a silly slick piece of trash.
About as funny as ebola, but lasts three times as long.
Darker, scarier, funnier and more fun-filled.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The only thing more tedious than watching this computerized bore would be downloading it through a phone line.
All the amped-up Tony Hawk-style stunts and thrashing rap-metal can't disguise the fact that, really, we've been here, done that.
An adventure sure to satisfy both the fans of J.R.R. Tolkien's classic and those neophytes who have never turned one of its pages.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: These days a comedy starring a Saturday Night Live performer is the cinematic equivalent of a dental cleaning.
It's Little Nicky-awful.
A cluttered overwrought thriller.
As scripted and directed by Mike Cahill, King of California reveals itself to be a moving, bemusing gem embellished by standout work from Douglas and the habitually marvellous Evan Rachel Wood.

Spider-Man 3 isn't a bad film -- many scenes, taken on their own, are thrilling and even moving -- but it indicates a downward spiral that leaves you not wanting to see what's in store for Spider-Man 4, but rather, dreading it.
There are worse things than waking up in a morgue. Like, say, waking up and realizing there's another hour of Rise: Blood Hunter to go.
Reviewing Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead is like critiquing a belch.
movie_title: Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A spellbinder of desire, hurt and nerve-rattling betrayal.
Ace work from all involved...
Johnson, as he's proven before, has all the stuff movie stars do. Well, except a decent script.
Never feels much more than a softly-lit, meandering, slightly senile made-for-cable television movie.
For much of its scant 96 minutes Mimzy is rudderless in a muddle of metaphysical malarkey and time-travelling science fiction.
You can afford to avoid Captivity.
This is a masterpiece.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: That Sydney White is as tolerable as it is -- you're more likely to gently nod off than storm out of the theatre in a rage -- is due largely to the presence of Amanda Bynes.
Let me say that I have seen this hump-obsessed raunch-com, but you haven't. And, hopefully, you'll be working to keep it that way.
The actors, unquestionably and predictably, are leagues better than the material deserves.
If you don't recognize Samuel L. Jackson at first in Resurrecting the Champ, it may be because the movie is actually good.
The music in the film is exhilarating, but there isn't enough information about anyone or anything, and the film feels slight overall. And scattered. You'll leave hungry for more.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Super-awesome -- a miracle of crudeness and charm that counters its coarseness with sincerity.
Fresnadillo, who also co-wrote the screenplay, understands that true horror lies in the moral choices men and women make in the direst of circumstances.
If none of this sounds particularly new or inventive, that's because it isn't. Darwin never said 'Cowabunga,' but he did know you evolve or you die.
My dog has the common sense to know his limitations. But then he's probably got an IQ point or 50 on poor Andy, if Hot Rod is indicative of how deep the waters of Lake Samberg go.
Director Paul Greengrass hasn't manufactured a sequel -- he's written code for a template all future Bonds, Ryans and whoever-the-hell-else will have to match or stumble and die trying.
Some performances are so good, you forget they're faking it. Case in point: Richard Gere's electrifying, career-best turn in The Hoax as famed huckster Clifford Irving.
From the sly, satiric opening sequence to the buttons-bursting finale, this is a rollicking roly-poly high point for the modern movie musical.
This third outing sadly lacks in ambition and, at times, even offers the whiff of sitcom plotting and plodding.
Bride of Silence has plenty to say. It's just too bad it couldn't speak it more clearly.

Audiences outside gay cinema will, frankly, probably find it too callow to emotionally invest in. However, for those who do see it, they will likely be surprised, and entertained, by its arch insights and near-camp bearing.
At every turn, despite treading familiar territory, You Kill Me stands elevated above the gangster glut.
Want to enjoy License to Wed? Go in expecting to have your eyes gouged out. I promise you'll be pleasantly surprised.
It's as juvenile as it exhilarating, as staggeringly-stupid as it is keenly well-crafted.
Ratatouille is not merely the smartest, funniest, most joyous, most lovingly crafted film of the summer thus far, but it ranks among Pixar's finest.
1408 ranks as the summer's smartest, spookiest surprise.
Evan Almighty emerges as nothing more than a preachy, overpriced sitcom.
As was the case with the inept 2005 original, the sequel is a shallow, shoddy, slap-dash mess of ideas and performances.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Whimsy and wit are the prevailing special effects of Stardust.
This is the season's most satisfying, heart-tugging surprise.
Instead of being disquieting or particularly exciting, it's loud, over-directed and merely serviceable.
As vacuous and disposable as Hollywood comedies come. I'd say it's preferable to rabies, but having never had rabies, I can't be sure, can I?
For cinephiles with sick senses of humour and fond memories of digging through bins of VHS tapes in grungy video stores in the 1980s, Hobo is, in simplest terms, heavenly.

Ask yourself: Should Alice in Wonderland have had steampunk Nazi zombies and leather chaps? Would One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest have been better if Nurse Ratched was Polish and played by Cher (specifically the Cher from Burlesque)?
Give props to the filmmakers behind Battle: Los Angeles for manufacturing an otherworldly attack that's as brutal, relentless and thoroughly unpleasant as the real thing might be.
Enjoy it for what it is. Just don't ponder what might have been.
Compelling performances and frequent bursts of excitement nevertheless warrant an opposable digit, pointed up.
Portman, far more dimensional than the genre norm, makes the film almost feel real and relatable. Again, I stress, almost.
At least Seth Rogen has the good sense to wear a mask for much of The Green Hornet. If I'd made this movie, I'd want to hide my face too.
Boozing, cheating, weeping, backstabbing, pill-popping -- Country Strong plays more like a honky-tonk jukebox than a movie.

Give it to the Coens then: for all the mayhem and marble-mouthed exchanges about morality and machismo, their film is also remarkably appealing, populated by characters who are lacerating, loopy and defiantly capable of surprising each other.
Now I've got nothing against introducing young audiences to "classic" characters from bygone, pre-Xbox eras. But why do they all have to feel so corporate, so soulless, so creatively leaden?
The Fighter, stirring and unshakable, is never as merciless and emotional, as traumatic and triumphant, as when the gloves are off.
Judged solely as eye-candy, the follow-up, enriched by a superb soundscape crafted by Daft Punk, merits a recommendation. But as optically impressive as it is, it's also dramatically inert.
In Faster, the cliches -- er, characters -- aren't named, they're labelled. (Better to keep track of them that way.)
If in past Potters -- especially the early ones -- Radcliffe, Watson and Grint were wisely surrounded by one acting legend after another, here they're called on to shoulder the story on their own.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: My advice: Enjoy and appreciate the film for the inventive, well-acted immersive adventure it is -- even if it is about eight minutes too long.
Kinetic, clever and even emotionally satisfying.
Relentlessly sadistic, stupefying and slick. In other words, it's a roaring -- actually, more like high-pitched shrieking -- success. And I can't think of one reason why anyone should see it.

Not that I'm complaining, mind you. The plot may be as creaky as the knees of its cast members, but as broad, big-budget spy yarns go, this is one that surprisingly doesn't require a nip, tuck or lift.
Disappointingly facile... despite an understated, observant turn from Galifianakis.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Harrowing and heartfelt, this is one of the best films I've seen this year.
As delicate and docile as its doomed doe-eyed clones, Never Let Me Go has a soul -- just not much of a pulse.
Michael Douglas is tremendously-serpentine; Oliver Stone's direction is energetic and acute; and this sequel to their 1987 Oscar-winning original purrs with snark and style. Then the bubble bursts.
Everything is adorable about Kristen Bell except her taste in material.
As a performer, Stone is neither a vapid plastic-enhanced bimbo nor so surly as to not be appealing. She has star wattage and strut -- and she's utterly confident carrying a movie solo.
Funny, warm and snappily-paced by German-Turkish director Fatih Akin, it should satisfy audiences in the mood for comfort food.
A mostly-mangled splicing of ideas and themes, one that never seems convinced of its own identity.
Only a film-going hermit -- at least as isolated as Robert Duvall's cantankerous mountain man -- would fail to appreciate the rarity and reward of Get Low.
How many times have we seen Cruise or Harrison Ford or Bruce Willis evade pursuers or, when the need arises, disable them? The sex change makes what transpires feel fresh -- and unpredictable.
The final half-hour alone is a miracle of clockwork-precise showmanship.
For all their foiled schemes, super-villains usually win the day with audiences. So is it any wonder actors prefer playing charismatic, fiendish outlaws over leaden, square-jawed do-gooders?
Stone is neither high-minded nor low-brow enough. Instead it's stuck in the middle -- in purgatory.

Up to the challenge, and clearly relishing roles of unusual substance, are Moore, Ruffalo and Bening -- who could well nab an Oscar nomination for her work as an iron-willed smother-mother for the ages.
Bourne meets the Big Bad Wolf in Hanna, a techno-action fable about a teenage girl groomed to be an assassin.
This installment is nowhere near the hip, serrated-edge blast of newness the original was in 1996. Suddenly, it's the horror thriller that, like, your parents are excited about.
Contemplative, sumptuous and haunting, this is one of the year's best films.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The surprise of the 3D animated adventure How to Train Your Dragon isn't that once again the digitally-rendered creatures dazzle -- it's that the movie does too.
It struggles (ironically) to establish its own identity. Bourne himself, it turns out, casts too great a shadow.
A feel-good documentary about a cheerful guy who's not made out of felt (but probably would be just as cheerful if he was).
Both an awesome Muppet outing and an epically entertaining comedy, period.
More than the ice is thin in Happy Feet Two.
What becomes clear is that while the bisecting of J.K. Rowling's hefty tome was artistically defensible, here, there's no such creative imperative.
J. Edgar may be well-made and well-acted, but it's also bloodless, unfocused and at times regrettably dull.

For all the gob-smacking violence, the most glaring clash here isn't between otherworldly deities and their worshippers, but between the artistry of the gifted director Tarsem Singh and the requirements of a formulaic Hollywood blockbuster.
Because it's based on real people and events, it carries unquestionable emotional heft despite its equally undeniable flaws.

The shakiest scenes in Breakaway, a hockey-meets-Bollywood mash-up about skating Sikh-Canadians, occur on the ice. Take that for what you will. The rest of this nimbly-paced but routinely-plotted sports fable is tolerably more entertaining.

Most children's entertainment feels as sugar-addled as their target audience. But Dolphin Tale avoids being either anxious or obnoxious, keeping young moviegoers amused and enthralled the old-school way: with its story and star.

Ask yourself: Would The Parallax View and Three Days of the Condor be better with scissor kicks? Are The Conversation and Marathon Man a few dislocated bones short of greatness? Even if you answered yes, you should lower your expectations.
It's not a bad film, per se, but it's more adequate than entertaining, more routine than recommendable.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Take off the beer goggles if you think Arthur was a classic. Put them back on if you plan on seeing the needless remake.
Like its predecessor, this Straw Dogs lights a long, deliberate fuse from its opening deer hunt to its climactic home invasion. These days, that's called restraint.
A film that's a powerhouse for all the old-school reasons: a tremendous cast, identifiable characters you care about and a story that both excites and moves.
The result is as scarring and engrossing as it is fascinating, infuriating and profound.

Less committed filmgoers probably won't be quite as enthused -- Potter has long been a franchise constructed to please readers of the books first -- but should be sufficiently entertained nonetheless.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: I realize Hanks, who also directed, wanted to make an upbeat, positive character study about rebounding in the face of unemployment and hardship. But did a story so hopeful also have to be so harmless? When did the everyman become the generic man?
A clanging, thrashing threequel that represents a near-complete upgrade over 2009's critically-despised Revenge of the Fallen.
Diaz, always a deft comic, makes the most as this potty-mouthed party girl whose age is bearing down on her.
A sequel with a lot of horse power under the hood, but little else.
Mr. Popper's Penguins finds Carrey in an agreeable groove, gliding smoothly.
Considering all the characters and subplots, it's no surprise Green Lantern feels more rushed and truncated than epic.
A comedy about young kids for young kids that feels like it was made by young kids.
movie_title: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Though it hews to the template of the original, director Todd Phillips has one strategy to fall back on: Upping the ante.
As for the sequel's use of 3D, other than the odd sword being jabbed at you, it's inconsequential.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A funny, fleet documentary that is marvelously meta.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: In the context of a social studies class, The Conspirator would make for a fascinating, informative two hours; on the big screen, it just feels like, well, a social studies class.
Seeing Contagion in a crowded theatre is like watching Jaws on a life raft. Bring hand sanitizer. Or bleach. And maybe soap and a bucket of warm water.

Less involving -- at least for this non-tween-girl -- is the love triangle that, for all its plaintive yearning after three movies, still never feels like it's scratched the frequently shirtless surface.
For audiences intrigued by, if not addicted to, stardom's nature, Grenier's film proves an entertaining, satisfying excursion.
All I know is, the end couldn't come fast enough.
The results here are more grueling than imaginative, more moronic than madcap.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A vapid vanity project that swaddles its smugness in the guise of profundity.
As Henry and Clare figure out for themselves, it's best not to overthink things. Audiences seeking escapist date fare are likewise advised.
A late-summer jolt of serious science-fiction juice that marries breathless action to political satire and poignant drama.
For what it is, A Perfect Getaway is absorbing and effective, largely due to Twohy's muscular direction and more-intriguing-than-you-expect work from the actors.

What some will relate to as authentic and real, others will dismiss as sluggish and meandering. But in a summer besieged by empty spectacles and plastic sitcom lameness, Cyrus emerges as a daring, disarming alternative.
This isn't just a lacerating drama about the wages of war on a soldier's soul, but also the most exhilarating, sweat-inducing action film of the year thus far.

Recommended for children under 10 and parents who don't want their kids exposed to anything more corrupting than adorable boy-and-his-dog cliches. If that passes for praise, then you can blurb me on that.
True, it's as contrived as the genre gets, but it nevertheless left me mourning the movie that might have been.
This is cinematic poetry for pinheads. It's less of a film than a reason for a noise ordinance. But for the faithful -- action aficionados and Transformers disciples -- it indisputably delivers.
It's got spunk and charm and two skillful stars in Bullock and Reynolds, who make it all feel much less generic than it is.
Enough of a pressure cooker -- with sufficient psychological crackle -- to recommend.
Are we supposed to laugh? Or wince? Or both? If director Sam Mendes knows, he's not telling.
It's the gentle, believable father-daughter chemistry between Murphy and Shahidi that emerges as the film's most impressive effect; it's enough.
No question, the world Acker conjures is a knockout.
What a magical, marvellous movie.
Of the cast, Worthington -- as a man unexpectedly granted a chance at redemption -- gives the most deeply felt performance, but honestly, that's not saying much.
In a movie as spiritless and stupid as this, you can't help but look for clues you've hit bottom.
When they're on-screen together, it's better than electrifying -- it's rhapsodic.
Efron, frankly, lacks the comic agility required for a role this nimble; he's as elastic as hard plastic.
A misguided head-spinner of conflicting tones, listless lead performances and dashed expectations.
How much you're entertained will likely depend on your own taste as well as your appreciation for Hill's subversion of feel-good Hollywood norms.
it rang pitch-perfect: Poignant and honest, with such a keenly felt eye toward period detail
Blame a script that, despite its early promise, goes nowhere.
Only Elias Koteas' work as a pained preacher manages to resonate, suggesting a quality this production otherwise sorely lacks -- soul.
Even if it never musters the lacerating intensity, the unsettling claustrophobia, of Lumet's original, it scores points for sheer audacity.

In many ways, it's a thriller undone by its scale; the premise, which is undeniably fascinating, would have been better served by a smaller budget and tighter focus -- anchored not by explosions, but by psychology, mood and suspense.
Ultimately Watchmen is simply too stunning, too audacious, too strange a spectacle, to not recommend, although it's more readily admired than enjoyed.
A scattershot ensemble piece that exceeds its reach in its retelling of the origins of Chicago's Chess label.

Throughout, the people on-screen -- from the Bielskis to the huddled masses they shelter -- feel less like flesh and blood people than stock characterizations designed to forward a specific ideological agenda or plot point of the movie.
A painful, slapdash, unfunny, gross, inane debacle -- a comedy without a clue, a spoof without any sense of sport.

It is, in the end, a migraine in search of a movie-goer, one that hypocritically berates pop-culture's bloodthirst even as it eagerly quenches it with a sadistic barrage of severed limbs and crushed skulls.
A buoyant, whimsical charmer that glides by on wry laughs and movie-star magnetism.
Troubling news from the future: we'll perfect robotics, but still be unable to master a decent toupee.
To his credit, writer-director Jamie Thraves avoids the absurd twists and abrupt jolts audiences have come to expect from thrillers, instead maintaining a slow, deliberate burn.

Again, its leading man remains the most compelling component of this franchise.

It squanders both its source (the book is better-realized and more politically pointed) and the goofball interplay between its actors.
If only the imaginations behind The Back-up Plan were as fertile as its heroine.

Only the cast -- led by Whitaker and Mencia as they begrudgingly bond between squabbling sessions -- makes it bearable.
The beguiling Wasikowska tethers the arcane anarchy with weight and emotional clarity, anchoring us as moviegoers to Alice's plight in both universes, up and under.
It spares us the disturbing sight of a decent film being haplessly eviscerated for its brand name. By that standard, The Crazies is insanely good.

So while Shutter Island may be flawed, when you consider the lobotomized state of most Hollywood thrillers, it's tough to complain too much about the work of a master -- no matter how schizophrenic it is.
The humour may be coarse, but the characters -- whatever their quirks -- are not.
Grown Up Movie Star is unruly, tortured, crisis-prone, nervy, melodramatic and just charming enough to make you forgive all of the above. It's like a teenager that way.
As audacious experiments go, it is a flawed one, but unforgettably so.
This is Mulligan's showcase, and she is a revelation, evolving from carefree sprite to self-assured woman, unbroken by heartache but shaped by it nonetheless.
Too bad though, that for all the eye-popping spirits on screen, it lacks a soul.
Twihards will be OMG, OMG, OMG. The rest of us? ROTFL.
This simply doesn't have the right stuff.
Most popsicles have more layers than the characters in Frozen.
Just because a movie has over-sexed blonds, lusty teens, roasted birds, a fire, a plane crash, self-mutilation and Charlize Theron's breasts doesn't mean it won't be bad. But it shouldn't be boring.

Buoyant, timely and bittersweet, Up in the Air finds Reitman at cruising altitude, confidently in the same airspace once occupied by zeitgeist masters Billy Wilder and Hal Ashby. This is the year's best film.
All of it will doubtlessly satisfy fans seeking some substance with their style.
Hardwired for hyperbole, as sensational as it is ridiculous, Avatar is, simply, a feat of fearless imagination and audacity.
Stick that in your pipe and smoke it.
In this case, for audiences - staggered and shamed by the epic size of it -- a picture is worth 1,000 Greenpeace protesters.

movie_review_blurb: As misguided and mystifying as it may sound at first, the Australian claymated Mary and Max turns out to be a hugely pleasurable and moving surprise.

A valentine as well as a poison pen letter to good-golly-it's-Bollywood.

This is a poignant, warm film with moments of humour.

movie_review_blurb: As much about the ethos of The Who and how it evolved as it is about their managers, Lambert & Stamp is essential for anyone with a passing interest in the band and the era in which they were at their prime.

The second half of the film devolves into something that resembles tedious, melodramatic daytime TV.
Fans of the stage play might have an invested interest, but with the exception of a few technical achievements, this isn't a musical with anything to say (much less sing).

Director/writer/producer Andrea Meller gives audiences an entertaining narrative about friendship, family, the challenge of being a Latino actor living in L.A.
Filmmaker Tim Burton strays slightly from his wheelhouse, but it's a welcomed change of pace.
Director Scott Dow and writer/actor Tim Ogletree have made a flick with zero laughs and no creative drive whatsoever.
Oscar-winning screenwriter Aaron Sorkin pens the type of fast-paced, clever and sardonic dialogue he lives for, but also gives Jobs a series of personal demons to exorcise.

Takes the research, analysis, interviews, red tape, dead ends and backroom politics of investigative journalism and turns it into an art form.

movie_review_blurb: There's a sense of hope that resonates with a character as confident as Wadjda that can't be ignored.

It's the year's most well-crafted dramatic thriller on both a technical and emotional level.
A noteworthy lead performance by Oscar Isaac.

The most unique script produced in the last five years.

movie_review_blurb: Man in the Middle, despite its restrictive one-hour runtime, is an effective biography that allows viewers to see this explosive era through the eyes of a Mexican-American who wrote the truth so he could make a difference.
movie_title: Ruben Salazar: Man In The Middle (2014)

Part talking-head documentary, part second-rate reenacted drama, Rebel is never quite sure what it wants to be and ends up playing both sides halfheartedly.
An adoring and inspirational portrait of one man's "expression of sacrifice in action."

Ignore the unconvincing performances and tinge of environmental proselytizing and focus on the computer-generated wind ripping apart a computer-generated barn, and Into the Storm still lacks the force it would take to blow out a candle on a birthday cake.

Set up almost like a modern-day version of John Steinbeck's Of Mice and Men - if all the characters in the classic novel were tripping on acid.

Dark comedy, sharp social satire and mainstream horror elements merge into the strange and smartly written first feature by filmmaker Jordan Peele, who drives his critique of cultural appropriation into a clever, anti-racism statement.
Visually gratifying and epic in scope, it's a memorable conclusion to a brilliant, re-imagined trilogy.

movie_review_blurb: The best comic-book-inspired offering this year - and maybe ever - was the weighty, somber, ultra-violent final chapter in the X-Men's Wolverine saga.
Aside from its timeliness, Spielberg's opus on the Freedom of the Press is also an effective narrative on female empowerment anchored by a contemplative performance by living legend Meryl Streep.

The fusion of blistering drama and dark comedy rises to the levels of Martin McDonaugh's first feature film, 2008's In Bruges. There's no denying the intensity brimming from both genres, which injects the picture with a strong dose of anger.

Compassionately told through the eyes of a child, [the film] is a captivating observational drama filled with moments of incredible sadness, wide-eyed innocence and pure joy.

Stunningly atmospheric and featuring eye-catching production and costume design, the romance can be stilted at times, but it's hard not to appreciate the cinematic composition in its entirety.

The motivation behind [the main characters'] unlikely friendship isn't fleshed out enough to get us completely on board.

There is an authenticity and refreshing candor that director Chris Brown allows to envelope his narrative, a difficult thing to capture, especially with non-actors who know when a camera is pointing at them.
The stories of the 1.1 million family caregivers of post-9/11 military veterans are given the respect and admiration they deserve in filmmaker Stephanie Seldin Howard's touching documentary.
Through powerful words and images, director David Rae Morris has created a documentary that is both timely and sincere.
movie_title: Yazoo Revisited: Integration and Segregation in a Deep Southern Town (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Denzel Washington and Viola Davis give incredible performances, which is reason enough to forgive the film's cinematic shortcomings.
Shot beautifully by cinematographer Stephanes Fontaine. The haunting score by composer Mica Levi drives home the grief felt through the entire picture.
Laika's strikingly imaginative fourth project has undoubtedly produced another major player in the increasingly competitive animation industry.
Uncomfortably bleak, director Antonio Campos scrapes away at the agonizing details of Chubbuck's anguish stemming from her stunted personal and professional life to reveal a tortured soul.
Although mainstream horror movie fans might not warm to its methodical pacing, the unnerving atmosphere director/writer Robert Eggers creates can be compared to genre classics like Rosemary's Baby.
Greek director/co-writer Yorgos Lanthimos designs a distinctive dystopian world and questions the idea of typical relationships and how couples connect at a surface level.
Taking his love for jazz music, director/writer Damien Chazelle breathes new life into the old Hollywood musical genre much like 2011's The Artist did for silent cinema.
With a perfect combination of understated humor and unpretentious drama, Enough Said is a sweet and oftentimes sad portrait of two middle-aged souls searching for happiness.
It might not be able to close out as efficiently as it would've liked, but it does present some valuable themes about appreciating every aspect of a relationship no matter how flawed it is.
With Oscar winner Forest Whitaker fully embracing the project and an impressive ensemble cast that brings to life America's dark racist past, Lee Daniels' The Butler is significant.

The anticlimactic scenes all lead up to an inevitable CGI-heavy showdown: Good vs. Evil, featuring a clan of grotesque zombie monks and a winged demon as realistic as the one Eddie Murphy jacks up in The Golden Child.
Director Ivan Reitman, who has never really gotten any dirtier than campers reading smut in Meatballs, is out of his element.
Consider director Sylvain Chomet...the ringmaster and main attraction in this melancholic circus accented by a warm, water-colored Edinburg landscape.

Watching Barney search for happiness in the most graceless ways is uncomfortable at times, but his sincere personality peers through enough from behind his callous exterior to inspire sympathy for him without dismissing his countless flaws.
Replace the melodramatic vampires and werewolves [from The Twilight Saga] with some equally angsty extraterrestrials and Four is an obvious imitation with faint originality.
The consistently despairing tone is remarkable, as is Isabelle Huppert's understated and absorbing performance as a woman lost in deep-seated denial and facing an inevitable end.
Director Catherine Hardwicke is out to tap into the demographic of 13 to 18-year-old tweens who fund these gothic soap operas with their babysitting money.
Actor Colin Firth is simply mesmerizing, as is the rest of the talented cast who bring to life this fascinating footnote in British history.
As far as courtroom dramas are concerned, you'd be hard-pressed to find something as generic as The Lincoln Lawyer.
Win Win may not be a flawless victory, but McCarthy is able to pin us down effortlessly nonetheless, proving there's more to life than being carried off the field a hero.
Might keep the youngest of kiddos hypnotized by the gaudy imagery on screen, but Hop is far from hip.
Without the sweeping aerial shots and the rest of the highly impressive camerawork, the documentary doesn't add up to more than standard, harmless wilderness fare for the kiddos.
Is so obnoxious, annoying, unfunny, and downright hateful, that watching lunatics freaking out on stage during a paternity episode of Maury Povich would be better received.
Lacks the romantic luster needed between its leads to match the enchanting, saga-like feel of the time.

It's unfortunate director Roland Joffé fails to capture real emotion and passion within the religious narrative. Without that perspective, there's no way he can breathe any life into the biopic, much less fire.
It's difficult to tell if director James Gunn really is trying to play for laughs, because so much of the one-liner humor is inconsistent.
Once that buzz starts to wear thin, things become exhausting.
Director/screenwriter Sebastián Cordero delivers a lurid and absorbing drama about the power of the media and the steps some will take to get the big scoop.
Lucas controls himself, unlike in the previous prequels, and sticks to the most poignant issues, which makes the transition from Sith to A New Hope effortless.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: With subplots about pregnant girlfriends, drug-dealing cousins, and other sob stories that are mentioned but not developed, Coach Carter's exceptional message is delivered with little imagination.
The biggest problem with Gringo is that there are far too many unnecessary subplots, which the weak narrative can't support.
Turns the frightening scenario of a home invasion into a conventional slasher movie where everyone runs around while the killers walk menacingly and wield kitchen knives and drag axes on the ground.
A Wrinkle in Time will be relegated to the category where forgotten fantasy family fare like The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl takes up space.
Playing out like a highly-entertaining comedy routine, The Eleven O'Clock is a flat-out riot.
The dynamic between actors Tarra Riggs and Bo Mitchell is authentic and humanistic as writer/director Reed Van Dyk allows the scene to take form one heartbreaking second after another.
Doesn't capture the same enchantment as either the original fairy tales or Dahl's book, but should get a pass from most indiscriminate children.
Cute and playful enough, although the final moral-of-the-story homestretch doesn't make much sense.
Rich with detail and featuring a wonderful underwater scene with "underwear jellyfish," this Wes Andersonesque animation is a charmer.
[Wraps] up with some effective dark humor that gets to the core of the bleak narrative.
A beautifully hand-drawn animation and personal poem that is both impassioned and inspiring.
An intriguing look at the grieving process, identity politics and the fierce determination of a member of an underrepresented faction in society.
Is somewhat of a dull affair and one that runs counter to the idea that using sex as an element of female empowerment only works when the character isn't forced into the position to survive.
With broad strokes of self-awareness [and] a screwy screenplay that sometimes crosses the line into parody ... Game Night is more gratifying than hearing an opponent say, "You sunk my battleship!"

With a talented, majority black cast, a director with a distinctive voice and several technical triumphs, including some incredible costume design ... Black Panther is a superhero highpoint for the history books.
The framework is a tired one, especially when the screenplay doesn't deviate from hitting familiar plot devices.
The by-the-numbers storyline is disappointing considering how imaginative Nick Park's work has proven to be for the last 30 years.
Another unmemorable romp between the sheets.

Kristen Wiig has written a lead role for herself with some great awkward moments usually regulated for fools of the male variety. It's nice to see women can be just as boneheaded when the situation calls for it.
The narrative of this series needs a major wake-up-call if it doesn't want to lull audiences to sleep with the same old fantasy plotting and repetitious action sequences.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Ed Helms delivers some dialed-down, hilarious moments that never feel like second-rate gags.
A self-important, stock indie that finds a way to hit every superficial cliche possible and still has the audacity to flaunt itself as a thoughtful look at teenage romance.
Spreads the narrative too thin and becomes repetitious over the course of three exhausting months.
A conventional film built around an entertaining soundtrack.
Director Malik Bendjelloul attempts clear the air and really analyze the thoughts and emotions that formed Sixto Rodriguez's past work.
A solid political spy movie, despite being gift-wrapped a little too neatly.
Doesn't seem interested in offering anything new or building on an already well-established mythology.
Viciously funny.
Invigorating.
It's all fashioned together into one gut-wrenching, suspenseful, and often bizarre crime docudrama that is the creepiest true story to hit the big screen since 2010's Catfish.
Amongst the giants this year, this film by first-time director Benh Zeitlin can be overlooked. But without it, true fantasy is lost.
Congressional theater at its most fascinating.

Despite it's heavy-handedness in the last act, Susanne Bier directs with fascinating awareness of her characters and with grace for the moments of compassion between two families trying to understand how humanity can be so merciless.
Ang Lee and screenwriter David Magee managed to take Yann Martel's novel about a young boy and a tiger lost at sea and make it sing visually and narratively.
Tarantino takes a no-holds-barred approach and delivers another well-written, ultra-violent spectacle masked as a spaghetti western.
The final mission is mesmerizing.
It's undeniably tragic without being sentimental and easily the best non-American film of the year.
When the sarcasm, silliness, and genuine family moments are executed well during the journey, Blood Cousins triggers some hearty laugher.

Hoffman's performance is beyond words, as always, but it is Phoenix's take on the animalistic nature of man that speaks volumes to the core elements of what makes the film such a devastating one to shake.
Takes some unique angles at familiar situations and allows the nerdy chemistry between its leads to play out naturally.
As the head of this diamondback-rattlesnake-of-a-film, Matthew McConaughey strikes within a sadistic realm very few actors would dare to tread.
Eccentric and sweet and director/writer Wes Anderson's best live-action contribution since The Royal Tenenbaums.
Charlize Theron embraces her lack of congeniality with a remarkable combination of resentment, hostility, and self-hatred that is both uncomfortable and compelling.
The movie doesn't have all the elements necessary to make it a true classic, but there are some admirable things it accomplishes, especially when the enthusiastic kids are at the forefront.
The problems start and end with the uninspired, witless and convoluted script.
As with most of his films, Michael Bay doesn't take the less-is-more approach when it comes to spectacle. That he saves for his convoluted screenplay and flat human characterizations.
The stakes are high in A Better Life and Bichir matches the film's tormented tone with a portrayal of a man overcome by both fear and faith.
The danger is seething as both sides battle between extravagant set pieces and eye-catching special effects.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Let's just hope Kevin James stops pissing on things long enough to realize his film career is already sufficiently soaked.
The all-star cast is able to class up the situations to make them feel as funny and original as possible.

Unpredictable throughout, The Debt may harp on the fine line between fact and fiction a bit much, but with Helen Mirren on board, there's little chance the film isn't going to reach its final destination without some style, class, and riveting insight.
The performances prevail in The Help as Emma Stone shows her range as a serious actress and Viola Davis epitomizes courage through her somber eyes.
Writer/director Joe Cornish chooses snarky attitude over genuine personality and scrambles the script by adding an ineffective side story about a drug deal gone bad.
Academy Award-winning screenwriters Steven Zaillian and Aaron Sorkin dissect the game into an intriguing underdog story.
Slightly entertaining and ordinary.
A poor man's version of Ocean's 11.
Directed and written by first-time feature filmmaker Sean Durkin, Martha is relentless in its unsettled tone, simmering throughout at a feverish level.
None of it comes off as clever as it probably did on paper.
Filmmaker David Fincher is extremely conscious of the details he needs to exhibit to keep each isolated moment at a highly concentrated level.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The massive wildebeest stampede and Scar's Third Reich-inspired musical number were already phenomenal 17 years ago without the additional dimension, so what's really the point?
Screenwriter/actress Zoe Kazan shows signs of potential, but she fluffs up Sparks instead of examining its darker elements.
It's all in the build-up: Kubrick sets the scene for the horror with meticulous care.

The film-making is rough and ready - Tempest looks like a student film and often sounds like a promotional video for Ovalhouse - but the cast is sympathetic and it's a pleasure to see them making the play their own.
This remains an enduring delight.
Thanks to its subtle touches and strong character development, Bridge to Terabithia is not only entertaining for the family but for anyone who wants to leave reality behind for a little while.

Drag Me to Hell is plenty frightening and the effects pass the gross-out test two times over. But this screenplay includes some signature comedic moments that play with the genre and its tired cliches to create something much more interesting.

There's no big shocker ending in Enchanted, and it follows a pretty typical formula, but what makes it a winner is its ability to make you smile anyway. Be forewarned, you might even get a cheek ache.
Like the snooty restaurant critic Anton Ego (voiced by Peter O'Toole), we enter Ratatouille thinking we've tasted it all, and we leave hoping for seconds.
Adds too many gimmicks to a story that had plenty going for it already.
The movie was not great, but not Ishtar.
A predictable whodunnit set in a cinematographer's paradise.
Multiple marquee cameos keep the sparkle quotient high, and the film is genuinely (sometimes squirmingly) funny. No stunning reveals, but filial strife has rarely been better acted.

Though parts of the film drag, Neeson is terrific as Felt. That's saying something considering the character is as dispassionate and inscrutable as it's possible to be. But Neeson believably unpacks Felt's dignity and frustration.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Blade Runner 2049 is not only among the year's best films, but arguably one of the best sequels ever issued. Somewhere, Avatar's James Cameron is watching closely and scribbling notes.

It's nobody's idea of an action masterpiece. But American Made is a blast, leveraging star Tom Cruise's on-screen wattage and comedic sense while telling a heck of a story that again confirms truth is stranger than fiction.

Brad's Status has a ton of heart... the performances are strong. But nothing feels remotely new or novel. And White fails to leverage the dark humour you'd expect from a film with Jemaine Clement and Ben Stiller.
Danielle Macdonald does for the character of Patti what Gabourey Sidibe did for Precious: uses her non-Hollywood looks to conjure a character so believable we can practically smell her.
The Only Living Boy In New York is pretty much dead to me.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Audiences come to Alien films for thrills, chills and stylized gore set in creepy off-world locales, not sharply nuanced performances from decorated thespians.
[All eyez on me] lacks a sense of depth, a deeper insight into what made Tupac Shakur tick.
What makes [My Cousin Rachel] so engaging is that the audience never quite knows who it's cheering for. Turns out being off-balance is pretty darn exhilarating.
It's exhilarating, every bit of it, until the once-great, now depressingly bad Depp steps into the frame, slowing the action with maddeningly predictable pratfalls and faux-drunken slurs.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Beguiled is beguiling.
Baby Driver is a hoot. It's also ridiculous bordering on preposterous, but it's the giddiest you'll feel in the theatre all summer.
Not a lot happens in The Hero. Yet it is a deeply affecting warts-and-all rumination on thwarted ambitions, failed marriages and filial relationships gone sideways.
While it's commendable that one of history's most despicable human-inflicted tragedies is brought to light, Bitter Harvest leaves viewers bitter for all the wrong reasons.
The journey is surprisingly fun, owing to cut-above efforts by the principals and a story that, for all its absurdity, essentially spins on traditional themes of sisterhood, kindness and love.
Beatriz at Dinner could have been funny and sharply drawn, building on Hayek's strong performance. Instead, it's a clunky morality play rendered in crayon.
Kosinski has us consider the firefighters as people - which may be a gamble for an action movie, but boy, are we sucked through the wringer when inevitable tragedy strikes.
Annette Bening is reliably great opposite Jamie Bell who gives knocked knees genuine poise and gravitas thanks to the source material.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to overstate just how awful - really, truly, unabashedly dreadful - A Bad Moms Christmas is, or to exaggerate the many levels on which it disappoints.
Breathe wants to be liked. What it doesn't do is genuinely engage or surprise, offering neat conclusions and platitudes where a little grit would raise its game.
A tender, achingly tangible story about a woman's latent self-discovery, Meditation Park is a gem propelled by Cheng Pei Pei whose wildly expressive face fires emotion straight to the heart.
Beautiful, intensely (and unabashedly) weird and, unusual for sci-fi, propelled by a female cast.
An earnest Freaky Friday... conveys its message of tolerance and inclusion with conviction, though it could benefit from a bit more teen drama - something that can rarely be said in the real world.
Twee, yes, but Forever My Girl has plenty of heart and some solid performances. A journey not entirely without pleasure...
Director Akin's film is insanely heavy and completely free of the redemptive happy ending nonsense so common among Hollywood films.
Its ending is convoluted to the point of ridiculous yet Liam Neeson remains committed and indisputably watchable, a beacon amid a smouldering heap of twisted logic and garbled conclusions.
Films this trenchant (and mercifully short) don't come along every day.
To see The Shape of Water is to be catapulted into a dream world of dancing raindrops and swirling colours that toggle between scary and cool. Smart money says you'll enjoy the sensation either way.
Washington conjures a character clearly in crisis who is equally repulsive and sympathetic. But this really is a mess, a glorious, well-acted mess. Rubberneckers: your must-see has arrived.

Coco is a lovely film, with fizzy songs sure to resonate with the small-fry and empowering messages about following dreams and helping friends. It's also explosively colourful, and beautifully rendered.
Director Dee Reese uses the lengthy runtime to develop these characters, and we feel genuinely thunderstruck when calamity falls, as powerfully as a punch to the head.
The biggest sin a movie like this can commit is being boring. And bottom line: Justice League is seriously ho-hum, offering negligible thrills and some screamingly ridiculous plot twists.
Branagh's Murder on the Orient Express is beautiful but boring. Nothing in this latest iteration substantively stretches, expands or toys with the source material.
The knock-kneed buoyancy of the ensemble performances ensures the box office-friendly franchise goes out on a (relatively) high note even if its girl power message feels clubbed to death.

The film soars because it scans as real, each character someone who might very well live next door, struggling with everyday issues - family, sex, love, money, status, expectation, and disappointment.
The screenplay ... oversimplifies aspects of Lee and Mr. Grey's relationship while unnecessarily complicating others.
The film succeeds as a comedy because Niccol is great at teasing out the implications of his main idea and then developing an economical and frequently witty plot around them.
The Master of Disguise is awful. It's Pauly Shore awful. Don't say you weren't warned.
In this day of tidy trick endings, it's a pleasure to watch a film in which the thorny issues only get thornier.
Despite the addition of a villain and the inspired casting of Michael Caine as Austin Powers' dad, the film feels watered down.
Ford's Russian accent is so slight and intermittent it sounds more like he has a tickle in his throat, while Neeson's Irish brogue gives his speech a split personality.
Pleasures don't come much guiltier than this.

Suprisingly, the documentary is so free of rancour and so filled with love for the religion that it has actually inspired some audience members to raise their hands after screenings and ask how they can convert.
An accomplished genre flick.
The sexual politics in L'Ultimo Bacio leave a lot to be desired, and the film hasn't sat as well with me since the Toronto Italian Film Festival in June, when I gave it a three-star review.

[Junge's] memories are razor-sharp, and her ruminations on guilt are compelling, but the filmmakers' choice not to include archival photos or footage leaves the documentary bare, uncontextualized and with many questions left unanswered.
If only the film had more farce and less romantic fluff.
Every bit as creepy as the original. But this time the creepiness of the mouse-adoption isn't even acknowledged.
The false notes at the beginning give way to a darkly satisfying coming-of-age drama, capped by a truly cathartic poetry reading.
The small triumphs and frustrations these children experience are more affecting than a thousand life-and-death battles between adults.
movie_title: To Be and to Have (Etre et Avoir) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It's a slight premise given substance by the thoughtful dialogue and performances.
movie_title: The Man on the Train (L'homme du train) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Rewards your patience with realistic tension, twists and a poignancy that sneaks up on you.
Perfect for its target audience of swoony preteens.
Its premise ... never develops beyond the level of a mediocre X-Files episode.
It's hard to take any of this seriously when the cast is full of Guess jeans models, but the homophobia lurking under every plot twist is a serious turnoff.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Bed (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It's worth seeing for the intelligent, interlacing arguments between Rothman and Hitler.
Obnoxious Tootsie rip-off.
Do we really need another film that praises female self-sacrifice?
The beautiful, unusual music is this film's chief draw, but its dreaminess may lull you to sleep.
The biggest problem with Satin Rouge is Lilia herself. She's a cipher, played by an actress who smiles and frowns but doesn't reveal an inner life.
Freakishly fun to watch.
It doesn't know what kind of movie it wants to be.
Eminem gives a focused, intelligent performance.
Brings light to a little-known facet of the Holocaust in a way that does justice to its moral ambiguities.
Frequently hilarious and frustratingly underdeveloped at the same time.
An intriguing portrait of New Yorkers colliding with fate.
A fine film, but it would be a lot better if it stuck to Betty Fisher and left out the other stories.
movie_title: Alias Betty (Betty Fisher and Other Stories)(Betty Fisher et autres histoires) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Awfully disappointing coming from the director of Swingers and Go.
Just a bunch of good actors flailing around in a caper that's neither original nor terribly funny.
If this were a miniseries, it would probably be worth watching while doing homework.
What on earth made Woody Allen think it would be fun to watch him and Helen Hunt, surely the most pinched actress of her generation, trade insults for an entire film?
movie_title: The Curse of the Jade Scorpion (2001)

movie_review_blurb: If you like your comedy dumb and exhausting, this flick's for you.
A provocative film like Bully invites knee-jerk reactions, but there's a lot more to this story than meets the eye.
A comedy with a weird identity crisis.
The film is broadly humorous and unrealistic in a sitcom way, yet it also contains smatterings of truth -- most notably in its performances -- that keep the journey grounded.
Breathtakingly original.
It's hard to muster up sympathy for characters too stupid to avoid getting sucked into the tragic fate of others and too self-involved to stand against injustice until they're inconvenienced by it.
Opie may know how to spin a good fable, but he's no match for this brilliant, complicated couple.
Vanilla Sky proves to be Cameron Crowe's wildest work to date. It's also his least coherent, but for some viewers that may be a plus.
Long-winded comedy.
Though the story ... is hackneyed, the characters have a freshness and modesty that transcends their predicament.
What rating do you give a film that's as vile as Freddy Got Fingered in some scenes and as funny as Rushmore in others?
Benjamin Bratt gets to show off a lot in the title role, but to his credit he nails Piñero's Beat poetry and transmits startling savagery through his flashing eyes.
A well-crafted letdown.
Who knows what exactly Godard is on about in this film, but his words and images don't have to add up to mesmerize you.
movie_title: In Praise Of Love (Éloge de l'amour) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Most of the jokes can be spotted a mile away.
The tone shifts abruptly from tense to celebratory to soppy.
If ... you consider yourself a discerning filmgoer, you will find Dragonfly excruciatingly bad -- head-in- popcorn-bucket bad.
Two previously boring actors [Hartnett and Sossamon] ... bring their characters to sparkly life.
In the pantheon of recent animated films, Ice Age fits under Toy Story (less depth), across from Shrek (less adult sass) and above Monsters Inc. (far livelier).
Boy, what a movie.
Plodding, superficial, unmemorable -- unfortunately, these adjectives can now apply to Bill Paxton's directorial debut as well as his usual screen presence.
Not only does [Allen] act as though blind people are stupid, unable to determine where a voice is coming from, but he also allows scenes to drag on far longer than this one joke can sustain.
A cool film starring Val Kilmer -- who woulda thunk it?
Worth the effort to watch.
A smart send-up of spy movies, race relations and pop culture that packs more funny into its 86 minutes than Austin Powers will manage in a lifetime.
Chillingly prosaic.
movie_title: Comment j'ai tué mon père (My Father and I) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: It's not going to be everyone's bag of popcorn, but it definitely gives you something to chew on.
Miller gets away with stuff that other filmmakers are crucified for (too much narration, that pretentious title) because her characters are so well observed.
The theme of silent passivity runs throughout the film, so Bonello must have wanted to make some kind of statement with it. The effect is merely alienating.
Calculated fluff that hinges on a couple of gross miscalculations.
First-time director Wayne Kramer makes the odd choice of taking this premise seriously, which forces the actors to work overtime selling hackneyed plot twists.
This superficial storyline borders on being a public menace, but Muccino casts well (Monica Belluci is the other woman) and his scenes crackle with melodramatic zest.
Though its story is universal enough to leap across cultural boundaries, it's not deep enough to justify the leap to the big screen.
There's more wit, insight and pathos in this doc than Bingenheimer perhaps deserves, but he's a fascinating touchstone in this crazy celebrity culture nonetheless.
Harrelson's environmental truths are taken as self-evident, and his private life off-limits, which makes for a doc that's neither educational nor especially compelling.
Skips along, propelled by sharp humour and performances.
One of those quietly brilliant indies, so small in scope that it takes a little extra attention to appreciate how deeply it plunges into its characters.
It's just good, clean fun.
Hogan's adapation is likely faithful to a fault: it goes through the motions of the story without seeming to have any reason for telling it.
The only real depth here is in Lane's ability to convey lingering heartache despite having little call to do so from the script.
It's an experiment that's only partially successful. As a character study, In the Cut is sublime; as a murder mystery, however, the film is slightly ridiculous.
A flawed yet mesmerizing adaptation of the 1986 BBC mini-series.
Despite the flawed premise and sitcomish plot, this film has an undeniable charm.
It falls apart in the third act when plot decays into melodrama.
It's even worse now, when its perms and polyester mark it as dated as its sexual politics.
Quote not available.
If you like Stiller and Wilson, you'll find enough to like about this film. If you don't, you can always just gawk at that awesome car.
Good thing the people serving this utilitarian story have the wit to dress it up a little and make it dance.
Wears you out in a way that would be considered heartless and manipulative if it weren't also (mostly) true.
The script is so weak, so illogical, so bereft of actual humour that it takes the considerable charm of the cast merely to prop it up.
Lepage's adaptation of his own stage play distills his typically grandiose ideas and visual quirks into a masterfully cohesive and entertaining film.
While the Catholic lore in this film may be wonky, the relationship between the young Chinese-Canadian sisters who try on Catholicism in a bid to safeguard their family is bang-on.
The characters are all original and memorable.
It's the anti-Mission: Impossible, and for a while it's really gripping and refreshing.
Young gamers might not mind all the competing colours and sounds, but their parents might need a stiff drink in a dark room afterwards.
For every smart dig the film gets in at sexism, it digs its own grave as a comedy. We can't pick a side when both sides have good intentions.
How many villains does a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles sequel need? Five? Really?
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's like Toy Story without the lament for childhood things: pretty disposable stuff.
Chicago is no Cabaret, but if all you want from your evening's entertainment is jazz, it's all that.
Sayles's latest clash between over- and underprivileged cultures focuses solely on the issue of motherhood, but within this one issue he explores the widest range of emotions.
The heartbreak comes early and often, as it should, but so do inane maxims.
Not one character seems like a fully realized human being, let alone a likeable one.
movie_title: The Middle of the World (O Caminho das Nuvens) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating portrait of the woman, and a damning one of the society in which she lived.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Blame Marc Lawrence for most of the film's flaws.
Grotesque yet trippy.
An action-comedy that no one should be surprised sucks.
A hot, visually entrancing film.
movie_title: La Turbulence des fluides (Chaos and Desire) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A technically accomplished yet dull-as- dishwater biography of Kurt Gerron.
Promises an intelligent debate about capital punishment but delivers a predictable thriller, directed with stunning amateurishness by Alan Parker.
The sort of comedy your Uncle Marty might like, if Uncle Marty is the sort of geezer who lives in a hovel and numbs his pain with beer and porn.

Charlene establishes herself early on as manipulative and untrustworthy, which could lead to wicked fun if the film stayed true to this side of her character. Instead, like Hollywood clockwork, Charlene morphs into a good influence.
The filmmakers draw on interesting material here; too bad they don't go anywhere interesting with it.
movie_title: Cowboy Bebop: The Movie (Kaubôi Bibappu: Tengoku no Tobira) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Not all of it works, but the parts that do are quietly exhilarating.
Davis can't find a consistent tone for this long-winded story.
A fittingly arrogant and lunkheaded vehicle for its star.
An irrelevant gangster subplot and endlessly repeated shots cloud the fine film Kitano could've achieved if he'd let someone else edit it.
Legally Blonde 2 is often so dumb it hurts.
War is insane. Insane people are cute. Bryan Adams is God. There, now that you've got these three principles down, you don't need to see House of Fools.
Pacino gives the film its juice by arching his eyebrows and delivering his lines as if they were birthday presents, making the most of every wisecrack and innuendo.
