It's so muddily written, you'll get lost in silly jokes about building projects and tofu cheesecake.

With uninspired fight choreography and sequences so dimly lit the viewer has a hard time deciphering where and what anything is, director Bartkowiak reveals he's no Ridley Scott when it comes to tension and buildup.
Really, a musical would have been a much better idea.
Thanks to Garcia's vigorous camerawork, startlingly in-depth touches, guile and, importantly, a stable of top-notch actresses, and actors, the picture remains fresh and unexpected.
Vin Diesel, I used to love you ... but The Pacifier is making my job a lot harder.
If not for the race sequences and the intriguing presence of Caviezel ... the film would amount to a well-intentioned snooze.
The picture rarely delves into how personally (perhaps even politically) revolutionary the couple's new life has become, making its subject matter more lackluster than it has any right to be.
XXX: State of the Union suffers an action fate worse than un-explainable exploding cars and wooden dialogue -- it's boring.

Do you think Jiminy Glick is funny? If the answer is no, then you'll have a hard time spending 90 minutes with the corpulent, star-struck celebrity-interviewer in his debut film, Jiminy Glick in Lalawood.

Well positioned on that slippery cliff called melodrama, Susanne Bier's grainy, intimate, almost claustrophobic family drama, Brothers, keeps its footing, never falling into the deep chasm of Soap Opera.
Its overindulgence in pseudo-David Lynch stylistics provides yet another distraction from a potentially intriguing story.
Mick Davis' prosaic art biopic Modigliani is a tiresome, hammy and ultimately annoying portrait of the artist as a young drunk.
Schlocky and fun.
A predictable, choppy affair at best.
Poor special effects, a silly looking werewolf and clunky comic writing help to spoil what should have been a fun B-movie.
Gritty, exciting, sexy and refreshingly, honestly '70s, Catherine Hardwicke's Lords of Dogtown is one of the most thrilling pictures to be released in years.
A coming-of-age tale that eschews the typical trappings of that genre by making the friendship/love affair between two precocious adolescents into something powerfully obscure.
Though not a bad film, all too often it feels like a slickly made studio offering with nary the juice and verve of the zombie master's prior, lower budget, ventures.
Confined by the supposed thrills and chills of pseudo-J-horror, the film's allegorical depth remains, unlike all the ooze saturating Connelly's digs, hopelessly clogged.
It's not a perfect picture, but the overall effect is incredibly satisfying.
Broken Flowers overcomes its shortcomings through Murray's ability to make a nearly nihilistic character human.
This movie is channeling something quite wonderful and distinct: old-gal horror.
In spite of its darkness and 'edge,' it wants us too really, really like it. Sorry. As pretty and non-persuasive as you are, we really, really don't.
Messy, derivative, and silly, The Cave is, at the very least, oddly likable.

Though the film begins with the promise of dissecting the origins and politics of the firms, the neighborhood turf wars, and the general attraction towards football-hooligan culture, it quickly abandons those aims.

Is it possible that a film made in 1948 and by David Lean could exceed the darkness and controversy of a Roman Polanski picture? After watching the newest screen version of Oliver Twist, the answer is yes.
Can a film be undone by its lame twist ending? In the case of High Tension, the answer is yes.
Implausabilities aside, Confessions is a light lark that's colorful, spirited, and chock full of clothes.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A middling picture at best, it reveals some interesting inner workings of the Secret Service. At worst, it plays like a boring night of TV watched at your mom's.
There's just not enough substance here to make for anything other than a dippy feel-good comedy that pokes fun at what often happens in real life -- people around the same age can fall in love.
XX/XY proves that some movies just cast wrong actors.
Absorbing and moving.
It's a stylish work, seeping with brilliant animation and potentially interesting characters that didn't need so much time to establish themselves.
movie_title: Cowboy Bebop: The Movie (Kaubôi Bibappu: Tengoku no Tobira) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: In every aspect of filmmaking and intent this picture is peerless, so truly real, funny, poignant and sexy that it almost feels like a watershed cinematic moment.
Ponderous, pretentious and boring.

Within this haze of drug abuse, cockiness and hollowness, we're supposed to feel for our young, spoiled protagonist. Sadly, what we mostly feel is the pain of our eyes constantly rolling in our heads.
It may not be as cool as it was in the '60s with Michael Caine, but it's oddly pleasant.
Watch it and you'll long for a much-needed European vacation.
Tense, well directed, adequately acted and frequently funny.
We expect Pamela Anderson and her VIP crew to come traipsing out in their high heels and cheap props. It's a shame they don't -- the film would be significantly improved.
A bit of exotic neo-noir, clunky in parts and long, but often engaging and artfully atmospheric as well.
It's just one of many Hoffman portraits that are painfully real and brilliantly textured.
The film is potent enough to make you think. But it suffers from a lack of smoothness.
Everyone talks 'cute' and 'smart,' but the timing's off. And though Alex is supposed to be a brilliant writer of dark comedy, you wouldn't think so by the story he concocts.
From Justin to Kelly [is] completely awful.
Unlike other sequel's cramming the multiplexes, this one certainly won't bore you.
The idea of this strange little girl growing into a woman obsessed with body parts is intriguing, but McKee hasn't a clue what to do with her actors.
You get the feeling that these actors had fun making this film, and that fun is contagious.
Though there are some funny moments, little in Red, White and Blonde is enjoyable.
Though the lanky, dreamy-eyed Brody shows range, he's got a dorky quality that's hard to dismiss -- his strutting his stuff sends eyes rolling.
League isn't a terrible movie -- it's often thrilling -- but by the end, the experience is numbing.
Though well-intentioned, it's not terribly compelling.
Some will hate this film, but there's something delectably junky about it -- like a bright colored candy glistening from a gutter, you just have to look at it.

A film that merges cocaine, Ivy League, college applications, the Asian American experience, dark comedy and high school drama while maintaining a personal tone and likable lead characters is just too impressive to knock.
An embarrassing exercise in muddled comedy, buddy bonding and touching drama fueled by a hackneyed chop-socky verve.
Hallmark Hall of Fame material.
Quote not available.

Mulling a definitive take on the film, you can't come up with one. Meanwhile, you bask in its ingeniousness, marvel at its acting, writing and structure and laugh at humor that veers from very real to very odd to very obviously odd.
Well-acted, well-directed and, for all its moodiness, not too pretentious.
Amid the shock and curiosity factors, the film is just a corny examination of a young actress trying to find her way.
Almodovar walks an unsteady line and he knows it, showing us that compassion and delusion aren't too far removed, and powerfully, lend a surreal richness and beauty to life.
[The kid's] just too bratty for sympathy, and as the film grows to its finale, his little changes ring hollow.
This is a movie where you can just sit back and revel in it, warts and all.
Mistry is appealing (even while enduring some pretty embarrassing moments) and the picture entertaining, but it never crosses into something relevant or creatively eccentric.
Needed more grit and finesse.
A fun, if blood- and sun-soaked, ride.
With little cohesion and no respect for the editing process, Old School often feels like someone threw film clips on the floor and strung them together willy-nilly.
Simplistic, sometimes funny but mostly stupid.
In 1975, the idea of a straight man tying up a gay burglar was exotic, darkly humorous and sexually charged. In director/star Steve Guttenberg's new film version, it comes off as no big deal.
Wonderfully entertaining and, yes, touching.
Dreamcatcher baffles -- in tone, in intent and in just about every other way a film can puzzle.
[Van Sant has] managed something abstract yet explicit, and he's at his most honorable and purest in the aesthetics of filmmaking.
Although mired in the flashback technique and bumbling at times, Basic essentially is a fun movie, surprise ending and all.
[Hoffman's] remarkable, and though the film brings gifts, it's hard to imagine the picture existing without him.
The film strives to be poetic, but it exposes nothing especially moving or relevant. Rather, the engaging leads wander around like actors lost in an ill-fated exercise in subtext.
Merging a documentary with a stand-up film is interesting, but Gallo never goes the distance with his material.
Needing the gristle of its title, the film should have been angrier.
Be patient with the lovely Hush! and your reward will be a thoughtful, emotional movie experience.
Nudity and intelligent musings: What more could you ask for?
A harmless film that could have been perfect for its leads, but given so little to do, they're never as endearing as the film implies.
Tedious, clunky and, for the big budget and all the exotic locales, surprisingly chintzy-looking.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A flashy, mediocre picture.
Though not bad looking, the look here conveys nothing like the simultaneously open-air and claustrophobic beauty of its predecessor.
The tedious film just plays out far too long with little new to say.
The script is inane, and though Ferri has some funny moments, the acting is annoying or hopelessly bland.
A tone deaf picture that fails to be either darkly funny or intelligently consequential.
If a film can't make you laugh when American Idol host Simon Cowell gets shot at a freestyle rap competition, something is seriously wrong.
It moves like a breezy techno-thriller but tangles itself with duplicities and metaphors. You get it, and then you don't get it, and then you wonder if you even care.
Engrossing, fun and oddly touching, Gigantic makes you wish the best for these guys.
The screenplay doesn't have enough force to take us anywhere particularly interesting.
Too full of sweet sticky stuff for even the starry-eyed to stomach.
A relentlessly mean picture that will tickle those tired of sweet comedies whether in drag or plainclothes.
Everything is so picture-perfect that it plays like hackneyed fiction rather than the real-life drama to which it aspires.
Though some critics have decried exploitation, the film is nothing of the sort -- you will think long and hard after the film, only to come up with one answer -- there IS no easy answer.
Though it might have been a theatrical polemic, the picture becomes cinematic simply through Keitel and Skarsgard's very different visages -- two sights you never tire of looking at.
Sometimes nothing is more irritating than forced wackiness. Especially forced wackiness with a supposed deeper point.
movie_title: Sin noticias de Dios (Don't Tempt Me) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Intriguing documentary narrated by the slain rapper himself.
The picture proves tiring, its pretty, color-coordinated images are like flipping through a funky fashion magazine.
Once the film moves into crime-solving territory, it becomes ludicrous and lazy.
Engrossing and unusual.
movie_title: Stoked: The Rise and Fall of Gator (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The Missing fails to shape its ideas with much cogency.
Though stilted and emotionally vacant at times, it's still an entertaining and absorbing experience.
For those who've seen the original, no surprises will be unearthed other than an altered story (not for the better) and more gore.
So palpably exciting you'll want to watch it again immediately after the first viewing.
Although there are wonderful moments to enjoy and a certain dry wit that's specifically French, and specifically Chabrol, the meandering story tests one's patience.
The performances are uniformly fine, with Perez showing a heavy amount of presence and complexity.
By a certain point The Heart of Me becomes pointlessly depressing and unlikable without offering insight.
Though it should be longer, we're not especially unhappy that it isn't, for being around these women gets tedious.
As with Madonna's Swept Away you're left baffled by how the thing was ever made.
Take your book-smart teenage daughters.
A lot funnier than most movies you're currently watching at the Cineplex.
A frothy but dark bit of modern cinema that has no idea how to reconcile its shifting tones.
So strained in its 'charm' and 'pluck' that you grow weary by minute 15, hoping that the teens whose lives it depicts will stop being so darn peppy or sweetly confused or irritatingly dramatic.
The picture aims to be cheeky and interesting. But more often it's annoying.
Bursting with energy and highlighted by some exciting skateboarding sequences (the more dedicated will wish for more), Grind has its laugh-out- loud moments.
A picture so powerfully harrowing, its slight shortcomings are forgettable compared to the entire film's cumulative effect. It's that searing.
Not even Chan's inherent charisma can save The Medallion.
Compare it with the book, and it stinks. Look at the film on its own, and it still stinks.
Lane is so lovable, so sexy and so believably conflicted (when she buys the place, you're convinced she'd do something that impetuous), the rest of the film blurs around her.
An erotic mystery of sorts, the film works because it's laconic rather than talky and its actors are all up for the material.
Feels like an extended recruitment ad for surfing.
Loaded with impressive IMAX-style shots but surprisingly skimpy on soul.
With understated skill and absolute authenticity, the film builds with enough layers that by its powerful ending, you'll feel as if you have been kicked in the stomach.
movie_title: Under the Skin of the City (Zir-e Poust-e Shahr) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: There are movies that are made for the big screen, and movies that are made for the small screen; Passionada is the latter type.
It's laughably earnest. And worse, tedious.
Gooding is off key and mugs and plops like a second-rate sitcom actor.
Fun, albeit a little messy.
Though not spectacularly directed, there are enough moments of humor and poignancy to keep you engaged.
The whole thing feels underwhelming, particularly compared to the original.
Some okay thrills with good performances and some smarts. But the last reel plunge spoils things.
Simply put, no Akira, no Matrix. It's that important.
At once realistic and idealised, this is a rare attempt to make drama of ordinary people doing the right thing.
The remake/parody sequences are outstanding, but Black's all-over-the-place mania and Mos Def's bland orphan hero don't quite tie the rest of the picture together. Still, it has heart.
This has matured over the years into a very likeable and moving romance with much to recommend it.
This is a respectful and complex work of fiction around the concepts of the biblical character and his life.
Towards the end you wish they'd just get it over with, but this film usually overcomes even the most cynical viewer's resistance.
Letter-perfect performances from Day-Lewis and Postlethwaite do a lot more than a dozen editorials to make an unforgettable point about the miscarriage of justice.
movie_title: In the Name of the Father (1993)

movie_review_blurb: A raw, vivid despatch from the frontline, this melds content with frights in classic Romero style. An outstanding exercise in showing the kids how to do it.
Amid the endless homages and the sheer adoration meted out to Sergio Leone's ambitious, pricier finale to his Spaghetti Western trilogy, it's easy to forget just how damn good the film is.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly (1966)

movie_review_blurb: If you've got the stomach for strong scenes of torture, and the heart to take part in an uncomfortable debate about human nature, this intelligent horror is well worth your time...
Kurosawa is always worth a look but this is a particular classic that has influenced so much to come, it's almost essential.
It's an enjoyable family film.
Deserving to be seen and remembered for so much more than that kiss, this is old school drama of the highest order.
Painfully sincere and uncompromising look at alcoholism for a film released in 1945, with a superb central performance.
Sweeping, epic, majestic, awesome, sumptuous, you name the grandiose superlative and you'll be right, with amazing performances and gorgeous visuals, although very, very long.
Ambiguous and intriguing.
Whether horror fans are ready for high-notes or musical buffs will appreciate Dario Argento levels of gore is an open question, but this is a rich, demented experience.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Strays slightly from the formula and therefore loses some of its mindless fun credentials.

This just can't compete in an arena with the likes of The Departed - which at least makes a point of its contrived storyline - let alone the high watermark set for cops vs. drugs drama by the TV series The Wire.
This Rodney Dangerfield vehicle is a lot better than it should be.
There's just enough whimsical good humour to carry Be Kind Rewind, but Michel Gondry's latest does tend to keep crashing into 'oh come on now, what were you thinking?' self-indulgence.
Originating the genre of 'dedicated teacher reaches troubled kids in a ghetto school', this is still affecting although heavy-handed.
Lemmon and Mathau's finest hour.
An okay paranormal mystery, with solid work from the regulars - but please Mr Carter, next time, could we have liver-eating mutants or post-modern comedy like the really good episodes of The X Files?
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Not quite a complete write-off, but basically a folly.
As per usual it features a superb cast, including the ever-present Gena Rowlands, who successfully improvise their way the film.
A remarkable performance from Emil Jannings.
Bogart as Marlowe is compelling in this classic thriller that is complex but triumph of atmospheric cool.
Not rich in plausability of plot or character development, but tonally interesting in places.
movie_title: Il portiere di notte (The Night Porter) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: McAvoy crashes the A-list, Jolie finally gets to be as big a star on screen as she has been in print, and Bekmambetov proves the most exciting action-oriented emigré since John Woo.
At last, a British crime movie that's as good as its pitch sounds: Brian Cox trying to break out of prison. Do you need to know any more to want to see it?
Aykroyd's script has more than its share of clever, witty ideas, but the film still feels the need to descend way too often to Police Academy-style heroes-dress-up-like-idiots sequences.
Still sounds great, and looks as good as ever through Ray-Bans.
Mad, but highly watchable.
It has a comic strip premise which is neverthless wholly credible in a sick sort of way.
A clever and enjoyable wrapping-up of the time-travelling adventures.
movie_title: Back to the Future Part III (1990)

movie_review_blurb: Arguably the most imaginative of the horror franchise, with a fair number of truly resonant scenes.
movie_title: A Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors (1987)

movie_review_blurb: Not so terrible that you can understand why it's been practically buried by its distributors, but you can get better ridiculous whodunits on TV.
Mildly titillating, but not very good.
Even thought it's the third such effort to employ handheld camera in a zombie flick, this has more than enough shocks to hold its own.
Al Pacino delivers a powerful performance in this compelling biopic of a cop and a city's police force.
This gets progressively nastier and winds up with an impressive hellfire finish.
It's mental but charming, so that's OK.
movie_title: I'm a Cyborg, But That's OK (Saibogujiman kwenchana) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A number of decent performances and a gritty realistic view of London makes this little sci-fi spin-off still worth a look.
Extremely gory. Horror fans should delight.
Superbly Vincent Price!
movie_title: Theater of Blood (Theatre of Blood) (Much Ado About Murder) (1973)

movie_review_blurb: Director Allan Moyle travels a quirky road too often trod by aspirant indie pics.
A competent, atmospheric remake, but, considering the quality of Murnau's masterwork, is it necessary?
movie_title: Nosferatu: Phantom der Nacht (Nosferatu the Vampyre) (1979)

movie_review_blurb: If hell is in the details, Roman Polanski has captured it here in his disturbing portrait of falling into psychosis.
Genuinely disturbing thriller classic from the master of suspense.
A visual and emotional treat.
movie_title: Nosferatu, a Symphony of Horror (Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens) (Nosferatu the Vampire) (1922)

movie_review_blurb: A peculiar but decidedly ordinary addition to the British thug genre.

Cold and cerebral, with simmering suspense rather than outright excitement, this is a feel-the-quality-of-the-acting movie. It can't answer all sorts of questions, but does take a scary mug shot of a subtle monster.
As modern-day re-stagings of Bible stories go, this is oddly less funny than The Reaping. Next time, for real laughs, do the story of Job.
Thoroughly deserving of its cult status.
Torture junkies should remember it's only four months to Saw IV -- so you can afford to avoid Captivity.
Carnivorous lunar activities rarely come any more entertaining than this.
A fantastical monument to Fritz Lang's megalomania, this sci-fi silent remains one of the gems of the genre.
Interesting story and OK performances but this takes a little time to warm up.
Bigger action, more amazing deserted (and devastated) London sequences and biting contemporary relevance, if a touch less heart than the original.
This is a set of footnotes rather than a fully achieved film - but it's so packed with tidbits of interest it can't fail to be intermittently diverting.
Very, very low-brow.
Pretty solid gory horror.
Entertaining and genuinely creepy at times this boasts strong performances from its French cast.
Massively underrated.
Well-crafted and well-acted, but ever-so-slightly worthy and strangely unaffecting. Given the track record of the CIA, it probably ought to be angrier.
If it came to a wolfbitch fight, the girls from Ginger Snaps could rip up the entire werewolf race from Blood and Chocolate without mussing their fur.
... this gripping character study becomes more agonisingly suspenseful as it gets closer to an answer that can't be confirmed.

Clever parody of the sequel trend; once again we are treated to a movie mocking its own conventions. Some great comic -- and terrifying -- moments, but suffers for not being as original as the original.
Beautiful photography, a heartbreaking story, and iconic moments from beginnning to end. Absolutely unmissable.
It uses Caribbean folklore and weird religious imagery to spice up a romantic tangle that pays off.
Acutely observed, beautifully performed, lovingly directed media morality tale that resonates far beyond its 1950s setting.
Previously, Jigsaw and the filmmakers played fair, but too much about this latest instalment seems simply arbitrary.
More Damon Runyan than Irvine Welsh, but as entertaining as it is important.
movie_title: The Man With the Golden Arm (1955)

movie_review_blurb: By refusing to explain Ripley, this gets closer to Highsmith's character than any other film version.
That this is just about passable as a divorced parent's weekend treat is down to Roberts' charm and the timeless appeal of Nancy herself.
A little bit of going through the motions with this horror spoof but fans will enjoy

Make up your own sheep-related pun - ewe'll love it, mutton to be ashamed of, ram-bunctious etc. If you only see one zombie sheep movie, you won't have a lot of choice, but this certainly delivers all you could wish for.
This take on Halloween is grim and nasty, but never remotely scary.
It relates to Night Watch the way X2 relates to X-Men: you need to have seen the earlier film to have a hope of following the plot, but it's a bigger, deeper, more exhilarating ride.
Even though he was just staring out, Kubrick instantly mastered the crime genre. A stunning film.
Kubrick's second feature shows his promise as a powerful and iconic director in motifs and style.
This offers moments of suspense, some pointed scenes and star charisma, but it's also a touch confused. Heads will be scratched before they roll.
One of those little science fiction movies that, once seen (and it's a TV staple) is never forgotten.
Still the greatest multi-story ghost/horror picture.
In 1982, Paul Schrader seemed a very odd choice to remake Val Lewton's classic 1943 horror movie. The original was a model of restraint and subtlety and the remake, frankly, isn't.
It may be one of the most famous, but it's certainly not an original on which others are based.
Great effects for its time and some incredible performances makes this a true cinema classic.
A surprisingly yet successfully restrained lesson in how to haunt a house.
Cronenberg attempting a little mainstream with this Stephen King yarn and really pulling it off.

Shot in a grainy grey and white helps to give the film an amateurish and at the same time realistic feel, particularly as it's based on true events. With standout performances from Lo Bianco and Stoler, this is a forgotten gem.
For the viewer, too, this creepy mood-piece is far from a comfortable watch.
movie_title: What Ever Happened to Baby Jane? (1962)

movie_review_blurb: A standard shudder picture, with an impressive, chilling apparition.
Savagely witty on backstage life and audaciously edited.
An injection of adrenaline straight to the eye - which isn't entirely a bad thing.
An effective, scary emotional work-out, but perhaps you can have too much paranoid despair.
Even by their high standards, the performances of Weaver and Kingsley here are impressive, and Polanski ratchetts up the tension nicely. A chilling and thought-provoking piece.
A disturbing and poignant anthology of Roman Polanski's favourite, oppressive themes.
Not cheery, but gripping, against-the-odds funny and uncomfortably unique. Johnson and Ferdinando are certainly now names to watch.
Genuinely original interpretation of the Brit gangster and Lewis Carroll's surreal tale.

Alternating between gritty realism and red-hued fantasy, this is one of those 70s films that has worn well, managing to be universal in its heart while picking out specifics that now look exactly of their time.
Atmospheric, with authentic 60s/70s capering all over Brazil.
movie_title: OSS 117: Rio ne répond plus (Lost in Rio) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Mad Max 2 with Thought for the Day thrown in. There's some ace post-holocaust action, but you can't help feel you were invited to a party with fizzy pop and cream cake and got suckered into a sermon instead.
A great evening at the theatre, maybe. It has enough straight to-camera emotion and anecdote to provide clips for a wealth of acting awards nominations, but too rarely feels like a movie.
Alvin must be the most unsympathetic lead in any kiddie franchise, and having him do squeaked-up De Niro impersonations doesn't help.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Atmospheric, mesmerising and darkly humourous with a sizzling script and cast. This is a true classic of its genre.
For curious completists only.
It's deliberately chilly, and feels like a series of overheard conversations rather than a story, obliging you to listen for barbs among the trivialities.
It sets out to be less pompous than similar films, which inevitably means it feels less substantial. While amusing rather than hilarious, it ought to establish Matt Damon as a star character actor.
Fundamentally terrible, but almost irresistibly entertaining. Its horrors get a tad monotonous in the mid-section, but it's still a value-for-money hoot.
Liable to disappear mysteriously from cinemas.
It has a quality cast, but we've run round this track too many times, while the script jogs from scene to scene without any surprises.
The set-up is deceptively low-key, but the second and third acts deliver textbook suspense and horror.
Not without interest, but less satisfying than even an average Hammer horror.
Blaxploitation meets vampire movie that's formulaic and full of holes.
Funny and scary, this is vintage Polanski.
A really satisfying backstage drama, this is an exhilarating tour around a man whose talent was almost as big as his ego.
In a word, ugly. It just pips Halloween: The Curse of Michael Myers (aka Halloween 6) to the title of worst Halloween film ever.
Slow-building dread rather than all-out splat, House keeps you guessing which way the sneaky plot is going, all adding up to a satisfying shocker.
Not a dry eye in the house - but not irritating schmaltz either.
Entertaining and powerful, if hurried. It needs a killer Part Three to make it a trilogy, not a hit with sequels.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Russ Meyer does mainstream, kind of.
movie_title: Beyond the Valley of the Dolls (1970)

movie_review_blurb: Remember the film you hoped Snakes On A Plane would be -- this is it!
With dark humour from time to time, underneath an extremely repulsive concept, this is a relatively conventional horror movie.
Humane and harrowing, highly recommended. This one will stay with you.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It doesn't go the complete distance, but this is a wholly admirable, refreshingly grown-up science-fiction movie: a Frankenstein with a beating, gene-spliced heart and top-of-the-range performances.
Cheerfully catch-all.
A solidly okay Saturday night effort, but unambitious considering the talent involved. Maybe Rodriguez should direct Predator Resurrection, but get a science fiction writer to script it.
Essential for Doors fans, but enlightening to the uninitiated. A tantalising study of a troubled creator whose charisma still borders on the supernatural. Great music, too.
Shutter Island offers sumptuous, enthralling, shivery gothic filmmaking with a hardboiled heart and a sly line in asylum humour.
A nerve-fraying new take on the home-invasion horror.
Effective jump-shocks and a strong turn from Eddie Marsan mask an over-complicated last act.
Guaranteed to offend a lot of folks across the political and belief spectrum, but consistently funny and horribly to the point.
A small but perfectly formed crime drama. And, without making a fuss, a proper nail-biter, too.
Valhalla Rising gets into your mind and stays there. You can argue what, if anything, it's trying to say, but it is impressive cinema.
As a sports movie and as a mixed-up teen flick, it keeps taking unexpected turns, and unlike so many in the former genre, remembers there's more to sport dramas than just winning.
All the head-crushing and thigh-flexing doesn't compensate for the monotony of a story that simply traipses from one combat (sorry, kombat) to the next.
Game over, man.
The one interesting idea -- what would a town be like if all the teenagers in it had been slaughtered in five movies? -- is thrown away with a few cheap jokes.
Possibly the lamest of all the sequels, although Five and Six later set the bar particularly low.
movie_title: A Nightmare on Elm Street 2: Freddy's Revenge (1985)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps you can be too cool for school and too clever for a multiplex, but if you're willing to go along with this, you'll enjoy being fooled so much that you won't mind it's all a trick.
Inventive and genuinely suspenseful, this is a welcome addition to the expanding zombie/virus canon.
Pandorum is a hodge-podge of familiar sci-fi stuff, which feels as if it were adapted from a computer game.
Even the gratuitous nudity can't quite save a Heathers-goes-to-college horror that's undermined by a silly plot and clunky dialogue.

An admirably non-formulaic drama, which manages to reconcile the opposed British film traditions of contemporary, realistic, low-key character drama with eccentric, flamboyant, Gothic fantasy. It certainly marks out McMorrow as a talent to watch.
Unlucky for almost everyone. It's a sad day when a Friday the 13th remake is shown up by a My Bloody Valentine remake - couldn't they at least have sprung for 3-D?
It does develop powerfully the themes of Schrader's earlier work and will not disappoint his fans.
Writer-director Sean Ellis is influenced by M. Night Shyamalan, and manages an approximation of both Shyamalan's habitual look and whispery melodramatics.
A needless threequel. Note to director: avoid 'rise of the' titles.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a shaggy-dog story that spirals into garage Grand Guignol, with Suvari and Rea well-matched in uneasy roles.
Displaying admirable love for pulp material and striking enviably sexy poses, but missing the emotional resonance, zeitgeist-catching populism and mainstream thrills which found movie franchises.
Admirable within its limitations, but Bernard Schlink's Oprah Winfrey Book Club-approved book wasn't exactly literature, as this isn't exactly cinema.
Magical, if messy - this gets by on a good heart, high adventure and an unashamed love for books.
Darker and more subtly complex than you'd expect from a 1950s crime caper.

As a thriller it's solid three-star tension. As a Samuel L. Jackson showcase it proves a man can only coast through so many motherfuckin' or milquetoastin' turns before having to display his full and overpowering talent.
The guy story is so strong that conventional romantic interludes with the woman torn between two men could easily have been dropped.
A pacy, visually imaginative follow-up to the series relaunch. If it doesn't even try to be bigger and better than Casino Royale, that's perhaps a smart move.
It's nothing wildly original, but it is pacey and entertaining when it gets going.
This is the best bond movie since On Her Majesty's Secret Service.
Despite being not officially a Bond film this is good solid, entertaining action.
After the fizzle of the later Roger Moore Bonds, The Living Daylights brings in a new 007 in Timothy Dalton, who manages the Connery trick of seeming suave and tough at the same time.
The main problem with Mirrors is its truly clunky screenplay, which fails to support the often stylish visuals.
It has few fireworks, but still sticks in the mind, and is a definite upgrade from Digimon: The Movie for director Mamoru Hosoda.
movie_title: The Girl Who Leapt Through Time (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's a shaggy dog story, with a script obviously made up as the film was being shot, but reasonably engrossing as the directors enjoy exaggerating their own mannerisms.
Fascinating history, very good movie - but demanding, and its lack of easy answers will frustrate some. Lessons about 21st century terrorism are implicit, but not overly stressed.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An elegant, entertaining, informative picture with a gallery of vivid supporting turns, this provisionally crowns the winning Blunt as a Brit-pic star - but it skimps a bit on the bodice-ripping, blood and thunder.
Certifiable classic territory, Hitchcock's glossiest entertainment is the closest the trickster ever came to an action movie.
A nerve-shredding masterpiece.

Gorgeous and seductive, if pitched at Almodóvar fans and perhaps a touch long. Those drawn by Cruz's divadom will wonder why it takes so long to get to her - though she is wholly dazzling when it does.
Predictable and been-there, seen-that, but entertaining nevertheless at times.
Daft, plain daft. With a few daft but spectacular stunts.
Watch the first episode but stop after that.
An instant gangster classic.
Instantly gripping, with a powerhouse star performance, it'll make you want to speed through the weeks to get to part two.
movie_title: Mesrine: Part 1 (Killer Instinct) and Part 2 (Public Enemy #1) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Scott's style, all staccato edits and blurry panic, pays off in a few minor scenes, though it's a pity a sub-plot traffic accident has more impact than the main event.
Nick Moran definitely emphasizes certain characteristics of the idiosyncratic producer over others for affect, but this is still as fascinating portraits in parts.
A thought-provoking ordeal is repackaged as a middling shocker which leaves you feeling good about revenge.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It doesn't bother much with establishing rules for its supernatural menace or stitching together set-pieces with anything but Sellotape, but it's consistently funny in a painful way.
What Lars is driving at is something completely bizarre, massively uncommercial and strangely perfect.
A fresh, surprising take on an old, old story (and an overpopulated subgenre) that holds the attention with deadly wit.
Given that it combines religious, scientific, political, art historical and academic lunacy in one package, Angels & Demons is at least more entertaining than the dreary, talky Da Vinci Code.
Bogdanovich's perfect recreation of the sense of time and place, and his ability to mix wit with poignancy that make this such a charming, timeless film.
Poor remake of the Korean thriller.

A film version of fish and chips - humble, honest fare that's ludicrous, inventive, gory within limits, and has a cast having so much fun it's hard not to be swept along with them. And besides, you can't have nouvelle cuisine every night of the week.
Mid-list Herzog, but still a stimulating, strange experience. And that tragically perverse penguin is the most memorable movie animal of the year.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: At once a devastating, curiously uplifting inhuman drama and a superbly crafted genre exercise, Let The Right One In can stand toe-to-toe with Spirit Of The Beehive, Pan's Labyrinth or Orphee. See it.

If it were a DVD, you'd Fast & Forward to the chases, but not Forgive & Forget the crushing disappointment. In cinemas, you have to endure exposition and sob-you-were-my-best-friend scenes. It's clearly time for Fast & Furious Vs. The Transporter...
Besides a big heart, it has outstanding 3-D action sequences
Hitch's remake of his own film results in an equally compelling action thriller with sterling performances from Stewart and Day.
movie_title: The Man Who Knew Too Much (1956)

movie_review_blurb: One of those movies you remember Great Moments from.
Prestigious, well turned out piece of British historical drama with enough genuine intrigue and wit to persuade some audiences they aren't watching a history lesson.
The air of desperation is emphasised by the insistence on padding out horror-movie gags with crude Farrelly-style humour.
There are enough strong moments to guarantee a good night out.

The question of where ethnic comedy stops and cruel stereotype begins also gets lost as the cast improv well beyond any given scene's point, and it can all end only with a contrived last act of kidnappings and shoot-outs with the cops.
Brando's magnetism is eternal.
Director Singer actually lived in the tunnels himself for a while, so the result is fascinating and never patronising.
The lamest of the three versions but the performances are bearable.
As disturbing as it set out to be. This may not be an enjoyable experience but it is definitely an experience.
movie_title: Salò o le 120 giornate di Sodoma (Salò, or the 120 Days of Sodom) (1979)

movie_review_blurb: Fast and loose, with a buzzing sense of the potential of the cinema undercut by the beginnings of Godard's intellectual rigour.
A very rich film, confident enough in its emotional core to get away with broadstrokes like the villainous performances of Freddie Jones and Michael Elphick as rotten exploiters.
Great performances, moments and ideas. If it doesn't provide the tidy ending that made The Sixth Sense a talking-point, that might not be a bad thing.
For Winona Ryder completists, maverick Biblical scholars, fans of monied Manhattan interiors and Mark Kermode. All others, beware.
If you want your trilogy to become a franchise, make something grander than Scream 3.
Taken as a sequel to Halloween, this is just above average; taken as a sequel to Halloween Two, which is where most of its backstory comes from, it looks terrific.
For once, a great remake, smartly executed. Great performances and a killing ending that will stay with you forever can't hurt, either.
... the solemn young Sekiguchi is a real find, complementing his co-star and never becoming as icky as the brats who'd be up for a Hollywood remake.
Surprisingly, even after waiting 20 years, they managed to turn out a smart, darkly-comic thriller with some imaginitive twists.
The film's unconventional style gives druggy magic enough to get over a plot which might seem like a downer, and deliver something genuinely worthwhile.
...an uneasy mix of laughs and thrills; suspense and soap.
Not to everyone's taste but certainly haunting in theme and visuals.
A big studio film, with still-superb sea sequences and a then-daring erotic interlude with the native girls of Pitcairn Island, this remains irresistible.
Less historical spectacle than vicious farce, this boasts a great cast spitting venomous dialogue and a young Anthony Hopkins and Timothy Dalton as gay lovers destined to rule England and France.
A bewildering and frustrating experience.
A classic horror that warms the heart.

The big attraction is the iron giant itself. At one stage, it transforms into a scary alien being with War Of The Worlds heat-rays and impressive zapping capability, but it is mostly a lovably old-fashioned, clanking 'bot.
A somewhat awkward plot, and too many scenes consisting of people in meetings or singing protest songs.
The question the film asks is, "Why not?" Surely life is to be enjoyed? The answer is grimmer than you expect.
A full measure of Toy Story 2's success can be gauged by its undeniable appeal for children who have never seen a Western television show or played with a cowboy toy.
There are genuinely imaginative special effects which manage to be recognisably in the spirit of the cheesy originals.
This follow-up, whose natural home would seem to be video rental stores rather than local multiplexes, lacks Gordon's wit and grit.
A terrific suspense movie, overlaid with a faintly embarrassing tale of faith lost and perhaps regained.
This comedy tells truths about American business and sexual morés as uncomfortable now as they were in 1960.
Scorcese drew seminal and genuinely creepy performances from his stars in this thriller remake.
A substantial and affecting piece of work.
Full of deftly handled small moments and characters.
Only the total collapse of Hollywood can save us from a reprise of My Mother the Car.
Worryingly satisfying in a purely gruesome, beat-em-up kinda way.
The original film, itself no masterpiece, at least had a strong premise, from Lois Duncan's novel, and complicated its characterisations by an unusual class awareness.
movie_title: I Still Know What You Did Last Summer (1998)

movie_review_blurb: This shows signs of being a lasting work, a film that shifts and changes along with the viewer, upon which all commentary is necessarily provisional.
Quote not available.
The main attraction, however, is Willis H. O'Brien's pre-King Kong stop motion monster effects.
Karen Walton's sharp screenplay is especially strong in the family scenes, allowing performances of Heavenly Creatures intensity from the young leads.
Likeable despite its silliness, Evolution delivers a solid entertainment package.
Not only is the guy playing Dracula not terrific, he barely even registers on screen.
It's more of an art movie than a thriller, but it's still gripping, persuasive, unsettling stuff.
This is first-rate filmmaking, horrific and tender, raw and lyrical.
The book is a deserved classic, but this film loses most of the tension and all of the terror in the transition.
Manages somehow to be rather endearing.
Significantly worse than the rest of the series, this film is one of the worst bell-flops in recent cinema.
The best imaginable film of very difficult material.
A dazzling spy thriller that's still amazing.
New York cop thriller with a touch of the Westerna and a touch of the Eastwood...and all the better for it.
While Harrelson and Love deliver convincing performances, in the end this is a distended account of a revolting couple which dodges the issue.

Though not as deep, philosophical or vocally star-studded as Antz, Pixar's insect nation is every bit as eye-popping, and kids who don't love it are very likely to become zealous members of some future Trenchcoat Mafia.
The film is full of moments of stifled hilarity...
movie_title: Ghost Dog - The Way of the Samurai (2000)

movie_review_blurb: An enormously energetic, flavourful film.
Gorgeously shot in luminous monochrome, it's all wrapped up with an extremely suspenseful last reel.
With its amazing widescreen compositions and epic running time, this Western truly wins points for length and width.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the West (1968)

movie_review_blurb: Witty screenplay.
The in-joke -peppered dialogue is consistently brilliant and the genial Shatner allows himself to be sent up nicely.
Witty, suspenseful, sad, funny and wise.

It's a film you might argue with, but its sparing use of on-screen violence, some extraordinarily protracted scenes and sensitive handling of thorny subject matter make it also a film you ought to see.
With its enigmatic and simple premise, this works best as a series of nerve-stretching suspense sequences as the characters try to get past the killing traps.
It's impossible to care about Cage's mission.
movie_title: Gone in 60 Seconds (Gone in Sixty Seconds) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: It's one of the franchise's highlights, and if the dated action can be forgiven, a cracking cold war story.
While not to everyone's tastes, this is without doubt one of the most exhilarating films of 1994.
Its commitment to palaeontological credibility still takes a back seat to storytelling, with a lot more disaster and conflict than leaf-munching and hibernating.
The worst offence committed is a waste of talents in casting powerhouse players Tucci and Grier in stereotype 'other cop' roles.
Its matter-of-fact tone and concentration on nuance of character in frank sex scenes renders it moving and involving rather than lurid and gratuitous.
The most purely horrifying horror movie ever made.
Instantly gripping, with a powerhouse star performance, it'll make you want to speed through the weeks to get to part two.
With a debut like this, it's no wonder that it spawned one of the biggest franchises ever.
Struggles longer than you expect it will to deliver a happy ending.
This ghost stuff works on a deeper level than the gross-out, and it's nice that Hollywood has rediscovered the art of the soul-freezing scare.
The Straight Story, perfectly titled on several levels, is an exercise in strange sweetness that wouldn't have shamed John Ford at his most elegiac.
Vincent Gallo's ego gets the better of his storytelling in his acting-directing-writing debut, but there are flashes of genuis that make it worth watching.
A very black comedy.
This makes you think harder about crime and punishment than, say, The Green Mile, delivering uneasy truths rather than comforting melodrama.
With narration from all four of the principles and a script that keeps piling on the moral dilemmas, this never settles for easy moralities.
The Warriors as pre-imagined by Gene Kelly, this really is the musical for people who don't like musicals.
A funny, brutal, scary movie, daringly surreal in its mix of Western and horror themes.
Oliver Stone's war classic is overlooked sometimes because of it's brutal but long-winded potrayal of the duality of man. This however remains gripping stuff.
Made in 1971, based on a novel from 1962, A Clockwork Orange resonates across the years.
Despite the pleasant feel and fun performance from Zane there's something missing from this superhero adventure.
Thoughtful trial movie with a disturbing edge.

Shot in grainy, high-contrast black-and-white with a lot of simple but effective optical and aural tricks to suggest the workings of Max's unusual mind, this is one of the most intimate movies in recent memory.

With rap music, scratch cuts, sudden explosions from ticking bomb characters, verbal and physical strutting and a heavy dose of morality, it's a super-charged, intensely-played picture which will edge most of its cast up the ladder.
Cruise, with a sharklike stance, gives a career-best performance as a total bastard.
Confidently cinematic in classical and modern terms, layered with subtleties but also a straight-ahead, crowd-pleasing comedy.
A witty, smart and knowing picture that marks a kind of return to form for both its male stars.
A masterpiece.
It's a tactfully acted film, beautifully shot in snowy widescreen, subtly scripted and directed with a rare touch.
Pacino's outstanding work elevates this to the crime movie pantheon.
It's less satisfying than the more idea-driven original, but this is still top-flight kick-ass entertainment.
The effect is as horribly funny as it is depressing, but gets pretty hard to take after a while, especially for anyone who is a committed cat-lover.
No mere creature feature, this 1940s classic offers more subtle chills.
It doesn't help that the film's premise, which sees stoneage cavemen turn into ace fighter pilots with only a week's training, is as naive as that of the 1939 serial Buck Rogers.
This is a footnote rather than a film.
Bats sticks to the ground rules of its genre and gets through a story at once predictable and preposterous with an ingratiating absence of pretension.
There is something badly wrong with the film's premise, which contradicts Milne's lessons that Tigger can't climb trees ... and that, crucially, Tigger can't be unbounced.

Contrary to pre-release nay-sayers, Daniel Craig has done more with James Bond in one film than some previous stars have in multiple reprises. This is terrific stuff, again positioning 007 as the action franchise to beat.
The best-looking Star Wars episode of all, if not the most exciting, most imaginative or most affecting.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Despite admirable chest thumping and Watts' wonderfully enhanced scream, there is still only one true king.
Fascinating, funny, wicked and to the point, this is an excellent film about a week every Briton over the age of 15 will remember vividly.
The dismal subject matter is beautifully shot, but Tideland merrily dances on the line between the merely unpleasant and the completely unwatchable.

A necessary counter-argument to the wave of patriotic 9/11 movies, this homes in on the other side of disaster and rings horribly true in the wake of the Washington anthrax scare and post-Katrina New Orleans.
All very well, but it is by no means the giddy delight that the fans hoped for.
Its intelligence makes it near-essential viewing.
Dahl's best film to date with twists galore and an energised performance from Fiorentino.
Dark, twisted and beautiful, this entwines fairy-tale fantasy with war-movie horror to startling effect.
Suprisingly no-holds-barred portrait of institutional bullying for such an early film.
movie_title: I Am a Fugitive From a Chain Gang (1932)

movie_review_blurb: It can still hold its own against the new generation of horror films still sourcing it. Well worth a look.
Loud, noisy, flashy but too rarely chilling.
Superb supporting performances from Polley and Baulk go some way to making up for our hero's lesser qualities.
You've been here before when it was fresher.
Worse than Scary Movies 1 through 3... And they were terrible.
If Charlie and the Chocolate Factory was Burton's big picture for 2005, this is his miniature.
A smart script, edgy acting and a gradual accumulation of suspense set-pieces makes for a decent popcorn high.
Gruesome schlock -- but whether it's beyond or beneath criticism is a matter of individual taste.
Martin, please stop making films.
A curiously resistable drama, despite several strong elements -- the most notable being newcomer Idina Menzel.
This is one of those rare films that truly manages to get by on unintentional laughs, but otherwise dreadful.
It requires a stretch of the imagination too far, but there's still plenty of gore and tricksy murders here.
This is a satisfying, spicy little picture.
If you can get through the confusing goings-on of the first reel, then this is a satisfying experience -- funny, touching and tragic by turns. And Giamatti deserves every award going.
If you can take Sandler for more than five minutes, this is his funniest film to date.
Definitely recommended for those looking for something different.
Bad idea. Bad film.
Gere does a great deal in solo scenes with no dialogue, suggesting that he might not be as alone in the dark as he seems.
Shamelessly silly, Bless The Child notches up the clichés as the daft story meanders towards a suitably hammy conclusion.
Director Beck loses it, with techno-scored flashbacks (note: techno isn't scary) and blow-up-the-place gimmickry...

Slowly paced for a thriller and with a hero many will find off-putting, this is nevertheless a gripping, unusual and challenging work from the most consistently brilliant filmmakers of the last decade.
A true evocation of the spirit of the Strand Magazine, this is the best Holmes movie ever made and sorely underrated in the Wilder canon.
movie_title: The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes (1970)

movie_review_blurb: This energetically charmless 'family' fantasy lies there dead on screen, occasionally twitching at a funny line.
Some will be uncomfortable or appalled, and the mix of humour and horror is uneasy, but this isn't a film you'll forget easily. And, seriously, what would you do?
A movie masterpiece. And on the big screen, the chestburster scene just kills.
For those with an appreciation for weirdness, this is an extremist on form.
The big battles impress, but become somewhat samey. Part Three is threatened.
A rare horror film in which the heroes are better drawn than the monsters, this trips up because Schaech doesn't cut it as a master fiend and the car chases distract from the dread.
This is the best type of documentary, giving an intensely personal story you can't help but become involved in, and also raises fundamental issues about America in the 90s.
A rare, clever, horror film.
Call an ambulance. This mess is in need of a bodybag.
A successful mix of literary adaptation, meta-fictional discourse and inside-showbiz comedy. Both funny and clever.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: There are moments of interesting honesty, and the players get to enjoy some meaty roles - especially Quaid, nicely underplaying one of the least showiest roles he's had in years.
Curiously fun-free, drab and ho-hum.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Van Sant's least 'show-offy', most personal, best picture in years (maybe ever), and an honourable attempt at respectfully considering the unbearable.
Even when in danger of self-destructing, it cadges laughs with smart lines, silly observations or blokish inside jokes about zombie movies, video games and pub nibbles.
What might have made for exciting action scenes tend to become mechanical exercises in first-person-shooter monster-blasting.

Asian horror can't go on much longer adhering to such standard rules, but for now it's frightening and effective.
It's as wistful and sad as it is funny and charming, with the first of Nino Rota's great scores to keep it burbling along.
This summer picture has a brain as well as muscles.
A must for fans of horror and of Bergman. So good it makes you wish he had dabbled in the genre that bit more often.
As a film, it is at once too much a part of an overarching story and divided into too many episodes to be all of a piece. However, as a sustained collection of scare moments, it's a winner.
Though this stuff could have been directed by anyone, the greatness of Spartacus is in the stretches everyone remembers.
Ragged, of course, but powerful, moving stuff.
This is nothing short of magisterial.
Tender, melancholy, suspenseful and, finally, uplifting.

Very silly: sometimes almost enjoyably so, often just in a tired way.
A great comic-book movie.
An enigmatic, poetic, disturbing, interestingly pretentious fable.
Disorientating, but good performances all round. Will have you thinking for days afterwards.

It's an infalliby funny gambit...
It's completely daft, and the one-liners are by now just plain cheesy, but there's a good deal of gore to keep the faithful amused, if not completely happy.

This is the ultimate expression of the American cinema's greatest fetishes: big breasts, fast cars, tight jeans, and sudden death. This is, in its own way, one of the great films of the 60's.
An effort that's somehow both depressing and trivial.
It's simply the best trial movie ever made.
Impressive performances, fascinating info-bytes and pertinent editorial, but in the end, it feels too much like an illustrated lecture.
As good an all-out, non-camp horror movie as we've had lately.
A memorable film that is still regarded as a psychedelic classic.

A brilliantly structured adventure movie.

By turns engaging and confusing, an intriguing film.

movie_review_blurb: Despite everything, it's still a marvellously energetic movie.
Enjoyable monster movie with some pretty decent performances.

Indispensible.
Unclassifiable odd masterpiece.
Effective melodrama with some satisfying emotional confrontations, particularly from Lana Turner.
A grab bag of bits from the whole demons-and-angels spectrum.

Underrated satirical musical that has contributed more to popular culture than many people are aware of.
Impressively nightmarish.

A good British sci-fi thriller that makes good use of tight spaces.

Extremely likable, with a few moments of proper wonder.
