Prisoners is a dense, cold film rife with religious symbolism and moral ambiguity.
What sells The Family is its cast; in particular, De Niro and Pfeiffer, who are charming and believable as a couple fluent in each other's faults but still unabashedly in love.
It's an excuse for a 90-minute orgy of car chases and crashes that thoroughly tests the audience's endurance and patience.
You're Next offers the perfect set-up for a home invasion film: a family's weekend reunion at a secluded estate with murderous masked intruders.
It's an occasionally serious film that never strays from its superhero roots.

It's Mirren again playing against type that proves most satisfying. Watching the 68-year-old and still dazzling actress wield guns with the best of 'em and calmly eradicate the corpse of a fresh kill with a bottle of acid is novel and darkly pleasurable.

Deathly Hallows is the first Harry Potter film that fully delivers on the promise of J.K. Rowling's works, expertly balancing a tricky and expansive narrative, along with quiet character moments and some rollicking action sequences.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Pacific Rim is the Godzilla movie that should have been.

[Verbinski] crams as much big-budget exhilaration into his movie as its origin story will permit, creating a film less about its namesake as it is large-scale action sequences, explosions, and CGI stunts.
Even with its nearly two-hour run time, The Heat is consistently funny.

The heart of the film is Crystal and Goodman, who remain as funny, spunky, and relatable as you remember. Their buddy-buddy chemistry is so natural, the actors could team up for several more Monsters films.

Playing the reluctant hero dragged into service, Pitt neither oversells Lane's bravery and action-hero abilities nor underplays his strength and quick-thinking skills. It's a restrained but effective performance.
Man of Steel is an expensive set-up piece that puts everything and everyone in the familiar positions, but moves no further.
While it's nice to have a Vaughn and Wilson buddy-up again, we can only wish they'd crashed another comedy instead.
For a father-son film project, there's strangely little emotional connection between the pair onscreen.
The Hangover Part III is the encore to a concert that's gone on too long: You know what's coming and you can't wait for it to end.
This film is about pushing driving stunts to new limits and further from what we've seen in the other installments.
There's a palpable new comfort level among the performers in their iconic roles for the second time and working from a script that has moved beyond introductions and reacquaintances for audiences.
Restless, largely unfocused, and always in motion.
There's undeniable humor in this comedy of errors of three bumbling criminals, and Wahlberg, Johnson, and Mackie strike the right tone in their performances.
Even as so many once-bankable action stars ungracefully age out of the genre, Cruise reclaims it... and returns to doing what he does best.
By no means a masterpiece, the full-length computer-generated animated film nevertheless has freed Spielberg from the shackles of conventional filmmaking and physical limitations.
Not as consistently funny as the original, Despicable Me 2 still proves itself a quite-capable sequel, one that moves the characters and their stories along in humorous and often sweet ways.

Without a loaded cast, or recognizable character name or brand, Arthur Christmas might be overlooked by audiences. Here's hoping that won't be the case. Some Christmas gifts are worth the extra effort.
A superhero in film is only as good as his villain. And that's a critical problem for Iron Man 3.
The powerful drama stars Reese Witherspoon in her strongest performance since her Oscar-winning turn as June Carter Cash in 2005's Walk the Line.
For those who want to see their superheroes grow up, Logan is a satisfying vision of what that real-world mutant would be.
Personal history is an enchanting muse, particularly in the hands of a skilled and thoughtful filmmaker whose story is worth sharing.
A darkly sweet tale about an outcast and the monster who heals him.

What carries this screen version of Wilson's work is the ability of these actors to keep our attention hostage for two-plus hours and make us feel for these characters, even when we don't always believe the words they say.
La La Land is a Christmas miracle for these coldhearted times: a vibrant and emotive present that warms the soul with good cheer as a celebration of a film genre and the indefatigable human spirit.
Save for the on-screen coupling of Lawrence and Pratt, Passengers is a quick trip just as quickly forgotten.
It ranks among the series' best -- just below A New Hope and The Empire Strikes Back (Episodes IV and V), and just above The Force Awakens.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Chastain is so good at the steely-eye determinism of Sloane, in the believability of what she does, and in making us understand why she does it, that the character is likable and even relatable despite her repugnant win-at-all-cost methods.
As an animated film, Moana isn't close to ranking among Disney's best. But as a tropical postcard on the big screen, the animation couldn't be more spectacular and inviting.
Words have meaning, Arrival reminds us, and communication is the way forward for humanity, especially in times of great uncertainty when the world seems to be at a crisis point.
A mind-bending, exciting, funny, and, yes, strange adventure, that ranks among Marvel's best, and as a superhero introduction film is second to only 2008's Iron Man.

It's less intrusive and gimmicky [as The Da Vinci Code], but it's also not as enjoyable -- particularly since so much of the movie is familiar, as they go from museum to museum, dodging bad guys and trying to solve the mystery.

[The franchise struggles] to balance its heroes and villains; even Knepper, a character actor known for playing bad men, fails to make an impression, not unlike Werner Herzog's turn as the main bad guy in the first Jack Reacher.
Reflecting its conventional storytelling, The Birth of a Nation relies heavily on Civil War-era stereotypes and stock characters, limiting its cast to little to no nuance in their roles.

Unfortunately for those looking for a different kind of hero, The Accountant's promising premise is subverted by hackneyed genre conventions and third-act silliness that set up the character for more big-screen adventures.

Perhaps the biggest twist to The Girl on the Train is that this menagerie of bleak souls doesn't vitiate the film, but redeems it, amid a flurry of surprises that provide, if nothing else, empathy for their cause.
Despite the film's flaws, the peculiarity of it all holds interests and carries through, until that rushed third act -- as if Burton simply lost focus and wanted it all to be over.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Fuqua isn't interested in the contemporary Western. His Magnificent Seven is a throwback to those decades-old films that informed him as an impressionable and young filmmaker. But to live in history invites comparisons to what was.
Relying on the same technique, however well done, is like a plate of warmed-up leftovers from last night's wonderful meal. It's never as good the second time.

Pete's Dragon is delightfully low key and delicate... It's a film about characters, story, and emotions that also happens to have a CGI dragon in it -- one that is effectively brought to life through the animation.
Even Smith's smart-aleck charm comes up short, with Deadshot's lines either not very funny or out of place to what's happening in the film.
Fortunately for Greengrass, the likability of Damon in this role can carry the film through almost any detours.
Star Trek Beyond is a mea culpa to fans who felt the new film series abandoned the franchise's network TV roots.
Ghostbusters wants to be its own comedy, but it won't let go of the past, including various cameos from the former Ghostbusters cast that stick out like Halloween decor at Christmas.
An adorable and occasionally quite funny computer-animated film about what domesticated animals are up to when their masters aren't around that never ingratiates the heart.

It's Oscar winner Rylance's warm-hearted motion-capture performance -- his BFG moves with human-like fluidity and grace -- along with John Williams' familiar and sweet score, that gives The BFG its soul.
This is a brainy, brawny popcorn pleaser at its best. And one not easily forgotten.

Just when it appears Finding Dory is the latest in a long line of sequel casualties, the deliriously fun and witty third act arrives to mount a revival, as everything comes together and the setups finally deliver laugh-out-loud payoffs.

At its best, Warcraft is a passable and occasionally mildly entertaining fantasy film. Unfortunately, the rest of the time it's a slog of an epic by a director struggling to condense an unwieldy fantasy not of his own making.
It may be Beauty who killed the Beast in the original King Kong, but in Kong: Skull Island it's the lackluster screenplay that takes down this not-so-great ape.

The songs are still lovely. The story still timeless. And when Beauty and the Beast is good, it's joyful and fun. But even in its best moments, this remake only reminds you of why you fell in love with Disney's animated take on this tale to begin with.
By carrying such little significance to the movie - no one watches a Fast and Furious film for its literate script - the plot can stand to be as illogical as it is under-developed.
It hurtles past at dizzying speed with a slew of new characters, soap opera-like motivations and confrontations, and goofy-ridiculous adventures, tasking audiences to keep up with it all.
What began as a fun and unique high-concept comedy with 2006's Night at the Museum is by this third installment bereft of life and creativity.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: While the big-name cast in A Wrinkle in Time is great for marketing, there's a star problem in the film, and it's not Winfrey.
This outing doesn't go so well, with Game Night's inconsistent laughs and a plot that's too silly even for a comedy.
Not since Christopher Nolan's The Dark Knight Rises has a superhero film so openly expressed politics - not so much ideology but a cultural mood - and taken so many chances.

The striking cinematography by Masanobu Takayanagi, enhances Hostile's vivid contrast between what's beautiful and ugly in this world, and Cooper's screenplay ... is a challenging balance between extreme violence and thoughtful reflection.

Most importantly, Call Me By Your Name is an honest story of hearts on fire, broken, and then healed, with wise affection for its characters and their struggles, and a message of tolerance and love for us all.

A surprisingly funny faux documentary with obvious affection for its beleaguered namesake, I, Tonya does what 25 years ago seemed impossible: It makes the derided and even despised Tonya Harding empathetic and human.
Historical irony, no matter how relevant, means little to movie-goers if a film isn't well told and well executed. And few filmmakers tell and direct a story better than Spielberg.
Chastain is fierce in a role that echoes that of a similarly tough-but-flawed D.C. lobbyist in last year's Miss Sloane.
The result is a convoluted satire with so many critiques and messages, it's pointless rather than pointed.
Why The Disaster Artist works so well is that it doesn't judge our reactions to it; the film is not in the slightest ironic or, as is fashionable these days, meta.
Coco's heart is its ethnicity.
Justice League is one of those superhero films that you can't help but cheer on. Those smiles and laughs by these heroes, as it turns out, are as contagious as their frowns.

Even when the plot and pacing slow considerably in the middle of Murder on the Orient Express, during what's mainly busy work for the detective, Branagh as Poirot still makes this train trip worthwhile.

Watching a 7-year-old boy with an overactive imagination play with his four Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle action figures would be more enjoyable and more coherent than what Green and company managed with this film.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The balance of humor and action has become so one-sided that Thor: Ragnarok could use a laugh track.
As to the those big questions ... Blade Runner 2049 is conclusive about most things, but also asserts its own set of questions. And that's not a spoiler.
King fought for better pay for women's professional tennis players ... Battle of the Sexes captures that zeitgeist. Just not in the way you expect.
40 years after the film's release, the only thing that's aged is me.
movie_title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)

movie_review_blurb: It has been a long time since a Stephen King adaptation could be called fun.
Detroit is an important and thoughtful history reminder. And in these times of Black Lives Matter and videos of police killing black men, it feels sadly prescient.

It's not often that a summer film is hampered by running short on time, but The Dark Tower rushes through like it's the last two hours on a Friday before a weeklong vacation and there's still packing to be done.

It's a harrowing, moving, and minimalist epic that haunts the soul while satisfying those fleshy urges with spectacular and unforgettable action alongside an unrelenting hum of anxious intensity. It's about people, not war.
War for the Planet of the Apes triumphantly caps this Apes trilogy. Equally remarkable, it leaves you wanting more.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Spider-Man: Homecoming is light, quick and never too serious, bounding with a playful sense of humor lacking in the increasingly angsty and no longer fun franchise.
The fun and charm of the familiar humor and feel-good moments still haven't worn off, though the end is surely in sight.
The action, as with most everything about The Mummy, is fine, rarely impressive, and never inventive.
After her long struggle to the big screen, Wonder Woman makes the most of her first solo effort.
Indeed, the only appreciation for Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales is a damning one: It somehow manages to be worse than the already low expectations set for it.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Snatched director Jonathan Levine (50/​50) either has little faith in screenwriter Katie Dippold's (2016's Ghostbusters) final act in the script, or created a mess of his own, as the story bounces between sequences with no enthusiasm for coherence.
In a drama and thriller that struggles to be anything more than passable, the absence of such gallows humor is sorely needed and missed. As are the Coens.
A sleek sports car of a summer blockbuster junked up by too many aftermarket accessories.

The Last Jedi is the best Star Wars film since 1980's The Empire Strikes Back because it's so much more than stars and wars. It's those stories, joys, and pains of the heroes, villains, and nobodies who lived it.

Money Monster's timing couldn't be much better. But this Wall Street satire could be and should be, with a promising setup betrayed by absurd twists and a conventional resolution so tidy it wreaks of studio meddling.
Even with its few missteps, X-Men: First Class represents a major step in the right direction for the series.
While not as end-to-end funny and clever as the original Despicable Me, Minions does serve as a nice holdover for more Gru with the already announced Despicable Me 3 in 2017.

While wiping out sequels 3 and 4... makes sense for the studio, film series, and its fans, tampering with the roots of the franchise, 1984's The Terminator and 1991's Terminator 2: Judgment Day, is a colossal miscalculation.
Not that Ted 2's punchlines still aren't funny much of the time, but the familiarity of the characters and their actions lowers the laugh factor by about half of what it originally was.

Inside Out's story is utterly unique. It's also a wondrous and magnificent film that celebrates the human experience and all of the smiles, warmth, laughter, tears, frustration, and despair that comes with it.
In this era of the dumb, lumbering summer blockbuster, Jurassic World is anything but a dinosaur.
Fieg isn't so much interested in spoofing super agents as he is mocking the stereotypes that come with it, particularly as that relates to gender and appearance.
There's really nothing in San Andreas we haven't seen before in other disaster films, with the exception of The Rock as the hero.
It's surprisingly hollow entertainment -- a film with noble intentions and grand aspirations that drags us along for a two-hour adventure that we never really care about.
There's never been anything like Mad Max: Fury Road, a film as revolutionary as it is entertaining.

The best compliment to be paid Hot Pursuit, in fact, is that the action-comedy wisely clocks in at just under 90 minutes, thus sparing audiences from more failed laughs and ineptitude, and the film's stars further embarrassment at being part of it.
The D Train is proof that awkward and creepy can be funny and likable, even with main characters who aren't.
A sequel as epic as it is overly ambitious and as sprawling as it is restless.
There's a lot happening in Ex Machina and we're never entirely sure what will happen next.
Ant-Man is fun but surprisingly conventional.

Furious 7 is undeniably satisfying and mostly fun. More than pure escapism, however, it also serves as a fitting tribute to its costar Paul Walker, who was killed in a car accident while on a break during filming.
Comedy needn't be PC. But being offensive isn't funny, either.
Insurgent is better than its predecessor and really, for a mildly entertaining action film, Insurgent could have been much worse.
Star Trek director J.J. Abrams proves to be just what the franchise needed a jolt of life from someone unencumbered by the baggage that comes with more than 40 years of lore and legacy.
If it weren't for the imaginative and eye-catching costumes by three-time Oscar winner Sandy Powell, Cinderella could be mistaken for a typical Disney Channel special.

Blomkamp stages engaging action sequences, but his film's tone switches from violence to campy to drama with dizzying frequency, as the story bounces from interesting, to predictable, to highly illogical, to just plain dumb.
With Smith back in his element plus the timeless appeal of a well-executed con story, Focus is undeniably fun.
It's a true and simple story unencumbered by side plots, and with every character -- major and minor -- fitting neatly into place.
Jupiter Ascending suffers from stupid. And deja vu. And a lack of discipline. And filmmakers who either can't make another good film -- let alone a great one -- or don't care to.
It's these moments that elevate American Sniper beyond a jingoistic refrain and into a relevant reminder of the sacrifice of war, even to its biggest heroes.
Selma is one of so many well-meaning historical dramas that fall prey to their overpowering stories. Gravitas abounds in every scene.
It's a film you can't stop watching. Until it ends. And even then you wish Boyhood was only the beginning of an extraordinary work in progress.
Angelina Jolie directs her second film with a surprising amount of confidence considering the scale of this war epic. But there are some novice mistakes.

Despite its plot's mechanical issues, The Nice Guys has all the makings of must-see DVD and Blu-ray, when its long-winded story can be offset by the ability to rewind and rewatch some truly funny moments.

Marshall has always had grand visions for his musicals onscreen, and he fleshes out the stage production of Into the Woods to extraordinary lengths, particularly in the production design (Dennis Gassner and Anna Pinnock) of the titular mysterious woods.
It's not pixel-pushing artistry in DreamWorks Animation's latest that will win over audiences, rather it's the film's timeless traits of sincerity and originality.
What drives the film is also what defines it as slightly better than most of its ilk, Jake Gyllenhaal.
Binder's script is a big-screen soap opera, which he attempts to offset with often out-of-place humor.
Some trips, like the new and not-so-improved Vacation, aren't worth revisiting.
The computer-made anamorphic animals -- Mowgli's wolf family and best friends bear and black panther, and his enemies the tiger and python -- are astonishingly fur-and-blood real.

The fifth installment in this franchise that keeps getting better is the best one yet, with a compelling plot, a Bond-esque super villain to keep your interest, and the intense action set pieces that Cruise does better than anyone.
The latest Marvel movie to build on the series' past while setting up its future, Captain America: Civil War is also the most ambitious film yet in that comic-book cinematic universe.
The ride is worth it for the uniformly terrific cast and for the aspirations of this throwback science-fiction vehicle, when brainy stories drove films rather than Star Wars-style eye candy.
A dark and moody comic-book film with noble ambitions but the fizz of a week-old glass of Coke.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Like most of the Coens' work, Hail, Caesar! has multiple levels to nod at and appreciate -- like the cigarette metaphor and the loving recreations of film genres: westerns, musicals, biblical epics.
Room is a most extraordinary achievement, finding light and love and hope in even the darkest of places.
A maddening meditation on vengeance: its high toll and the fleeting satisfaction it yields.
The Hateful Eight isn't a masterpiece and it's not Tarantino's best film, but it is his most complete effort in a long while. It's sloppy but riveting.
The cast is uniformly excellent... and The Big Short's rapid pace and momentum keep the film and its subject matter light and breezy, even as the heavy story speeds to disaster.
With the mounting evidence and increasing concern of the potential hazards of playing football, the National Football League has much to be concerned about. The new film Concussion isn't one of them.
The dialogue is punchy. The actors are engaged and human. The action sequences and special effects complement the plot rather than make up for it. The story rockets along.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Good Dinosaur, as it turns out, is merely adequate by the great standards of Pixar's family-friendly library: a stunning piece of artistry let down by a familiar story of a journey against all odds that fails to inspire and connect.

Spotlight might very well be the best film of the year. It's an intense and well-crafted ensemble drama that has and will receive near-universal accolades and repeated mentions as an Oscar frontrunner.
[Mockingjay delivers] an ultimately satisfying conclusion to the adventures of Katniss Everdeen. But as with most heroic tales, the best stories are not necessarily the longest.

While the "Merc with a Mouth" is a novel and undeniably funny superhero film, like a relentless case of the runs, Deadpool's torrent of inappropriate/​smart-aleck jokes and pop culture references can be exhausting.
After soaring to new heights in Skyfall, James Bond comes crashing down in the hotly anticipated Spectre.
Only a blockhead won't enjoy Charlie Brown and Co.'s return to the big screen.
While The Visit doesn't always work, there's enough success in Shyamalan's bare-bones horror-dark comedy do-over to suggest he's learned hard lessons and taken these failures to heart.
Filmed by cinematographer Salvatore Totino on the foothills of Everest as well as the Italian Alps, Everest drops us in the white beauty of the mountain and its myriad dangers at every step.
Depp's performance, chilling as it may be, is rather basic, though formidable, with variable degrees of Bulger's anger and rage.
The Intern is a throwback comedy to the filmmaker's early work such as Baby Boom and Father of the Bride: sweet, uncomplicated, and overly earnest.
The Transporter made Jason Statham a star. The Transporter Refueled won't do the same for fellow Brit Ed Skrein.
Pointless, joyless, and insulting to Barrie and his beloved fairy tale.

This Bond for the 21st century is scarred physically and emotionally from his almost super-human efforts for country and Queen, and you believe there are layers to his psyche that will continue to define him in the movies to come.
This no-nonsense science-fiction thriller is proof that book smart and entertaining are not mutually exclusive traits on the big screen.
Rare are the filmmakers such as Spielberg with the knowledge and capability to wed thought-provoking artistry with thoroughly entertaining cinematic appeal.
Fans of The Man From U.N.C.L.E. would be advised to skip this revival. Some TV relics were not made for the big screen.
As a documentary it's lacking, but as a purely inspiring and motivational speech it's invigorating and hopeful.
Fantastic Four is a mess. It's poorly paced -- plodding through most of the story only to zip through its big finish. None of the characters is interesting, let alone fantastic.

This lickety-split action comedy is distinguished by the wry, character-conscious direction of Martin Brest, who coaxes a silver-bullet performance from star Eddie Murphy that's practically criminal in its accuracy.
The havoc makes for a genuine steel metal trap of a movie that may very well be the best picture of its kind since The Road Warrior.
A deeply dispiriting movie, not just because it is grindingly bad but because Jane Fonda actually chose this for her comeback after a 15-year absence from the screen.
So much is unspoken and this slice of reality is so thin and slow as to make the film downright unsatisfying.

What Lynch strenuously avoids is any examination of who these two individuals are, how the passage of time affects them and what could possibly draw them back together given that neither one of them is a walk in the park.
The Game of Their Lives has a great sports story to tell, yet the filmmakers fumble it away.
Characters are rote and unremarkable, plot devices predictable and the camera cheats by sticking close to actors so a viewer cannot see from where the next shock will come.
Ice Cube keeps the action-movie franchise alive with a pleasing one-two punch of humor and burly physicality.
It's hard to say what Kim is driving at here.
Kingdom fulfills the requirements of grand-scale moviemaking while serving as a timely reminder that in the conflict between Christianity and Islam it was the Christians who picked the first fight.
The final episode of George Lucas' cinematic epic Star Wars ends the six-movie series on such a high note that one feels like yelling out, 'Rewind!'
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This is definitely a film where style triumphs over substance.
Shorter and punchier but nearly as hokey as the original.
A disappointing turn-off. The film deliberately works against most cinematic expectations.
Alas, the film relies too much on its shocks and fails to make the supernatural element at all convincing.
Quite a roller-coaster ride through the funhouse of Tough-Guy P.I. Fiction.
Skips over such cinematic non-essentials as character, motivation, backstory and narrative.
In unraveling a nearly forgotten secret in the life of a self-satisfied and smug French intellectual, Haneke probes deeply into issues involving guilt, communication and willful amnesia.
Kornel Mundruczo's Johanna is a astonishing coup de cinema.
Match Point is a story designed more to prove a philosophical point than to examine a social milieu or a particular cast of characters.
Broken Flowers could break Jarmusch out of the art house, but admirers may question the film's overly conventional approach.
Down in the Valley might have come off as conceptually sound on paper, but onscreen the whole idea falls apart.
What it is is a big summer action movie that would have been hot stuff about 30 years ago but looks tired and worn today despite a perky, attractive cast that refuses to wilt in the desert sun.

American filmmakers, novelists and artists of all stripes have dealt the perplexing issue of race relations for decades, even centuries. Nothing von Trier presents here, whether real or imagined, is fresh or new.
A dry, spare, odd and oddly satisfying drama about a modern-day lonesome cowboy, lost in a desert of his own making, who seeks salvation by searching out those he left behind.
A meticulous, nuanced, hugely powerful drama about an already splintered family thrown into chaos by a seeming tragedy.
The schematic design behind her plot and characters is so rigidly predetermined that nothing feels lifelike despite the naturalistic acting and filmmaking.
movie_title: The Ballad of Jack and Rose (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Is this what passes for family entertainment these days?
Thrillers don't get much smarter.
A peculiar and at times even sour tale about the tyranny of Christmas.

Under Eastwood's painstakingly stripped-down direction -- his filmmaking has become the cinematic equivalent of Hemingway's spare though precise prose -- the story emerges as that rarest of birds, an uplifting tragedy.
Energy and comedy are in large supply in writer-director Mitsuo Yanagimachi's Who's Camus Anyway?, yet another riff on the levels of reality that occur when a cast and crew make a movie.

Instead of audiences feeling a part of a nifty conspiracy to pull off an audacious robbery, viewers are left largely in the dark as Soderbergh & Co. conspire to trick them with sleight of hand and misdirection.
No doubt about it, Brooks is solidly in charge of this feel-good fairy tale as he gets terrific performances from everyone including two super-talented child actors.
A pale -- dare we say ghostly? -- copy of the original coup de theatre directed by Harold Prince.
Demonstrates what happens when you take a clever idea and run it into the ground.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Weitz provides juicy roles for Dennis Quaid, Topher Grace and Scarlett Johansson and manages to edge into areas in our society mostly unexplored in mainstream American films.
A mysterious love story takes chances and mostly succeeds.

Even though logic takes a holiday in White Noise, Geoffrey Sax, a British television director making his theatrical debut, lavishes enough craft on the paranormal thriller to send more than a few chills down the spine.
While the film sometimes plays like an hour TV medical drama padded to reach feature length, Sawant achieves touching, naturalistic performances from a fine ensemble cast.
As an introduction to this mind-spinning festival, the film gets the job done.
movie_title: Short Cut to Nirvana: Kumbh Mela (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The results don't come close to duplicating Noonan's charming and gentle barnyard fable [Babe].
The salient point here is that Deep Throat can be seen as one of the first battles of the culture wars that still divide this nation.
A riveting account of the psychological journey of a man once molested by his priest.
A mesmerizing portrait of a man who staged a 13-year dance with death.
Bring[s] viewers into the world of the severely handicapped without any high-mindedness or sentimentality.
Too broadly played to achieve its dark satirical aspirations and too downright silly to pass for a serious commentary on contemporary society.
Be Cool is not really cool as Get Shorty was, but it's entertaining, a frivolous cocktail rather than a vintage wine.
Jokes never build, stagings are clumsy, and the whole thing feels as if it were slapped together in haste.
Dazzling landscapes feature Rube Goldberg contraptions and visual gags that turn our world on its head.

This first feature by multimedia performance artist Miranda July is a hit-and-miss affair. It has moments of unexpected, offbeat comedy, but most of the time neither the characters nor the situations engage the viewer.
movie_title: Me and You and Everyone We Know (2005)

movie_review_blurb: While nearly every shock comes at predictable moments, there is genuine ingenuity behind many, and the movie is surprisingly fresh for one made by a guy on his third go-round with the same material.
The major problem is that after about 10 minutes, you've seen all the movie's tricks. The look is hypnotic yet never changes.
Even a sharp pace can't disguise the lack of dramatic momentum.
The actors tune in to their individual characters perfectly, but this is Allen's show.
Jones displays a firm hand at the helm -- you sense that he is well within his comfort zone in this environment -- and performances including his own are lively and convincing.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A gloriously lead-footed excursion into time travel with all the accoutrements of 1950s science fiction: an absurd plot, cliched characters, corny effects and a race against time to save mankind.
For Christopher Nolan to turn Batman Begins into such a smart, gritty, brooding, visceral experience is astonishing.
The more the film stresses and strains to be funny, the unfunnier it gets.
Oh my, is the music sweet and hot and, yes, funky.
An oddly satisfying mesh of an international action-adventure with an extremely dark satire about the global arms trade.

A wondrous flight of fancy, a stop-motion-animated treat brimming with imaginative characters, evocative sets, sly humor, inspired songs and a genuine whimsy that seldom finds its way into today's movies.
Who knew Samuel L. Jackson and Eugene Levy would make such a dynamic comic duo?

Like Bandit Queen and Maya, Water bravely delves into outmoded social traditions of India, thus roiling the waters of religious fundamentalism, which might mean that Deepa Mehta's film will never get past the censors in that country.
This DreamWorks release recycles just about every sentimental ploy and cliche from a raft of horse racing movies.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: For all its literary references, the thing certainly looks like a shallow though slick French melodrama.
The spark that an original point of view might bring to the oft-told tale is missing.
The movie is amusing and clever but only skin deep.
An exceptional movie that digs deeply into an artist at the height of his creativity.
A cold, cerebral exercise in existential mannerisms that one watches with increasing dismay.
Occasionally inspired but much more often didactic.
Results less in an intense psychological portrait of a family crisis than a baffling puzzle where cause and effect are never firmly established.

Love stories don't get any more unusual than this.

Two of the funniest cartoon characters ever make a delightful feature debut.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A mesmerizing Australian western that occurs in a raw and brutal land.
No one will accuse Grant of wallowing in nostalgia.

Jodie Foster might draw audiences on opening weekend, and who knows what the spectacular drama this week at LAX may do for an in-flight melodrama. But audiences might react adversely to such transparent manipulation for so weak a payoff.
When under water, the action-adventure Into the Blue has genuine thrills. Above water or on dry land, this is one dead fish.
The storytelling is so ham-fisted as to induce titters.
Crass yet colorful exploitation of the sad, strange life of an English beauty-turned-bounty hunter.
The film never realizes its dramatic potential, choosing to take predictable story paths with obvious characters.
Save for one sentimental subplot, the writer-director clearly doesn't care for these people very much. Nor is there much reason for viewers to care, either.
The focus is steady and intense, the theme clearly delineated and subtexts well thought out.
As feeble as a teen comedy can get.
An attractively packaged political thriller that mixes Wall Street chicanery with mean streets skullduggery.

[It] will amuse kids, but this Bug is low on comic gas.
A lively, often hilarious yet profoundly moving experience.
The stoic, resolute heroes and heroines of Luc Jacquet's March of the Penguins captivate the viewer.
Has a jumpy and moody vitality.

A winning, charming, very droll children's film for the whole family.

For a one-joke movie, Fido does a fine job exploring every possible permutation of that joke.

One question hovers over the carnage, though: Whom the hell are we supposed to root for? The closest the movie comes to sympathetic assassins are its hit ladies, yet the payoff to their subplot is the weakest of the bunch.
Tragic tale of child abuse fails to make any sense of the crime.
The latter may be the better option in this lame comedy.
movie_title: Sing Now or Forever Hold Your Peace (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Despite an outlandish premise, Next suffers from being too conventional.
The drama never comes together in a smart, meaningful way; indeed, most revelations border on the banal.
It's dull, dull, dull.
Much of the bite and a good deal of the wit of the first two films are missing here.
This cool and cerebral film could be a hot arthouse item.
The cinematic equivalent of an inedible mess where ingredients war with one another and no one has paid any attention to the poor fellow who must consume the meal.
A movie falls into the clutches of long, solemn stares into space, meaningful drags on cigarettes, cryptic dialogue revealing little and a tiny drama that feels old, tired and empty of real purpose.
The result is mixed.
A fascinating film.
This is the movie where Michael Moore gets a few Michael Moore haters off his back.
Hardly anyone can make good old American suspense thriller like the French.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Van Sant has composed an emotional mosaic that brings you inside Alex.
The filmmakers were right to believe that a live-action version of this story would have failed to achieve the universality Persepolis does.
Other than its black-and-white photography, this is a nearly unwatchable movie.
movie_title: The Man From London (A Londoni Férfi) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Emotionally complex tale of a woman's confrontation with the worst of fates.
[Recaptures] much of the spirit of the original film.
Overdesigned characters and situations stretch plausibility at every turn.
James Gray again tackles his familiar family themes again within an overly familiar cops-gangsters genre.
Surfing penguins make for radical fun for young children.
Its imagination is limited. The backstory is shallow and pat. Its characters are mostly one-note. And everything goes on much too long at 133 minutes.
This topsy-turvy funeral produces a number of smiles, giggles, pleasant guffaws and several solid, sustained laughs. Not a bad batting average as comedies go.
Less about finger-pointing than a plea for India to confront its past.

A viewer takes in this circus of bizarre characters and absurdist images ... with an appreciation for the inventiveness, but a wish that one might be more involved or at least entertained by the stylistic workout.
movie_title: The Saddest Music in the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A fine and engaging study of two personalities, seemingly in sharp contrast, that prove awfully alike in the end.
movie_title: Mio Fratello è Figlio Unico (My Brother Is an Only Child) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Feels tired, derivative and lackluster.
Shallow entertainment where you have no rooting interest in the outcome.
An extraordinary film, operating simultaneously at visceral, psychological and spiritual levels as it takes us on a voyage into space with the fate of mankind at stake.
This is a film from the heart, from a firsthand familiarity that yields conflicted emotions over the gap between an ideal and its realization.
A disappointing and manipulative look at one family's loss in the Iraq war.
The veneer of stylistic hyperactivity can't conceal the starkly banal dialogue and a roster of performances that seem, under the circumstances, hardly directed at all.
A train wreck of a movie.
movie_title: Summer Rain (El camino de los ingleses) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Teeth is a solid first effort that makes you extremely curious about the filmmaker's next project.
Robinson Devor and his accomplished crew expand our concept of the documentary film.
Azur & Asmar blends a highly sophisticated art design with a tale of childlike wonder and innocence that speaks to open-minded humans of any age.
movie_title: Azur et Asmar (Azur and Asmar: The Princes' Quest) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There is a fine idea for a romantic comedy in Jake Paltrow's The Good Night but the writer-director, in his debut feature, never develops it much beyond the idea stage.
The blues music in Moan is superfine, but my oh my, what to make of the ripe Southern cliches and this absurd story.
The film's most effective moments are its quietest.

A superb and devastating piece of cinema that with justification can be compared favorably to Gillo Pontocorvo's classic The Battle of Algiers in its dispassionate yet sweeping journalistic inquiry into cataclysmic social and political events.
Breach, based on actual CIA and FBI history, meticulously scrutinizes the real world of spies to draw scary portraits of deadly, unpleasant people.
Frank Miller's graphic novel about an ancient Greek battle comes to vivid life.
There is a glimmer of comedy, but it's quickly swamped in overextended gags and broad caricatures.
The greatest failure of the film is its inability to enter into the lives of the Rwandans, Tutsi and Hutu alike.
As a director, Rock has little visual flair, so the film looks clumsy and stilted.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The claustrophobic and poorly executed Caffeine is either a play in search of a movie or a movie in search of a play but, either way, it's searching for the wrong thing.
Yes, Terrence Howard delivers another solid lead performance and competition swimming is a new arena for such films. Nonetheless, Pride is just plain trite.
Ultimately, the movie seems driven more by the need to keep a toy line and franchise alive than any creative inspiration.
Definitely a cut above the average action thriller.
A moralistic black drama that makes its points with a heavy hand and unconvincing story developments.
A cartoon that is busy and frenetic yet has little actually going on.
Religious horror with multiple shocks but little substance.
Like all double bills of the sick, shocking, perverse exploitation movies of old, one is better than the other.
Can anyone dislike a Firehouse Dog? Even one as formulaic and hackneyed as this one?
A strange and compelling Kafka-esque account of an American artist caught up in Bush's war on terror.
The cartoon is amiable enough and has bright comic moments.
The political maneuverings are of some historical interest, but modern relevancy is hard to find.
...mesmerizing but often empty...
movie_title: Ye yan (Legend of the Black Scorpion) (The Banquet) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: No matter how badly the movie cons you, you must admit that the film is stylish as hell with sharp dialogue, a tongue-in-cheek plot and visual and editing razzle-dazzle.
Come Early Morning is a simple story, yet told with such conviction, delicacy and instinct for truth that is carries keen emotional power.
Wristcutters: A Love Story is somewhat original and amusing. But only somewhat.
Right at Your Door takes a viewer on a harrowing, distinctly uncomfortable journey.
Al Gore brings his campaign to reverse global warming to the big screen in this vivid and vital activist movie.
A surprisingly light-hearted though nonetheless devilish spirit.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A muted psychological mystery.
What will make many viewers uneasy, though, is Dick's central quest.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Both dutifully formulaic and brazen in its willingness exploit in-jeopardy elements just short of the horror-film threshold, such barriers might prevent audiences from savoring an otherwise old-fashioned thriller.
Garrison Keillor, impresario, creator and host of one of radio's longest running programs -- 31 years and counting -- and director Robert Altman are a match made in heaven.
Stars Matthew McConaughey and Sarah Jessica Parker put as much energy, winning smiles and comic business into their roles as possible, but it's a no-go from the start.

A pitch-perfect ensemble comedy that burrows deep into the mind-set of white, upper middle-class Angelenos, anxious to strike the right balance among career, family, love life and money but never quite pulling it off.
She's the Man fails to exploit the myriad comedic possibilities, settling instead for broad, unconvincing slapstick aimed at 12-year-olds and gags Shakespeare would have rejected as ancient.
This is the mother lode all action/suspense directors search for and Lee, who usually doesn't work in that genre, has hit it.
Debuting director William Brent Bell, who wrote the script with producer Matthew Peterman, keeps the pace brisk and the pot bubbling.
The movie strands you in two miserable flats with these cliche-ridden characters and a static love story that is as predictable as it is pedestrian.
A film guilty off moral stupidity and misguided hero worship.
The Devil and Daniel Johnston is undoubtedly the best movie anyone could have made about this unwitting practitioner of 'outsider' art.
Several good ideas for a movie rumble around inside ATL, but they never coalesce.
The only real intrigue comes in the film's risky flirtation with high camp.
The first word of the movie's title stands for Pretty Hot and Thick. The second word is never spelled out, but it could mean Good Intentions Ruined by Lousy Zingers.
The humor emphasizes quantity over quality, but the batting average isn't too bad. And where else can you witness Leslie Nielsen do a nude scene?
What we have here is a solid documentary covering one of the icons of modern music.
The singing and songs -- written by Nona Hendryx, former member of R&B group LaBelle -- get better as the movie wears on and as the plot dictates. But the same can't be said for the script.
The filmmakers essentially box themselves into an almost existential situation where nothing happens other than the unraveling of intimate relationships under insurmountable stress.
The performances are terrific: None is showy or actorish but earnest, truthful jobs laying bare souls in anguish.
At its core is a pair of lovers no contemporary audience could possibly care for, and at the periphery are characters that threaten to become interesting but never quite do.

This Jerry Bruckheimer production, directed by commercial director James Gartner in a solid feature debut, should please male fans as well as those who don't mind a dose of social commentary with their sports heroics.
The movie demands that its viewers put the fragmented images and information together like an intellectual jigsaw puzzle, but it never gives those viewers a good reason to do so.
The movie blows all over the place, too, as its meandering plotlines do flesh out this portrait of a success who believes himself a failure, but never expands any further.
What have they done to the Zorro movie series? It's turned into Spy Kids!

The filmmakers clearly wanted to avoid the politics surrounding the first Gulf War even as they pay tribute to the Marines, the jarheads, who went to Saudi Arabia to fight. But the result is a movie rife with ambivalence.
A riveting exploration of good and evil where the line between the two is unclear.
A sweet-natured holiday comedy that derives no small amount of specialness and energy from the fact that the movie offers a glimpse of contemporary American Indian life.
For all its biographical truth, Get Rich's journey into a ghetto of hustlers, gangstas and mindless violence is all too familiar.
A pleasingly whimsical and slyly mischievous road movie.
The best one yet.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Alvart does put the viewer through a gripping experience with a final twist few will see coming.
A discouragingly senseless 48-hour journey into the world of teenage hooliganism and criminality in the company of a pair of amoral losers.
Characters switch personalities in midscene, forget slights, ignore the obvious, abandon goals and betray family and friends just because the script demands it. No motivation required.
What Syriana feels like is a television miniseries condensed into two hours.

The details are what matters, and thanks to a cast of all-star British elders and a mischievous sense of humor, the filmmakers bring those details to vivid life.
What is lightly sketched in the novel, where much is left to the imagination, blossoms into full-blown, richly detailed life in the movie.

movie_review_blurb: This is spectacle filmmaking at its best, where a director is in tune with the story's underlying emotions and his own boyish love for adventure fantasy.
A thought-provoking, highly charged inquiry into the political, moral and historical ramifications of terrorism and the effort to combat this scourge.
The Producers is simply a missed opportunity.
An evocative yet slow-moving exploration of the Pocahontas myth.

movie_review_blurb: A wry exercise in acute observation and emotional distancing, Noah Baumbach's The Squid and the Whale represents what's best in autobiographical filmmaking.

The richness of the characters and themes in Nearing Grace inspire director Rick Rosenthal and his cast to create a film with terrific emotional energy and larkish humor.
You'll never complain about those in-flight meals again. Things could be so much worse.
Odd but entertaining musical with a distinctly OutKast overcast.
Think of it more as a milder, more palatable version of Fear Factor.
A persuasive and enjoyable sports film for male audiences.

... a good 30 minutes could come out of this 124 minute film to its benefit ...

A second look at Truman Capote's journey to write In Cold Bloo that against all odds is as good as Capote.

movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A few new insights into Nixon administration criminality amid old news and favorite John Lennon tunes.

Although slick and clever, the ethnics of this fake docu about an imagined assassination of Bush are woeful.

A minor but amusing Woody Allen enhanced by his newfound love for London life.

Edward Burns' best riff yet on guys trying to sort out their feelings about women.

Closely observed story of the mental and family pressures that can lead someone to accept an exorcism.

It probably sounded like a swell idea in the pitch meeting.
Chirpy, silly fun for youngsters thanks to solid character animation.
An intelligent, lucid and affectionate sketch of one of the world's leading architects.

A tense and provocative thriller revolving around a past tragedy.

If you're going to spend 89 minutes with a wild animal, something about that character should engage or intrigue you. Nothing here does.

The movie slices through the cobwebs of history to seek the heart of the young Austrian princess whom 18th century political diplomacy thrust into a maelstrom of court intrigue and poisoned personal relationships without even asking if she minded.

A happy convergence of silly and smart gives Adam Sandler one of his best comic vehicles yet.

This production is a vast, expensive, sprawling affair that never feels out of control thanks to Verbinski's assured direction.

Sadistically proficient at the old 'turn of the screw.'
Like a precious and finely cut diamond, magnificent to behold in its sparkling beauty yet in reality it's one tough rock.

One of the most elegantly suspenseful ghost stories in years.

In baseball slang, a 'can of corn' is a high, lazy fly ball to the outfield. The baseball movie Summer Catch is the cinematic equivalent of that can of corn.

The movie is fun, with plenty of intrigue and suspense that will have audiences clutching at their arm rests.
Hokum is best served straight, not as a New Age cocktail with too many ingredients.
As with any good cartoon, the animators mix visual stunts with rimshot-worthy one-liners and verbal gags.

All four films feature terrific stunts. But Fast & Furious is the first film since the original to be smart about how far to stretch logic without sacrificing the desired macho swagger and revved-up emotions.
There is nothing we haven't seen here before in terms of chases, intrigue and betrayals, so for all its A-list cast and production values, the film comes off as routine.
Despite occasional misfires, this Zac Efron comedy earns its laughs and delivers its life lessons.
A must-see for fans of the original stage musical A Chorus Line.
Director Dito Montiel's jump from indie to studio film is mostly a successful one.
This film version takes a somewhat romanticized view of both journalism and skid row yet is nevertheless a compassionate and compelling look at mental illness.
Until Beyonce and Ali Larter duke it out at the climax, this is one dull film.
As written by Jon Lucas and Scott Moore and directed by Mark Waters, the movie clumps through one witless if not wince-evoking sequence after another without the relief of laughter.

The effect is impressionistic and provocative, with the emphasis falling differently on scenes because of our knowledge or lack thereof. It also serves to view the "girlfriend experience" as a kind of performance art.
A keen disappointment as action and effects take over from a poorly conceived story.
A lovingly crafted 3-D animated sci-fi film that cleverly reverses War of the Worlds.
Seems more like a dance studio's infomercial than a romantic comedy.
Returning to his origins as a theater and film student, Francis Ford Coppola deploys striking visuals, music, dance and classic drama to spin a tale of familial conflicts and brothers reunited.

It's a low-wattage film about a high-wattage event. Which is somewhat disappointing, though you do get a thoughtful, playful, often amusing film about what happened backstage at one of the '60s' great happenings.

Peter's lightning-fast script and Loncraine's steady direction steer this road picture to the sunny side of the street.
American democracy has rarely looked worse than in this unfunny and undramatic comedy-drama.
A broad action comedy that manages to mix subtlety with satire.
Exhausted is how many audiences members will feel after squirming through such a repetitive, one-joke comedy.
Brick Lane is beautifully acted and written (by Abi Morgan and Laura Jones) so its themes are touched upon glancingly rather than with full force.
All in all, it's a grand package of hearty acting, design and action with the only caveat being that unlike the first film this Elizabeth can no longer surprise us with its modern twists.
Signals another promising discovery in a film industry that is definitely coming into its own golden age.
Teeters between film genres, not ever quite making up its mind what it strives for.

The film gets caught somewhere between domestic weep-athon and revenge melodrama.
Actor-turned-filmmaker Tom McCarthy demonstrates that the critical acclaim for The Station Agent in 2003 was no fluke.

The viewer never glimpses anything more than the shadow of a clever movie.
There is less of a story here than a series of gag situations...
Farrelly brothers films are looking better and better, but aren't nearly as funny as their grungy early films that hit with the stealth and vigor of guerrilla commandos.
December Boys bathes in the summer sun and sea breezes even as it exudes the energy of youth and promise.
Poor writing, an indifferent production and sincere but often wooden acting make Season one big strikeout.

While not a perfect comedy, Dan is certainly a crowd-pleasing, cleverly engineered and well-executed divertissement that should put grins on the faces of movie fans of many ages and execs at Disney and Focus Features.
The movie is smooth and smart enough to attract a significant audience beyond the considerable fan base of its stars, Denzel Washington and Russell Crowe.
Unfortunately, bees just aren't that funny.
With Santa Claus movies like Fred Claus, who needs Ebenezer Scrooge?
For audiences unaccustomed to the format, the film runs too long -- though it is short by Bollywood standards -- and is repetitive, sentimental and cliched.
Animated acting and the sheer chaos of this squabbling family give the film a comic buoyancy.
A minimalist and unimaginative horror thriller.
An often charming urban fantasy that teeters perilously on the brink of preciousness but never quite topples over.
It may raise the eyebrows of English Lit professors but will quicken the pulse of everyone else.
The formula is not that far removed from James Bond except there's a hole at its center. Agent 47, played by a virtually expressionless Timothy Olyphant, is a soulless, emotionally dead protagonist.
Jenkins walks this dramatic tightrope with breathtaking ease. The humor is never forced but always springs from the characters and situations naturally.
An unstable mix of a tearjerker, junkie-recovery story and odd-couple pairing.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: While it makes no bones about where its sympathies lie, these fictional stories show a genuine fascination with the role politics plays on both sides of such confrontations and how things can spin out of control with no single person to blame.
The film does feature a host of interesting characters and, as always with Sayles, the dialogue has more than a few zingers.
Few movies ever have gone to such a length to tell so slight -- and, worse, unengaging -- a story.

Stunt work is among the best ever committed to film. There is something very satisfying in this digital age about an action film where CGI doesn't overwhelm, actors are in great physical shape and huge spaces are actual sets.
Yelchin delivers one of those performances that pop eyes.
Bay and an army of visual designers have successfully re-imagined a photorealistic world in which these Titans can believably clash.

There is the fact that this [movie] is a watershed of backstory, revelations and plot clarifications before heading into the two remaining chapters. So while Phoenix is a necessary film, it's quite possibly the least enjoyable of the lot so far.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Comedies don't get much lamer than License to Wed. Working from a flawed premise with characters lacking credibility and plot turns more moronic than funny, the movie flatlines in about five minutes.
A small miracle -- a smart popcorn movie.
One longs for something like Paul Rudnick's script for In & Out, which was very funny yet delved into the trauma of coming out and the perplexing issue of homophobia in society.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A culinary misfire whose comic ingredients fail to coalesce.
A clever and spirited big-screen version of its better-known small-screen cousin.
It's a 114-minute chase film, dashing through streets and rooftops of any number of international urban sprawls with Matt Damon's redoubtable Jason Bourne hot on the trail of -- himself.
Good one-liners and dog tricks, but no best in show.
A modern sensibility afflicts much of the screenplay, with characters expressing thoughts and opinions for our ears rather than acting as people of that era.
An effective action thriller that only hints at the psychological complexity the director might have wanted.
Satire that sputters when its characters refuse to grow out of caricature.
It should scare up a bit of boxoffice as it does hearken back to the day when horror meant the imagination gone wild rather than severed body parts. Otherwise, the film is all too pointless.
As with the Bourne films, Gilroy has a knack for creating strong characters and situations that resonate with tension.

Unfortunately, Shepard's approach takes the movie into Jason Bourne territory and away from the black comedy he seemingly wants to make, making the film fall between the cracks in terms of boxoffice appeal.
... gets smothered in pointlessly long takes, repetitive scenes, grim Western landscapes and mumbled, heavily accented dialogue.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: India is definitely Bollywood, ashamed of neither sentimentality nor predictability. Yet its sharp-eyed view of Indian society makes for a world of difference from old-style, sugar-coated Bollywood films.
Mordant, melancholic but impressive debut for director Affleck.
So whatever the shortcomings of this literary construct, it remains a joy to experience a movie so in love with good writing.
Documentaries these days tend toward doom and gloom, so Moon is a welcome relief.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Deep Water is a stunning documentary that not only beautifully elucidates a nearly forgotten incident but touches on crucial themes involving isolation, sanity, self-worth, impossible dreams, the nature of heroism and limits of human endurance.

Bollywood fans will dismiss the mishmash as the work of an American director 'slumming' in a genre outside his own culture, and Western audiences unfamiliar with Hindi-language masala movies will find the whole thing puzzling.
Actually, all performances are sharp, which shows what can happen when actors get to play characters and deliver lines that bristle with originality.
Charlie Wilson's War is political drama played as comedy and true life as satire. Sorkin's script comes loaded with computable comic lines.
The blend of live action, CG and visual effects is superb, making what must have been a technological nightmare look easy as pie.
Genuinely new and different.
movie_title: Prince of Himalayas (Xi ma la ya wang zi) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The show couldn't have fallen into better hands.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Add watching The Promotion to the Geneva Conventions' list of humanitarian abuses.
Deft and fascinating handling of a moral quandary in a Nazi concentration camp.
A flimsy, unconvincing teen comedy from Apatow and company.
Disappointing period football comedy laterals too often without a clear goal in mind.
The 'Sex' in the title may entice the unwary, but what they will experience will come closer to the title's other noun.
Fast action combined with rock-solid characters.
Its characters, especially the youngest one, are engaging, and few adults are immune to childhood fantasies about secluded tropical isles.
While not as silly as it sounds, it nevertheless is silly (as are most horror films), and while certainly different, the payoff isn't there.
Deception will deceive very few viewers as an all-too-obvious setup leads to a foregone conclusion featuring forgettable characters.
Iron Man may not make the A-list of Marvel Comics' stable -- home to Spider-Man, X-Men and the Hulk -- but he may be the cinema superhero for the rest of us.
Unlike a Pixar cartoon that embraces as wide an audience as possible, Speed Racer proudly denies entry into its ultra-bright world to all but gamers, fanboys and anime enthusiasts.
This lyrical drama about memory and survivor's guilt taps a deep reservoir of emotions.
Full-contact marital warfare connects with every body part save the funny bone.
This family film is willing to tackle important issues such as burgeoning sexuality, alcoholism and a troubled home life but does so in a bland and unconvincing story.
Though aimed primarily at youngsters, KF Panda embraces humor that plays well across age groups and nationalities.

movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The movie seems more like a '50s science fiction film of extreme paranoia or an episode of "The Twilight Zone" that even at a swiftly paced 90 minutes feels padded.
A neat thrill ride with an intelligent script by Zak Penn and smart, well-paced direction by the French director of The Transporter series, Louis Leterrier.
Brooks tiptoes into territory Luis Bunuel would have frolicked in, but he does so without the master surrealist's desire to outrage and confound his viewers.
This is a slap-dash effort whose producers threw money and stunts onscreen instead of the satirical gags and one-liners that made the old spy spoof so memorable.
Not only does the film stumble badly from one skit to another, the skits themselves have too much dead air.
This is getting to sound like a broken record: Pixar Animation Studios has just topped itself. Again.

Pure adrenaline. [Nolan], having dispensed with his introspective, moody origin story, now puts the Caped Crusader through a decathlon of explosions, vehicle flips, hand-to-hand combat, midair rescues and pulse-pounding suspense.
A splendid revival off the old Hitchcock train-suspense movie set aboard a most ominous train.
The CG animation is nothing special, but the characters are surprisingly fun and the story is full of enough puns, wordplay and slapstick to elicit laughs from across the age spectrum.
A delight, brimming with colorful, elastic characters and bountiful wit.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A homogenized piffle about the "ordeal" of a middle-class college grad momentarily without a job.
Digital imagery imagines a striking prehistoric world for these back-to-basics heroes, villains and raging beasts.
Two glorious star turns by gifted actresses Frances McDormand and Amy Adams.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film can never quite decide whether it's speculative fiction or a B-movie horror show. It's not a fatal flaw, though.
[Woody] Harrelson digs deep for this portrait of shallowness.
There is nothing special about this romance.
Terrific acting lights up this period drama directed by Denzel Washington.
It's virtually the same movie with new locations. Oh, plus Helen Mirren. Not a bad addition, but the popcorn fun is gone.
So lacking in imagination is this movie that the Brothers Strause and writer Shane Salerno keep scrambling back to the original movie for inspiration.
It plods along at a sluggard's pace through a weak premise with crude execution and even cruder characters to arrive at an unearned sentimental ending.
[An] improbable and generally unfunny comedy.
For all of Gondry's undeniable talent, it would be hard to imagine him pulling off this delicate and even cornball conceit without his star, Jack Black.
The film certainly makes a compelling case for this particular kind of academic derring-do.
[Screenwriter] Poirier is a master at dialogue. His script crackles with sharp lines and he gives all his scenes a splendid comic undertow.
A sometimes insightful and other times sentimental slice of Americana.
Plays like diminished comedy.
Overall, the film lacks dramatic heft.
The actors gamely struggle to find some truth here, but their director lets them down: [Johan] Renck sees nothing other than True Events to exploit.
The freshness and ingenuity of this techno-thriller should spark a cult following.
A melodious howl of protest against the Iraq War from one of rock's greatest bands.
Three stories involving essentially the same elderly man are slight, slight and slighter.
A biographical documentary doesn't get any better than this.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An invaluable document for the time capsule.
A much smarter film was possible.
At the end of a very long night, Light is simply another in a long line of Rolling Stones concert films.
It seems like Morris...misses the bigger picture.
The movie is one long argument, tiresome and repetitive, that produces more heat than light.
Semi-Pro is a mess, but it's a likable one.
Families seem to be extremely tolerant of taxing movie car trips. Perhaps the trick is that everyone is simply glad it's happening to another family and not theirs.
Painfully funny satire of British and American bureaucrats in the days leading up to the Iraq War.

A total misfire from the first scene to the last.

This is not a case of doubling the fun so much as an anxious attempt to revive a franchise running out of gas.

The best thing about this movie -- starring Alex Pettyfer, Vanessa Hudgens and Mary-Kate Olsen -- is that it's only 86 minutes long.

A moderately entertaining crime drama from people who know their way around a bloody knife or suspicious evidence.
An optimistic exploration of what's right and wrong with the world.
Intriguing if unbelievable sci-fi piece that quickens the pulse even if you don't completely buy into the set-up.
A couple infiltrates a secretive cult in this tense, very low-budget thriller with science fiction overtones.
Limitless should be so much smarter than it is.
A jigsaw of intimate relationships and betrayals during wartime with more than a few pieces missing.

An eye-opening and most entertaining doc about a group of autistic people who challenge old misconceptions about the disability.
A fun and funny mix of live action and animation that puts the hop back into Easter.

The Conspirator is never less than thought-provoking and illuminating. It's an answer to those who moan that they don't make movies like they used to

movie_review_blurb: A tired though vigorously acted story about a father confronted with a son who wants to be a girl.

An artificial drama enlivened by solid acting but dragged down by contrived melodrama over a fundamentalist nut.
The movie features a great finish, where three movies' worth of subplots and characters dovetail into a breathtaking climax and final confrontation that is positively soul satisfying.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The riveting, flesh-and-blood story behind the headlines.

It merely recycles 1987's Broadcast News with only a single reference to YouTube.
How Lena Dunham made her movie is more impressive or at least unique than the actual story she chooses to tell.

In the end, this is a smart movie that could have been smarter. The script feels like it was a draft or so away from total clarity and focus. But the energy of the cast and a dive into an unfamiliar world make the movie rather addictive.
Death comes in 3D but everything else is tedious.
Henry Jaglom again tries to mix comedy with melodrama with decidedly mixed results.
A throwback to the '70s -- straight action with a few clever twists, all anchored by solid characters actors
The film, like a great meal, leaves you wanting more.
The ingredients here congeal into a gooey mess that is not without amusing moments.
A live-action/cartoon mix that's misguided in just about every way.

Themes and cliches plucked from countless country lyrics fuel a thoroughly unconvincing show business story about a larger-than-life, crash-and-burn star and her unruly entourage of self-serving personalities.
An effects-driven children's movie enlivened by Jack Black but deadened by over reliance on those effects.
It's a mood piece, and that mood is melancholy.

All the trappings of a horror film without any real horror or jolts.

A mesmerizing, multilayered portrait of one of the world's great cities.

movie_review_blurb: An arresting visual style cannot make up for lack of new information or viewpoints about the Green Revolution in 2009 Iran.

Director Bhatkal keeps the pace lively especially when things pick up following the boy's return to the town with an unpronounceable name.

There are small moments in the film though that make you long for a movie that is not so deep-dish serious and self-conscious.

The movie does achieve something nearly impossible: Someone who doesn't even like the sport may care about Billy Beane and the 2002 Oakland Athletics.
Surprisingly, this is easily director Roland Emmerich's best film.

Easily [Coppola's] silliest work ever.

First and foremost a testament to the power of the documentary.
A fascinating observational doc about the most famous restaurant in the world.

It wants only to thrill -- and so it does.
Family matriarchs played by Angela Bassett and Loretta Devine go up against each other in a wedding comedy that grows increasingly unfunny with each passing minute.
The real question, is who cares?
Something blue as well as this wedding party has enough unlikable characters to put anyone into a funk.
A big disappointment for fans of Antonio Banderas and film noir.

The Lion of Judah turns out to be a lamb and this Bible story with animals turns out to be exceedingly lame.
A for-small-children movie that excludes everyone else.
movie_title: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is fast, funny and light on its feet, dipping less into politics or religion than into cultural quirks and characteristics.
By keeping things simple and understated, director Chris Weitz and screenwriter Eric Eason have crafted a little gem where humanity is observed with compassion, not condescension.
The six penguins cast in this amiable Fox family comedy steal the movie -- along with any fish they can find -- although the film's star, Jim Carrey, does manage very nicely to hold his own.
A smartly shot sea documentary delivers its ecological message but does suffer from an overly dramatic narration.
A scary film where the scares peter out far too quickly.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The kick of the first movie was the pleasurable shock of humans and these transformative mechanical beings interacting. The third chapter is dedicated to little more than wanton destruction.
A romantic comedy whose obsession with easy laughs undermines the dramatic opportunities in a story about a suddenly jobless man.
Probably isn't horrible enough to excite younger viewers and will certainly not attract anyone else.
An emotionally powerful tale of two sets of Chinese women in two different centuries.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Nothing is bleaker than failed black comedy, which this is.
In terms of even recent films, Captain America lacks the deft touch, appealing character interaction and sophisticated storytelling skills of Marvel Comics' X-Men: First Class.
The movie suffers perhaps from too many characters and subplots but all the actors appear to have fun with their characters.
It sounds kooky on paper, but on the screen, cowboys and aliens make beautiful, fun music together.
An agreeably sick little movie about a serial killer, a bunch of cats and the uneasy tenants of a Montreal apartment complex.
A gripping, intimate story to which science fiction adds a provocative, philosophical context.
Katherine Heigl and Josh Duhamel do make for very attractive leads while bringing plenty of vitality to thinly written roles.
A refreshing throwback to movie musicals that celebrates its stars while indulging in sexy fun.
An extremely versatile and talented cast struggles mightily to make something funny that simply isn't.
The plot? Wish you hadn't asked.
Exquisitely produced but dramatically erratic.

Over-the-top -- and ultimately tiresome -- female mud-wrestling, kick-boxing and cat fights in a parody of old exploitation movies.

A fanciful and melancholy portrait of exiled Russian poet Joseph Brodsky.

An encouraging film for the large Philip Seymour Hoffman fan club -- he directs with the same energy and integrity he brings to his acting.

The results are entertaining -- up to a point.

This clearly is an actors' movie, and they all blossom in that environment.
The screen is alive with more action and the soundtrack pops with more robust music than any dozen sci-fi shoot-'em-ups you care to mention.

Jeff Bridges is terrific but the movie only ordinary.
Crass, nonstop action triumphs over narrative and character in this movie-length simulation of a video game.
A comedy about corporate fraud, malfeasance and a mental disorder that never quite succeeds as a comedy.
A sports rivalry poisons everyone in this British soccer movie based, loosely, on a true story.
An unoriginal and mostly unscary horror-comedy from, surprisingly, the pen of Diablo Cody.
Never does anything feel forced or contrived. Life, as this memoir reminds, can offer plenty of drama that need not abide by fictional formulas or genre conventions.
An identical twins comic crime drama goes seriously wrong.
Just as the dystopian world the movie portrays is arid and specious, the movie itself is a mechanical sci-fi'er absent of logic or emotions.
A superb, slam-dunk documentary about young boys achieving personal and team goals on the basketball court.
A seriously funny film about an angst-ridden Jewish professor seeking the answers to life's questions and getting a metaphysical pie in the face.
This intermittently funny tale of four couples undergoing relationship therapy struggles hard for its occasional laughs.
A reverential but uninvolving adaptation of Maurice Sendak's classic illustrated book for children.
An implausible thriller with a few horror elements in the guise of social criticism.
This remake turns a fondly remembered horror/thriller into a mild and tedious suspense film.
A vampire movie in sore need of a transfusion.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A horror film with no punch.
Looks like the world has missed one helluva concert.

A Christmas Carol is, in its essence, a product reel, a showy, exuberant demonstration of the glories of motion capture, computer animation and 3D technology. On that level, it's a wow. On any emotional level, it's as cold as Marley's Ghost.
A flat-footed sitcom with unconvincing situations and comedy.
A playful throwback to the days when cartoons were mostly aimed at children.
A remake of a Danish film has much to admire but never comes together with the impact of the original.
Insipid, predictable, broad comedy mixed with Disney Family Values makes for one exasperating sit.
This is the best Disney animated film in years.
The film certainly plays well enough as a melodrama-cum-revenge thriller.
A thoroughly fake movie with trite characters that is about, of all things, the need for truthfulness.
